line: The partial inclusion of the Dardanians within the name of Troes is
further shown by the verse[491],
Αἰνεία, Τρώων βουληφόρε·
and by the appeal of Helenus to Æneas and Hector jointly, as the
persons chiefly responsible for the safety of the Troes and Lycians:
the name Lycians being taken here, as in some other places[492], to
denote most probably a race akin to and locally interspersed with the
Trojans.
But the Dardanians have more commonly their proper designation
separately given them. It never includes the Troes. And we never find
the two appellations, Troes and Dardans, covering the entire force.
Whenever the Dardans are named with the Troes, there is also another
word, either ἐπίκουροι, or Λύκιοι.
The word Troes, it is right to add, is sometimes confined strictly to
the inhabitants of the city: but the occasions are rare, and perhaps
always with contextual indications that such is the sense.
Another sign that Priam exercised a direct sovereignty over the
territory which yielded the five contingents may perhaps be found in
the fact, that we do not find any of his nephews in command of them.
They were led by their local officers, while the brothers of Priam
constituted a part of the community of Troy, and chiefly influenced the
Assembly: and their sons, though apparently more considerable persons
than most of those local officers in general, simply appear as acting
under Hector without special command. The brothers of Priam are Lampus,
Clytius, and Hiketaon. His nephews and other relatives are Dolops the
son of Lampus; Melanippus the son of Hiketaon; Polydamas, Hyperenor,
and Euphorbus, the sons of Panthous and his wife Phrontis.
Had the senior members of the family held local sovereignties, we
should have found their sons in local commands. But we find only two
sons of Antenor in command, as either colleagues or lieutenants of
Æneas, over the Dardans, whom we have no reason to suppose they had
any share in ruling.
Strabo, indeed, contends, that there are nine separate δυναστεῖαι
immediately connected with Troy[493], besides the ἐπίκουροι. Of these
states one he thinks was Lelegian, and was ruled over by Altes,
father of Laothoe, one of Priam’s wives. Another by Munes, husband of
Briseis. Another, Thebe, by Eetion, father of Andromache. Others he
considers to be represented by Anchises and Pandarus: but this does
not well agree with the structure of the Catalogue. He refers also
to Lyrnessus and Pedasus; which are nowhere mentioned by Homer as
furnishing contingents, but they had apparently been destroyed, as well
as taken, by Achilles. He places several of the dynasties in cities
thus destroyed: and they all, according to him, lay beyond the limits
marked out in the Twenty-fourth Iliad.
[493] Strabo xiii. 7. p. 584.
This assemblage of facts appears to point to a very great diversity of
relations subsisting between Priam, with his capital, and the states,
cities, and races, of which we hear as arrayed on his side in the war.
There are first the cities of Troas, or Troja proper, furnishing the
five, or if we except Dardania four out of the five, first contingents
of the Catalogue. Over these Priam was sovereign.
There are next the cities, so far as they can be traced, under the
δυναστεῖαι mentioned by Strabo, such as Thebe, and the cities of Altes
and Munes. These were probably in the same sort of relation to the
sceptre of Priam, as the Greek states in general to that of Agamemnon.
Thirdly, there are the independent nations. Of these eleven named
in the Catalogue; others are added as newly arrived in the Tenth
Book[494], and further additions were subsequently made, such as the
force under Memnon, and the Keteians under Eurypylus[495]. Nothing
perhaps tends so much, as the powerful assistance lent to Priam by
numerous and distant allies, to show how justly in substance Horace has
described the Trojan war as the conflict between the Eastern and the
Western world. The two confederacies, which then came into collision,
between them absorbed the whole known world of Homer; and foreshadowed
the great conflicts of later epochs.
~_Political institutions of Troy._~
We may now proceed to consider the political institutions of the
kingdom of Priam, which has thus loosely been defined.
The Βασιλεὺς of the Trojans is less clearly marked, than he is among
the Greeks: for (as we shall find) they had no Βουλὴ, and therefore we
have not the same opportunities of seeing the members of the highest
class collected for separate action in the conduct of the war. Still,
however, the name is distinctly given to the following persons on the
Trojan side, and to no others.
1. Priam, Il. v. 464, xxiv. 630.
2. Paris, iv. 96.
3. Rhesus, x. 435.
4. Sarpedon, xii. 319. xvi. 660.
5. Glaucus, xii. 319.
Among the Trojans, as among the Greeks, it was the custom for the
kings, as they descended into the vale of years, to devolve the more
active duties of kingship on their children, and to retain, perhaps
only for a time, those of a sedentary character. Hence Hector at least
shares with Priam the management of Assemblies, as it is he[496] who
dissolves that of the Second Book, and calls the military one of the
Eighth. Hence, too, he speaks of himself as the person responsible for
the burdens entailed by the war upon the Trojans. ‘I did not,’ he says
to the allies, ‘bring you from your cities to multiply our numbers,
but that you might defend for me the wives and children of Trojans;
with this object in view, I exhaust the people for your pay and
provisions[497].’ Hence we have Æneas leading the Dardanians, while his
father Anchises nowhere appears, and, as it must be presumed, remains
in his capital. Hence, while ten or twelve sons of Antenor bear arms
for Troy, and two of them are the colleagues of Æneas in the command of
the Dardanian contingent, their father appears among the δημογέροντες,
who were chief speakers in the Assembly within the city. We do not know
that Antenor was a king; more probably he held a lordship subordinate
to Priam, in a relation somewhat more strict than that between
Agamemnon and the Greek chieftains, and rather resembling that between
Peleus and Menœtius; but the same custom of partial retirement seems to
have prevailed in the case of subaltern rulers, as indeed it would be
dictated by the same reasons of prudence and necessity.
The βασιλήϊς τιμὴ of Troy was not, any more than those of Greece, an
absolute despotism. In Troy, as in Greece, the public affairs were
discussed and settled in the Assemblies, though with differences, which
will be noticed, from the Greek manner of procedure. It was in the
Assembly that Iris, disguised as Polites, addressed Priam and Hector to
advise a review of the army[498]. And it was again in an Assembly that
Antenor proposed, and that Paris refused, to give up Helen: whereupon
Priam proposed the mission of Idæus to ask for a truce with a view to
the burial of the dead, and the people assented to the proposal[499];
οἱ δ’ ἄρα τοῦ μάλα μὲν κλύον ἠδ’ ἐπίθοντο.
It was in the Assembly, too, that those earlier proposals had been
made, of which the same personage procured the defeat by corruption.
Lastly, in the Eighth Book, Hector[500], as we have seen, holds a
military ἀγορὴ of the army by the banks of the Scamander. At this he
invites them to bivouac outside the Greek rampart, and they accept
his proposal by acclamation. This Assembly on the field of battle is
an argument _a fortiori_ to show, that ordinary affairs were referred
among the Trojans to such meetings. We have, indeed, no detail of any
Trojan Assembly except these three. But we have references to them,
which give a similar view of their nature and functions. Idæus, on his
return, announces to the Assembly that the truce is granted[501]. It
is plain that the restoration of Helen was debated before, as well as
during the war, in the Assembly of the people; because Agamemnon slays
the two sons of Antimachus on the special ground that the father had
there proposed that Menelaus, if not Ulysses, should be murdered[502],
when they came as Envoys to Troy, for the purpose of demanding her
restoration. This Antimachus was bribed by Paris, as the Poet tells us,
to oppose the measure[503]. Again, Polydamas, in one of his speeches,
charges Hector with having used him roughly, when he had ventured
to differ from him in the Assemblies, upon the ground that he ought
not, as a stranger to the Trojan δῆμος, to promote dissension among
them[504].
Trojan institutions do not, then, present to our view a greater
elevation of the royal office. On the contrary, it is remarkable, that
the title of δημογέρων, which Homer applies to the chief speakers of
the Trojan Assembly, not being kings, is also used by him to describe
Ilus the founder of the city[505]. It is, however, possible, perhaps
even likely, that this title may be applied to Ilus as a younger son,
if his brother Assaracus was the eldest and the heir[506].
But although it thus appears that monarchy was limited in Troy, as it
was in Greece, and that public affairs were conducted in the assemblies
of the people, the method and organization of these Assemblies was
different in the two cases.
1. The guiding element in the Trojan government seems to have been age
combined with rank; while among the Greeks, wisdom and valour were
qualifications, not less available than age and rank.
2. The Greeks had the institution of a βουλὴ, which preceded and
prepared matter for their Assemblies. The Trojans had not.
3. The Greeks, as we have seen, employed oratory as a main instrument
of government; the Trojans did not.
4. The aged members of the Trojan royal family rendered their aid to
the state, not as counsellors of Priam in private meetings, but only in
the Assembly of the people.
A few words on each of these heads.
~_The greater weight of Age in Troy._~
1. The old men who appear on the wall with Priam, in the Third Book,
are really old, and not merely titular or official γέροντες; they
γήραϊ δὴ πολέμοιο πεπαυμένοι.
There are no less than seven of them, besides Priam. Three are his
brothers, Lampus, Clytius, Hiketaon; the others probably relatives,
we know not in what precise degree: Panthous, Thymœtes, Ucalegon,
Antenor. They are called collectively the Τρώων ἡγήτορες, as well as
the ἀγορηταὶ ἐσθλοί; and they were manifestly habitual speakers in the
Assembly.
There is nothing in the Greek life of the Homeric poems that comes near
this aggregation of aged men. Now we have no evidence, that their being
thus collected was in any degree owing to the war. Theano, wife of
Antenor, was priestess of Minerva in Troy; which makes it most probable
that he resided there habitually, and not only on account of the war.
The only group at all approaching this is, where we see Menœtius and
Phœnix at the Court of Peleus; but we cannot say whether this was a
permanent arrangement. Phœnix, as we know, was lord of the Dolopians,
and if so, could not have been a standing assistant at the court of
Peleus; we do not know that the Trojan elders held any such local
position apart from Troy, even in any single case; and on the other
hand, we have no knowledge whether Phœnix and Menœtius, even when at
the court of Peleus, took any share in the government of his immediate
dominions. The name γέροντες, as usually employed among the Greeks to
describe a class, had no necessary relation to age whatever.
Of the respect paid to age in Greece, we have abundant evidence; but we
find nothing like this gathering together of a body of old men to be
the ordinary guides of popular deliberation in the Assemblies.
It is true that we hear by implication of both Hector and Polydamas,
who were not old, as taking part in affairs: but all the indications
in the Iliad go to show that Hector’s share in the government of Troy,
though not limited to the mere conduct of the forces in the field,
yet arose out of his military office, and probably touched only such
matters as were connected with the management of the war. Polydamas
evidently was treated as more or less an interloper.
But even if it were otherwise, and if the middle-aged men of high
station and ability took a prominent part in affairs, the existence of
this grey-headed company, with apparently the principal statesmanship
of Troy in their hands, forms a marked difference from Greek manners.
For in Greece at peace we have nothing akin to it; while in Greece at
war upon the plain of Troy, we see the young Diomed as well as the old
Nestor, and the rather young Achilles and Ajax, as well as the elderly
Idomeneus, associated with the middle-aged men in the government of the
army and its operations.
~_The absence of a Βουλὴ in Troy._~
First then, I think it plain that the Trojans had no βουλὴ, for the
following reasons:
1. That although we often hear of deliberations and decisions taken on
the part of the Trojans, and we have instances enough of their holding
assemblies of the people, yet we never find mention of a βουλὴ, or
Council, in connection with them.
2. In the Second Book, Homer describes the Trojan ἀγορὴ thus (Il. ii.
οἱ δ’ ἀγορὰς ἀγόρευον ἐπὶ Πριάμοιο θύρῃσιν
πάντες ὁμηγερέες, ἠμὲν νέοι ἠδὲ γέροντες.
This latter line is only to be accounted for by the supposition, that
Homer meant to describe a difference between the usages of the Trojans,
and those of the Greeks; whose γέροντες were recognised as members of
the βουλὴ, even when in the Assemblies.
Of the separate place of the Greek γέροντες in the Assemblies, we have
conclusive proof from the Shield of Achilles (xviii. 497, 503):
λαοὶ δ’ εἰν ἀγορῇ ἔσαν ἄθροοι·
and afterwards,
οἱ δὲ γέροντες
εἵατ’ ἐπὶ ξεστοῖσι λίθοις, ἱερῷ ἐνὶ κύκλῳ.
And again, where the Ithacan γέροντες make way for Telemachus, as he
passes to the chair of his father.
But in Troy the γέροντες (such is probably the meaning of Il. ii. 789.)
have no separate function: the young and the old meet together: while
in Greece, besides distinct places in the Assembly, the γέροντες had an
exclusive function in the βουλὴ, at which they met separately from the
young.
3. It would appear that the ἀγορὴ was with the Trojans not occasional,
as with the Greeks, for great questions, but habitual. And this agrees
with the description in Il. ii. 788. For when Jupiter sends Iris to
Troy, she finds the people in Assembly, but apparently for no special
purpose, as she immediately, in the likeness of Polites, begins to
address Priam, and we do not hear of any other business. So, when
Idæus came back from the Greeks, he found the Trojan Assembly still
sitting. All this looks as if the entire business of administering the
government rested with that body only.
I draw a similar inference from the remarkable expression in Il. ii.
788, ἀγορὰς ἀγόρευον. This seems to express that there was a standing,
probably a daily, assembly of the Trojans, not formally summoned, and
open to all comers, which acted as the governing body for the state.
The line would then mean, not simply ‘the Trojans were holding an
assembly,’ but ‘the Trojans were holding their assembly as usual.’
The names βουλευτὴς and ἀγορητὴς appear to have been merely
descriptive, and not titular. Both are applied to the Trojan elders.
And so βουλαὶ, βουλεύειν, βουληφόροι, are constantly used without any,
so to speak, official meaning. In Il. x. 147, the expression βουλὰς
βουλεύειν can hardly mean ‘to attend the βουλὴ,’ for the singular
number would be the proper term for the βουλὴ specially convoked: and
I interpret it as meaning, to attend at or to hold the usual council.
This is among the Greeks. Among the Trojans, in Il. x. 415-17, Dolon
says,
Ἕκτωρ μὲν μετὰ τοῖσιν, ὅσοι βουληφόροι εἰσὶν,
βουλὰς βουλεύει θείου παρὰ σήματι Ἴλου,
νόσφιν ἀπὸ φλοίσβου.
Now the word βουληφόρος is applied, Il. xii. 414, to Sarpedon, as well
as in xiii. 463 and elsewhere to Æneas. Neither were among the γέροντες
βουλευταί. But further, it is applied, Od. ix. 112, to the ἀγορὴ itself:
τοῖσιν δ’ οὔτ’ ἀγοραὶ βουληφόροι, οὔτε θέμιστες
And therefore the word, though it means councillor in a general sense,
does not mean officially member of a βουλὴ, as opposed to an ἀγορὴ or
Assembly.
The phrase βουλὰς βουλεύει, in the passage Il. x. 415-17, does not
oppose, but supports what has now been said. It is quite plain that
this of Hector’s was a small military meeting, or council of war,
just as in viii. 489 he held an ἀγορὴ, or assembly of the army, both
Trojans and allies; it was not a meeting of a βουλὴ of Troy, because
it was held in the field, far from the city, and without any of the
Elders, who were the great ἀγορηταὶ and βουλευταὶ of Troy; for Hector
had already arranged (Il. viii. 517-19) that the old men should remain
in the city, to defend the walls from any night attack: most of all
however because, as we hear of no βουλὴ before the military Assembly
in the Eighth Book, so we hear of no Assembly following the meeting
for deliberation in the Tenth. Generals in modern times hold councils
of war: but no parallel can be drawn between them, and Councils for
dispatching the affairs of a State.
As we never have occasion to become acquainted with Trojan politics in
peace, we can only argue the case as to the nonexistence of a council
from the state of war. But in Greece, it will be remembered, both war
and peace present their cases of the use of this institution, as one
regularly established, and apparently invested with both a deliberative
and an executive character.
~_The greater weight of oratory in Greece._~
It is next to be inquired, whether the Trojans, like the Greeks,
employed eloquence, detailed argument as furnishing, and the other
parts of oratory, a main instrument of government.
I think it is plain, that the decisions of their Assemblies were
governed rather by simple authority; by the ἀναποδεικταὶ φάσεις, the
simple declarations, of persons of weight.
The report of the re-assembled ἀγορὴ of the Greeks in the Second
Book begins with the 211th line, and ends with the 398th: occupying
188 lines. But the Trojan ἀγορὴ of the same Book is despatched in
twenty-one lines (788-808).
A more remarkable example is afforded by the second Trojan Assembly
(Il. vii. 345-379). For this ἀγορὴ is described as δεινὴ, τετρηχυῖα;
and well it might be, in circumstances so arduous. The Elders in the
Third Book were of opinion that, beautiful as Helen was, it was better
to restore her, than to continue the sufferings and dangers of the
war. Accordingly, Antenor urged in this Assembly that she should be
restored, together with the plundered property. He referred also to the
recent breach of a sworn covenant on the Trojan side, and said no good
could come of it. This he effects in a speech of six lines; the first
of which is the mere vocative address to the Assembly, and the last is
marked as surplusage with the _obelos_ (348-53).
Paris, the person mainly concerned, replies. He does not address
himself to the Assembly at all, but to Antenor: and he disposes of the
subject of debate in eight lines (357-64). Four of them are given to
the announcement of his intentions, and four to abuse of Antenor.
It was impossible to conceive a subject more likely to cause debate;
and excitement we see there was, but after the speech of Paris, nothing
more was said about Helen, either for or against the restoration. Priam
then arose, and in a speech of eleven lines (368-78) laid down another
plan of proceeding, namely, by a message to the Greeks for a truce with
a view to funeral obsequies, which was at once accepted.
~_Oratory of greater weight in Greece._~
Nowhere, in short, among the Trojans have we any example, I do not
say of multiplied or lengthened speeches, but of real reasoning and
deliberation in the conduct of business: though Glaucus tells his story
at great length to Diomed on the field of battle (Il. vi. 145-211),
and Æneas to Achilles (Il. xx. 199-258) nearly equals him. Indeed, it
may almost be said, the Trojans are long speakers when in battle, and
short when in debate: the Greeks copious in debate, but very succinct
in battle.
Again, we may observe the different descriptions which the Poet
has given of the elocution of Nestor, and of that of the Trojan
δημογέροντες in their respective ἀγοραί. To Nestor (Il. i. 248, 9)
he seems to assign a soft continuous flow indefinitely prolonged.
Theirs he describes as resembling the ὄπα λειριόεσσαν of grasshoppers
(Il. iii. 151, 2), a clear trill or thread of voice, not only without
any particular idea of length attached to it, but apparently meant
to recall a sharp intermittent chirp. Yet there is an odd proof that
to Priam at least, as one of these old men, there was attached, by
the younger ones, the imputation of favouring either too many or else
too long orations. For, in the ἀγορὴ of the Second Book, Iris in the
character of Polites, though there is no account of what had preceded
her arrival, objurgates Priam as both then encouraging what may be
called indiscriminate speaking, and as having formally, before the war,
been addicted to the same practice[508];
ὦ γέρον, αἰεί τοι μῦθοι φίλοι ἄκριτοί εἰσιν,
ὥς ποτ’ ἐπ’ εἰρήνης.
Upon the whole, I think it must have been Homer’s intention, while
representing both Trojans and Greeks as carrying on public affairs in
their public Assemblies, to draw a very marked distinction between them
in regard to the use of that powerful engine of oratory, which played
so conspicuous a part in the former, as well as in the later stages of
the Greek history.
And it is important, that nowhere does a sentiment escape the lips of
a Trojan chieftain, which indicates a consciousness of the political
value of oratory. Ulysses, in a state of peace, describes before the
Phæacians beauty and eloquence as the noblest gifts of the gods to
man[509]: and employs ἔπεα and νόος, eloquence and intelligence, as
convertible terms. Polydamas, when rebuking Hector in the Thirteenth
Iliad, delivers a passage in many respects strikingly analogous. He
speaks, however, of νόος and βουλὴ, mind and counsel[510]; he does not
drop a word relating to public speech or to eloquence as instruments of
government, though he describes the mental quality and the habit which
he names as of priceless value for the benefit of States.
The phrases applied to the Trojan elders appear to indicate, that they
derived their political character from taking a prominent part in the
Assembly, and from that alone. For the word δημογέρων indicates an
elder acting in and among the δῆμος, or people. And this name the Poet
uses but twice: once in Il. iii. 149, where he enumerates the eight
persons, who bore that character in Troy; and once with reference to
Ilus (Il. ii. 372). Homer nowhere employs this term for any of the
Greeks.
The want of the βουλὴ shows us, that there was no balance of forces
in the Trojan polity, less security against precipitate action, more
liability to high-handed insolence and oppression of the people, and,
on the other hand, unless the danger had been neutralized by mildness
or lethargy of character, likewise in all likelihood to revolutionary
change.
~_Trojans less gifted with self-command._~
Again, on the Trojan side we do not find the silence and
self-possession of the Greeks. After the enumeration in the Third Book,
at its opening, we find that the Trojans marched with din and buzz:
Τρῶες μὲν κλαγγῇ τ’ ἐνοπῇ τ’ ἴσαν, ὄρνιθες ὥς·
but as to the Greeks, we are told that they marched in profound
silence: and the Poet skilfully heightens the contrast by mentioning
that they breathed forth what they did not articulate, and that they
were steeled with firm resolution to stand by one another[511]:
οἱ δ’ ἄρ’ ἴσαν σιγῇ μένεα πνείοντες Ἀχαιοὶ,
ἐν θυμῷ μεμαῶτες ἀλεξέμεν ἀλλήλοισιν.
We are finally told that each leader indeed gave the word to his men,
while all beside were mute[512]:
οἱ δ’ ἄλλοι ἀκὴν ἴσαν, οὐδέ κε φαίης
τόσσον λαὸν ἕπεσθαι ἔχοντ’ ἐν στήθεσιν αὐδὴν,
σιγῇ δειδιότες σημάντορας·
but from the Trojans there arose a sound, like that of sheep bleating
for their lambs[513]:
ὣς Τρώων ἀλαλητὸς ἀνὰ στρατὸν εὐρὺν ὀρώρει.
And, again, we find the relation of the burning of the dead given with
the usual consistency of the Poet. The men of the two armies met: and
on both sides they shed tears as they lifted their lifeless comrades on
the wagons: but, he adds, there was silence among the Trojans,
οὐδ’ εἴα κλαίειν Πρίαμος μέγας·
and it was because the king had felt that there would be indecency in a
noisy show of sorrow: while the Greeks needed not the injunction (Il.
vii. 426-32), from their spontaneous self-command.
When the Poet speaks of the Trojan Assembly in the Seventh Book as
δεινὴ τετρηχυῖα, he evidently means to describe an excitement tending
to disorder: and one contrasted in a remarkable manner with the
discipline of the Greeks, who were summoned to meet silently in the
night, that they might not, in gathering, arouse the enemy outside the
ramparts. Even in their respective modes of expressing approbation,
Homer makes a shade of difference. When the Greeks applaud, it is
ἐπίαχον υἷες Ἀχαιῶν, or what we call loud or vehement cheering: but
when the Trojans, it is ἐπὶ δὲ Τρῶες κελάδησαν, which signifies a more
miscellaneous and tumultuous noise.
In short, it would appear to be the intention of Homer to represent
the Greeks as possessed of a higher intelligence throughout. In the
Odyssey, we find that Ulysses made his way into Troy disguised as
a beggar, communicated with Helen, duly informed himself (κατὰ δὲ
φρόνιν ἤγαγε πολλήν[514]), and contrived to despatch certain of the
Trojans before he departed. In the Iliad we are supplied with abundant
instances of the superior management of the Greeks, and likewise of
their auxiliary gods, in comparison with those of the Trojans. Juno
outwits Venus in obtaining from her the cestus, and then proceeds
to outwit Jupiter in the use of it. Minerva, on observing that the
Greeks are losing, (Il. vii. 17) betakes herself to Troy, where Apollo
proposes just what she wants, namely, a cessation of the general
engagement, with a view to a personal encounter between Hector and some
chosen chieftain: she immediately adopts the plan; and he causes it to
be executed through Helenus. It both stops the general havoc among the
Greeks, and redounds greatly to the honour of their champion Ajax. At
the end of the day, however, Nestor suggests to the Greek chiefs, on
account of their heavy losses (Il. vii. 328), that they should, on the
occasion of raising a mound over their dead, likewise dig and fortify
a trench, which might serve to defend the ships and camp. In the mean
time the Trojans are made to meet; and they send to propose the very
measure, namely, an armistice for funeral rites, which the Greeks
desire, in order, under cover of it, to fortify themselves (Il. vii.
368-97). And this accordingly Agamemnon is enabled to grant as a sort
of favour to the Trojans (Il. vii. 408):
ἀμφὶ δὲ νεκροῖσιν κατακαιέμεν οὔτι μεγαίρω.
This superior intelligence is probably meant to be figured by the
exchange of arms between Glaucus and Diomed. And, again, when Hector
attempts anything in the nature of a stratagem, as the mission of
Dolon by night, it is only that he may fall into the hands of Diomed
and Ulysses. But there does not appear to be in any of these cases
a violation of oath, compact, or any absolute rule of equity by the
Greeks.
Of all these traits, however, it may be said, that they are of no
value as evidence, if taken by themselves. They are means which would
obviously occur to the Poet, zealous for his own nation. It is their
accordance with other indications, apparently undesigned, which
warrants our relying upon them as real testimonies, available for an
historic purpose.
~_Difference in pursuits of high-born youth._~
Although, on the whole, we seem to have the signs of greater wealth
among the Trojans than the Greeks, yet in certain points also their
usages were more primitive and simple. Thus we find the youths of the
house of Nestor immediately about his person; and Patroclus, as well
as Achilles, was apparently brought up at the court of Peleus. Again,
the youthful Nestor travels into Thessaly for a campaign: Ulysses
goes to hunt at the Court of his grandfather Autolycus. The Ithacan
Suitors employ themselves in manly games. But we frequently come upon
passages where we are incidentally informed, that the princes of the
house of Dardanus were occupied in rustic employments. Thus Melanippus,
son of Hiketaon, and cousin of Hector, who was residing in Priam’s
palace, and treated as one of his children, had before the war tended
oxen in Percote[515]. Æneas, the only son and heir of Anchises, had
been similarly occupied among or near the hills, at the time when he
had a narrow escape from capture by Achilles[516]. Lycaon, son of
Priam, was cutting the branches of the wild fig for the fellies of
chariot-wheels when Achilles took him for the second time: on the first
occasion, he had been at work in a vineyard[517]. Antiphos and Isos,
sons of Priam, had been captured by Achilles whilst they were acting
as shepherds[518]. Anchises was acting as a herdsman, when he formed
his connection with Venus[519]. The name of Boucolion, an illegitimate
son of Laomedon, seems to indicate that he was bred for the like
occupation[520].
From the force, variety, and extreme delicacy of his uses of the
word, it is evident that Homer set very great store by the sentiment
which is generally expressed through the word αἰδώς, and which ranges
through all the varieties of shame, honour, modesty, and reverence.
Though a minute, it is a remarkable circumstance, that he confines
the application of this term to the Greeks; except, I think, in one
passage, where he bestows it upon his particular favourites the
Lycians[521], and a single other one, where Æneas[522] employs it under
the immediate inspiration of Apollo, with another sense, in an appeal
to Hector and his brother chiefs, not to the soldiery at large.
With the Greeks it supplies the staple of military exhortation[523]
from the chiefs to the army; Αἰδὼς, Ἀργεῖοι.
[523] Il. v. 787. viii. 228. _et alibi_.
But quite a different form of speech is uniformly addressed to the
Trojans proper: it is
ἀνέρες ἔστε, φίλοι, μνήσασθε δὲ θουρίδος ἀλκῆς,
which is below the other, and appeals to a less peculiar and refined
frame of intelligence and of sentiment.
~_Summary of differences._~
Whatever may be thought of the degree of detail into which (guided as
I think by the text) I have ventured to carry this discussion, and of
the particularity of some of the inferences that have been drawn, I
venture to hope few will quit the subject without the conviction that
Homer has worked with the purpose and precision which are his wont, in
the diversities which mark the general outline of his Greeks and his
Trojans, and of the institutions of each respectively; and that he has
not altogether withheld from his national portraits the care, which he
is admitted to have applied to his individual characters on both sides
with such extraordinary success. If we look to the institutions of the
two countries, although the comparison is diversified, we must upon
the whole concede to the Greeks, that they had laid more firmly than
their adversaries those great corner stones of human society, which are
named in their language, θέμις, ὅρκος, and γάμος. In the polity of Troy
we find more scope for impulse, less for deliberation and persuasion;
more weight given to those elements of authority which do not depend
on our free will and intelligence, less to those which do; less of
organization and of diversity, less firmness and tenacity of tissue, in
the structure of the community. We are told of no φῦλα and no φρῆτραι,
no intermediate ranks of officers in the army; no order of nobles or
proprietors, such as that which furnished the Suitors of Ithaca. There
are, in short, fewer secondary eminences; it is a state of things, more
resembling the dead level of the present Oriental communities subject
to a despotic throne, though such was not the throne of Priam. Among
the people themselves, there is more of religious observance and
apparatus, but not more of morality: less tendency indeed to crimes
of violence and turbulence, but also less of truth, of honour, above
all of personal self-mastery and self-command. The Greeks never would
have produced the Paris of the Iliad; for on behalf of no such dastard
would they have been induced to bleed. But if they had engendered
such a creature, they would not have paid the penalty: for man in
the Trojan type would not have had the energy to recover it from the
warrior-statesmen of the Achæan race, and under no circumstances could
the really extravagant sentiment put by Virgil into the mouth of
Diomed[524] have been fulfilled:
ultro Inachias venisset ad urbes
Dardanus, et versis lugeret Græcia fatis.

line: The soul of Achilles is stirred from its depths by an outrage, which

Poem Title: SECT. I.
line: seems to him to comprehend all vices within itself. He is wounded in

Poem Title: SECT. I.
line: an attachment that had become a tender one; for he gives to Briseis the

Poem Title: SECT. I.
line: name of wife (ἄλοχον θυμάρεα), and avows his care and protection of her

line: in that character. A proud and sensitive warrior, he is[693] insulted

Poem Title: SECT. I.
line: in the face of the army; and to the Greeks, whose governing sentiment

Poem Title: SECT. I.
line: was αἴδως, or honour, insult was the deadliest of all inflictions.

Poem Title: SECT. I.

Poem Title: SECT. I.

Poem Title: SECT. I.

Poem Title: SECT. I.

Poem Title: SECT. I.

line: It is not vice, nor is it virtue, which Homer is describing in his

Poem Title: SECT. I.
line: Achilles; it is that strange and wayward mixture of regard for right

Poem Title: SECT. I.
line: and justice with self-love on the one side, and wrath on the other,

Poem Title: SECT. I.
line: which are so common among us men of meaner scale. The difference is,

Poem Title: SECT. I.
line: that in Achilles all the parts of the compound are at once deepened to

Poem Title: SECT. I.

Poem Title: SECT. I.

Poem Title: SECT. I.

Poem Title: SECT. I.

Poem Title: SECT. I.

line: It can hardly fail to draw remark, that the spirit of Achilles never

Poem Title: SECT. I.
line: from the first moment fastens on mere restitution, or on restitution

Poem Title: SECT. I.
line: at all, as its object. With his knowledge of his own might, which was

Poem Title: SECT. I.
line: enough to prompt him, had he not been restrained from heaven, to assail

Poem Title: SECT. I.
line: and slay Agamemnon on the spot, he nevertheless does not so much as

Poem Title: SECT. I.
line: entertain the thought of fighting to keep Briseis. His thought is far

Poem Title: SECT. I.
line: other than this: ‘I will not lift a finger against one of you for the

Poem Title: SECT. I.
line: girl, since you choose to take from me what you gave (298, 9). I will

Poem Title: SECT. I.
line: not hold what you think fit to grudge.’ While he adds, that they shall

Poem Title: SECT. I.
line: not touch an article of what is properly his own[699]. Not that he

Poem Title: SECT. I.
line: cares for mere possession or dispossession. Were that his thought, he

Poem Title: SECT. I.
line: would have lifted up the invincible arm for the retention of Briseis.

Poem Title: SECT. I.
line: But his thought is this, ‘One outrage you have done to justice and

Poem Title: SECT. I.
line: to me, and, encouraged as well as commanded by great deities, I bear

Poem Title: SECT. I.
line: it; but not even under their promises and injunctions will I endure

Poem Title: SECT. I.
line: that you shall sin again.’ The loss he had suffered now became quite

Poem Title: SECT. I.
line: a subordinate image in his mind; punishment of the offenders, and

Poem Title: SECT. I.
line: not restitution, was ever before his view. His first threat is that

Poem Title: SECT. I.
line: of withdrawal (Il. i. 169): which, he conceives, will put a stop to

Poem Title: SECT. I.
line: Agamemnon’s rapacious accumulations. Next (233) he swears the mighty

Poem Title: SECT. I.
line: oath that every Greek shall rue the day of his wrong, and look in vain

Poem Title: SECT. I.
line: to Agamemnon for protection against the sword of Hector. Again, in his

Poem Title: SECT. I.
line: prayer to Thetis, he intreats that she will induce Jupiter to drive the

Poem Title: SECT. I.
line: Greeks in rout and slaughter back upon the ships and the sea. He never

Poem Title: SECT. I.
line: dreams of the mere reparation of his wrong: when he refers to Briseis

Poem Title: SECT. I.

Poem Title: SECT. I.

Poem Title: SECT. I.

Poem Title: SECT. I.

Poem Title: SECT. I.

Poem Title: SECT. I.

Poem Title: SECT. I.
line: of his foe, and magnifying the occasion and achievements of his own

Poem Title: SECT. I.
line: might, to be put forth when the proper time shall come.

Poem Title: SECT. I.

Poem Title: SECT. I.

line: If we were to consider Achilles as engaged in a mere personal quarrel,

Poem Title: SECT. I.

Poem Title: SECT. I.

Poem Title: SECT. I.

Poem Title: SECT. I.

line: We should look in vain, I think, for a finer and subtler exercise of

Poem Title: SECT. I.
line: poetic art, than in the mode in which Homer has contrived to convey to

Poem Title: SECT. I.
line: us, both the general, and in particular the military inferiority of

Poem Title: SECT. I.
line: the Trojans, as compared with the Greeks. Hardly any reader can be so

Poem Title: SECT. I.
line: superficial in his observation of the poem, as not to rise from it with

Poem Title: SECT. I.
line: this inferiority sufficiently impressed upon his mind. Yet there is

Poem Title: SECT. I.
line: not a passage or a word throughout, in which it is asserted. And why?

Poem Title: SECT. I.
line: Because every direct assertion that the Trojans were less valiant or

Poem Title: SECT. I.
line: less strong than their antagonists, would have been so much detracted

Poem Title: SECT. I.
line: from the glory of overcoming them. It was essential to the work of the

Poem Title: SECT. I.
line: Poet, that he should represent the contest as an arduous one. He might

Poem Title: SECT. I.
line: have done this in the coarse method, for which his theurgy would have

Poem Title: SECT. I.
line: afforded the materials: that is, by converting his Trojans into mere

Poem Title: SECT. I.

Poem Title: SECT. I.
line: the impelling force of some deity or other, and, independently of

Poem Title: SECT. I.
line: such extraneous aid, was powerless. But this would have destroyed the

Poem Title: SECT. I.
line: full-flushed humanity of Homer’s poem.

Poem Title: SECT. II.

Poem Title: SECT. II.

Poem Title: SECT. II.

Poem Title: SECT. II.

Poem Title: SECT. II.

Poem Title: SECT. II.

line: These five lines form the largest of the merely personal descriptions

Poem Title: SECT. II.

Poem Title: SECT. II.

Poem Title: SECT. II.

Poem Title: SECT. II.

Poem Title: SECT. II.

Poem Title: SECT. II.

Poem Title: SECT. II.

Poem Title: SECT. II.

Poem Title: SECT. II.

Poem Title: SECT. II.

Poem Title: SECT. II.

Poem Title: SECT. III.
SECT. III.
line: _Homer’s perceptions and use of Number._

Poem Title: SECT. III.
SECT. III.
line: While the faculties of Homer were in many respects both intense and

Poem Title: SECT. III.
line: refined in their action, beyond all ordinary, perhaps we might say

Poem Title: SECT. III.
line: beyond all modern, examples, there were other points in which they

Poem Title: SECT. III.
line: bear the marks of having been less developed than is now common even

Poem Title: SECT. III.
line: among the mass of many civilized nations. In the power of abstraction

Poem Title: SECT. III.
line: and distinct introspective contemplation, it is not improbable that he

Poem Title: SECT. III.
line: was inferior to the generality of educated men in the present day. In

Poem Title: SECT. III.
line: some other lower faculties, he is probably excelled by the majority

Poem Title: SECT. III.
line: of the population of this country, nay even by many of the children

Poem Title: SECT. III.
line: in its schools. I venture to specify, as examples of the last-named

Poem Title: SECT. III.
line: proposition, the faculties of number, and of colour. It may be true of

Poem Title: SECT. III.
line: one or both of these, that a certain indistinctness in the perception

Poem Title: SECT. III.
line: of them is incidental everywhere to the early stages of society. But

Poem Title: SECT. III.
line: yet it is surprising to find it where, as with Homer, it accompanies a

Poem Title: SECT. III.
line: remarkable quickness and maturity not only of great mental powers, but

Poem Title: SECT. III.
line: of certain other perceptions more akin to number and colour, such as

Poem Title: SECT. III.
line: those of motion, of sound, and of form. But let us proceed to examine,

Poem Title: SECT. III.
line: in the first place, the former of these two subjects.

Poem Title: SECT. III.
SECT. III.
line: It may be observed at the outset, that probably none of us are aware

Poem Title: SECT. III.
line: to how great an extent our aptitudes with respect to these matters are

Poem Title: SECT. III.
line: traditionary, and dependent therefore not upon ourselves, but upon

Poem Title: SECT. III.
line: the acquisitions made by the human race before our birth, and upon

Poem Title: SECT. III.
line: the degree in which those acquisitions have circulated, and have been

Poem Title: SECT. III.
line: as it were filtered through and through the community, so as to take

Poem Title: SECT. III.
line: their place among the elementary ideas, impressions, and habits of

Poem Title: SECT. III.
line: the population. For such parts of human knowledge, as have attained

Poem Title: SECT. III.
line: to this position, are usually gained by each successive generation

Poem Title: SECT. III.
line: through the medium of that insensible training, which begins from the

Poem Title: SECT. III.
line: very earliest infancy, and which precedes by a great interval all the

Poem Title: SECT. III.
line: systematic, and even all the conscious, processes of education. Nor am

Poem Title: SECT. III.
line: I for one prepared by any means to deny that there may be an actual

Poem Title: SECT. III.
line: ‘traducianism’ in the case: on the contrary, in full consistency with

Poem Title: SECT. III.
line: the teaching of experience, we may believe that the acquired aptitudes

Poem Title: SECT. III.
line: of one generation may become, in a greater or a less degree, the

Poem Title: SECT. III.
line: inherited and inborn aptitudes of another.

Poem Title: SECT. III.
SECT. III.
line: We must, therefore, reckon upon finding a set of marked differences in

Poem Title: SECT. III.
line: the relative degrees of advancement among different human faculties in

Poem Title: SECT. III.
line: different stages of society, which shall be simply referable to the

Poem Title: SECT. III.
line: source now pointed out, and distinct altogether from such variations

Poem Title: SECT. III.
line: as are referable to other causes. It is not difficult to admit this to

Poem Title: SECT. III.
line: be true in general: but the question, whether in the case before us

Poem Title: SECT. III.
line: it applies to number and colour, can of course only be decided by an

Poem Title: SECT. III.
line: examination of the Homeric text.

Poem Title: SECT. III.
SECT. III.
line: Yet, before we enter upon this examination, let us endeavour to throw

Poem Title: SECT. III.
line: some further light upon the general aspect of the proposition, which

Poem Title: SECT. III.
line: has just been laid down.

Poem Title: SECT. III.
SECT. III.
line: Of all visible things, colour is to our English eye the most striking.

Poem Title: SECT. III.
line: Of all ideas, as conceived by the English mind, number appears to be

Poem Title: SECT. III.
line: the most rigidly definite, so that we adopt it as a standard for

Poem Title: SECT. III.
line: reducing all other things to definiteness; as when we say that this

Poem Title: SECT. III.
line: field or this house is five, ten, or twenty times as large as that.

Poem Title: SECT. III.
line: Our merchants, and even our schoolchildren, are good calculators. So

Poem Title: SECT. III.
line: that there is a sense of something strikingly paradoxical, to us in

Poem Title: SECT. III.
line: particular, when we speak of Homer as having had only indeterminate

Poem Title: SECT. III.
line: ideas of these subjects.

Poem Title: SECT. III.
SECT. III.
line: ~_Conceptions of Number not always definite._~

Poem Title: SECT. III.
SECT. III.
line: There are however two practical instances, which may be cited to

Poem Title: SECT. III.
line: illustrate the position, that number is not a thing to be as matter

Poem Title: SECT. III.
line: of course definitely conceived in the mind. One of these is the case

Poem Title: SECT. III.
line: of very young children. To them the very lowest numbers are soon

Poem Title: SECT. III.
line: intelligible, but all beyond the lowest are not so, and only present

Poem Title: SECT. III.
line: a vague sense of multitude, that cannot be severed into its component

Poem Title: SECT. III.
line: parts. The distinctive mark of a clear arithmetical conception is, that

Poem Title: SECT. III.
line: the mind at one and the same time embraces the two ideas, first of the

Poem Title: SECT. III.
line: aggregate, secondly of each one of the units which make it up. This

Poem Title: SECT. III.
line: double operation of the brain becomes more arduous, as we ascend higher

Poem Title: SECT. III.
line: in the scale. I have heard a child, put to count beads or something of

Poem Title: SECT. III.
line: the sort, reckon them thus: ‘One, two, three, four, a hundred.’ The

Poem Title: SECT. III.
line: first words express his ideas, the last one his despair. Up to four,

Poem Title: SECT. III.
line: his mind could contain the joint ideas of unity and of severalty, but

Poem Title: SECT. III.
line: not beyond; so he then passed to an expression wholly general, and

Poem Title: SECT. III.
line: meant to express a sense like that of the word multitude.

Poem Title: SECT. III.
SECT. III.
line: But though the transition from number definitely conceived to number

Poem Title: SECT. III.
line: without bounds is like launching into a sea, yet the conception of

Poem Title: SECT. III.
line: multitude itself is in one sense susceptible of degree. We may have

Poem Title: SECT. III.
line: the idea of a limited, or of an unbounded, multitude. The essential

Poem Title: SECT. III.
line: distinction of the first is, that it might possibly be counted;

Poem Title: SECT. III.
line: the notion of the second is, that it is wholly beyond the power of

Poem Title: SECT. III.
line: numeration to overtake. Probably even the child, to whom the word

Poem Title: SECT. III.
line: ‘hundred’ expressed an indefinite idea, would have been faintly

Poem Title: SECT. III.
line: sensible of a difference in degree between ‘hundred’ and ‘million,’

Poem Title: SECT. III.
line: and would have known that the latter expressed something larger

Poem Title: SECT. III.
line: than the former. The circumscribing outline of the idea apprehended

Poem Title: SECT. III.
line: is loose, but still there is such an outline. The clearness of the

Poem Title: SECT. III.
line: double conception is indeed effaced; the whole only, and not the whole

Poem Title: SECT. III.
line: together with each part, is contemplated by the mind; but still there

Poem Title: SECT. III.
line: is a certain clouded sense of a real difference in magnitude, as

Poem Title: SECT. III.
line: between one such whole and another.

Poem Title: SECT. III.
SECT. III.
line: And this leads me to the second of the two illustrations, to which

Poem Title: SECT. III.
line: reference has been made. That loss of definiteness in the conception of

Poem Title: SECT. III.
line: number, which the child in our day suffers before he has counted over

Poem Title: SECT. III.
line: his fingers, the grown man suffers also, though at a point commonly

Poem Title: SECT. III.
line: much higher in the scale. What point that may be, depends very much

Poem Title: SECT. III.
line: upon the particular habits and aptitudes of the individual. A student

Poem Title: SECT. III.
line: in a library of a thousand volumes, an officer before his regiment of a

Poem Title: SECT. III.
line: thousand men upon parade, may have a pretty clear idea of the units as

Poem Title: SECT. III.
line: well as of the totals; but when we come to a thousand times a thousand,

Poem Title: SECT. III.
line: or a thousand times a million, all view of the units, for most men,

Poem Title: SECT. III.
line: probably for every man, is lost: the million for the grown man is in

Poem Title: SECT. III.
line: a great degree like the hundred for the child. The numerical term has

Poem Title: SECT. III.
line: now become essentially a symbol; not only as every word is by its

Poem Title: SECT. III.
line: essence a symbol in reference to the idea it immediately denotes; but,

Poem Title: SECT. III.
line: in a further sense, it is a symbol of a symbol, for that idea which

Poem Title: SECT. III.
line: it denotes, is itself symbolical: it is a conventional representation

Poem Title: SECT. III.
line: of a certain vast number of units, far too great to be individually

Poem Title: SECT. III.
line: contemplated and apprehended. As we rise higher still from millions,

Poem Title: SECT. III.
line: say for example, into the class of billions, the vagueness increases.

Poem Title: SECT. III.
line: The million is now become a sort of new unit, and the relation of two

Poem Title: SECT. III.
line: millions to one million, is thus pretty clearly apprehended as being

Poem Title: SECT. III.
line: double; but this too becomes obscured as we mount, and even (for

Poem Title: SECT. III.
line: example) the relation of quantity between ten billions of wheat-corns,

Poem Title: SECT. III.
line: and an hundred billions of the same, is far less determinately conveyed

Poem Title: SECT. III.
line: to the mind, than the relation between ten wheat-corns and one. At this

Poem Title: SECT. III.
line: high level, the nouns of number approximate to the indefinite character

Poem Title: SECT. III.
line: of the class of algebraic symbols called known quantities.

Poem Title: SECT. III.
SECT. III.
line: In proportion as our conception of numbers is definite, the idea of

Poem Title: SECT. III.
line: them, instead of being suited for an address to the imagination,

Poem Title: SECT. III.
line: remains unsuited for poetic handling, and thrives within the sphere

Poem Title: SECT. III.
line: of the understanding only. But when we pass beyond the scale of

Poem Title: SECT. III.
line: determinate into that of practically indeterminate amounts, then the

Poem Title: SECT. III.
line: use of numbers becomes highly poetical. I would quote, as a very noble

Poem Title: SECT. III.
line: example of this use of number, a verse in the Revelations of St. John.

Poem Title: SECT. III.
line: ‘And I beheld, and I heard the voice of many angels round about the

Poem Title: SECT. III.
line: throne, and the beasts and the elders: and the number of them was ten

Poem Title: SECT. III.
line: thousand times ten thousand, and thousands of thousands[790].’ As a

Poem Title: SECT. III.
line: proof of the power of this fine passage, I would observe, that the

Poem Title: SECT. III.
line: descent from ten thousand times ten thousand to thousands of thousands,

Poem Title: SECT. III.
line: though it is in fact numerically very great, has none of the chilling

Poem Title: SECT. III.
line: effect of anticlimax, because these numbers are not arithmetically

Poem Title: SECT. III.
line: conceived, and the last member of the sentence is simply, so to speak,

Poem Title: SECT. III.
line: the trail of light which the former draws behind it.

Poem Title: SECT. III.
SECT. III.
SECT. III.
SECT. III.
line: Now we must keep clearly before our minds the idea, that this poetical

Poem Title: SECT. III.
line: and figurative use of number among the Greeks at least preceded what

Poem Title: SECT. III.
line: I may call its calculative use. We shall find in Homer nothing that

Poem Title: SECT. III.
line: can strictly be called calculation. He repeatedly gives us what may

Poem Title: SECT. III.
line: be termed the factors of a sum in multiplication; but he never even

Poem Title: SECT. III.
line: partially combines them, even as they are combined for example in

Poem Title: SECT. III.
line: Cowper’s ballad,

Poem Title: SECT. III.
SECT. III.
line: John Gilpin’s spouse said to her dear,

Poem Title: SECT. III.
line: Though wedded we have been

Poem Title: SECT. III.
line: These _twice ten_ tedious years, yet we

Poem Title: SECT. III.
line: No holiday have seen.

Poem Title: SECT. III.
SECT. III.
line: Reference has been made to the convenience which we find in using

Poem Title: SECT. III.
line: number as a measure of quantity, and as a means of comparing things

Poem Title: SECT. III.
line: of every species in their own kind. But we never meet with this use

Poem Title: SECT. III.
line: of it in Homer. He has not even the words necessary to enable him to

Poem Title: SECT. III.
line: say, ‘This house is five times as large as that.’ If he had the idea

Poem Title: SECT. III.
line: to express, he would say, Five houses, each as large as that, would

Poem Title: SECT. III.
line: hardly be equal to this. The word τρὶς may be called an adverb of

Poem Title: SECT. III.
line: multiplication; but it is never used for these comparisons. Indeed,

Poem Title: SECT. III.
line: Damm observes, that in a large majority of instances it signifies an

Poem Title: SECT. III.
line: indefinite number, not a precise one. Τετράκις is found only once, and

Poem Title: SECT. III.
line: in a sense wholly indeterminate: the passage is[791] τρισμάκαρες Δαναοὶ

Poem Title: SECT. III.
line: καὶ τετράκις. Πεντάκις does not even exist. Ajax lifts a stone, not

Poem Title: SECT. III.
line: ‘twice as large as a mortal of to-day could raise’, but so large that

Poem Title: SECT. III.
line: it would require two such mortals to raise it. All Homer’s numerical

Poem Title: SECT. III.
line: expressions are in the most elementary forms; such forms, as are

Poem Title: SECT. III.
line: without composition, and refuse all further analysis.

Poem Title: SECT. III.
SECT. III.
SECT. III.
SECT. III.
line: ~_Greek estimate of the discovery of Number._~

Poem Title: SECT. III.
SECT. III.
line: His use of number appears to have been confined to simple addition: and

Poem Title: SECT. III.
line: it is probable that all the higher numbers which we find in the poems,

Poem Title: SECT. III.
line: were figurative and most vaguely conceived. If we are able to make

Poem Title: SECT. III.
line: good the proof of these propositions from the Homeric text, we shall

Poem Title: SECT. III.
line: then be well able to understand the manner in which Numeration, or

Poem Title: SECT. III.
line: the science of number, is spoken of by the Greeks of the historic age

Poem Title: SECT. III.
line: as a marvellous invention. It appears in Æschylus, as among the very

Poem Title: SECT. III.
line: greatest of the discoveries of Prometheus[792]:

Poem Title: SECT. III.
SECT. III.
line: [792] Æsch. Prom. V. 468. see also Soph. Naupl. Fragm. v.

Poem Title: SECT. III.
SECT. III.
line: καὶ μὴν ἀριθμὸν, ἔξοχον σοφισμάτων,

Poem Title: SECT. III.
line: ἐξεῦρον αὐτοῖς·

Poem Title: SECT. III.
SECT. III.
line: he goes on to add,

Poem Title: SECT. III.
SECT. III.
line: γραμμάτων τε συνθέσεις.

Poem Title: SECT. III.
SECT. III.
line: So that the use of numbers by rule was to the Greek mind as much a

Poem Title: SECT. III.
line: discovery as the letters of the alphabet, and is even described here

Poem Title: SECT. III.
line: as a greater one: much as in later times men have viewed the use of

Poem Title: SECT. III.
line: logarithms, or of the method of fluxions or the calculus. In full

Poem Title: SECT. III.
line: conformity with this are the superlative terms, in which Plato speaks

Poem Title: SECT. III.
line: of number. Number, in fact, seems to be exhibited in great part of the

Poem Title: SECT. III.
line: Greek philosophy, as if it had actually been the guide of the human

Poem Title: SECT. III.
line: mind in its progress towards realizing all the great and cardinal ideas

Poem Title: SECT. III.
line: of order, measure, proportion, and relation.

Poem Title: SECT. III.
SECT. III.
line: Up to what point human intelligence, in the time of Homer, was able to

Poem Title: SECT. III.
line: push the process of simple addition, we do not precisely know. It is

Poem Title: SECT. III.
line: not, however, hastily to be assumed that, in any one of his faculties,

Poem Title: SECT. III.
line: Homer was behind his age; and it is safer to believe that the poems,

Poem Title: SECT. III.
line: even in these points, represent it advantageously. Now, in one place

Poem Title: SECT. III.
line: at least, we have a primitive account of a process of addition. The

Poem Title: SECT. III.
line: passage is in the Fourth Odyssey, where Menelaus relates, how Proteus

Poem Title: SECT. III.
line: counted upon his fingers the number of his seals[793]. That it was

Poem Title: SECT. III.
line: a certain particular number is obvious, because when four of them

Poem Title: SECT. III.
line: had been killed by Eidothee, their skins were put upon Menelaus and

Poem Title: SECT. III.
line: his three comrades, and the four Greeks were then counted into the

Poem Title: SECT. III.
line: herd, so that the word ἀριθμὸς here evidently means a definite total.

Poem Title: SECT. III.
line: This addition by Proteus, however, was not addition in the proper

Poem Title: SECT. III.
line: arithmetical sense, and would be more properly called enumeration: it

Poem Title: SECT. III.
line: was probably effected simply by adding each unit singly, in succession,

Poem Title: SECT. III.
line: to the others, with the aid of the fingers, (proved through the word

Poem Title: SECT. III.
line: πεμπάσσεται,) but not by the aid of any scale or combination of units,

Poem Title: SECT. III.
line: either decimal or quinal. In the word δεκὰς we have, indeed, the first

Poem Title: SECT. III.
line: step towards a decimal scale; but we have not even that in the case

Poem Title: SECT. III.
line: of the number five, there being no πεντὰς or πεμπτάς. The meaning of

Poem Title: SECT. III.
line: πεμπάσσεται evidently is, not that he arranged the numeration in fives,

Poem Title: SECT. III.
line: but that, by means of the fingers of one hand, employed upon those of

Poem Title: SECT. III.
line: the other, he assisted the process of simple enumeration.

Poem Title: SECT. III.
SECT. III.
SECT. III.
SECT. III.
line: ~_Highest numerals of the poems._~

Poem Title: SECT. III.
SECT. III.
line: Homer’s highest numeral is μύριοι. He describes the Myrmidons as being

Poem Title: SECT. III.
line: μύριοι[794], though, if we assume a mean strength of about eighty-five

Poem Title: SECT. III.
line: for their crews, the force would but little have exceeded four

Poem Title: SECT. III.
line: thousand: and at the _maximum_ of one hundred and twenty for each ship,

Poem Title: SECT. III.
line: it would only come to six thousand. Again, Homer uses the expression

Poem Title: SECT. III.
line: μύρια ᾔδη, to denote a person of instructed and accomplished mind[795].

Poem Title: SECT. III.
SECT. III.
line: [794] Il. xxiii. 29.

Poem Title: SECT. III.
SECT. III.
SECT. III.
SECT. III.
line: Next to the μύρια, the highest numerals employed in the poems are

Poem Title: SECT. III.
line: those contained in the passage where the Poet says that the howl of

Poem Title: SECT. III.
line: Mars, on being wounded by Diomed, was as loud as the shout of an army

Poem Title: SECT. III.
line: of nine thousand or ten thousand men[796]:

Poem Title: SECT. III.
SECT. III.
SECT. III.
SECT. III.
line: ὅσσον τ’ ἐννεάχιλοι ἐπίαχον ἢ δεκάχιλοι

Poem Title: SECT. III.
line: ἀνέρες ἐν πολέμῳ.

Poem Title: SECT. III.
SECT. III.
line: But it is clear that the expressions are purely poetical and

Poem Title: SECT. III.
line: figurative. For he never comes near the use of such high numbers

Poem Title: SECT. III.
line: elsewhere; and yet it obviously lay in his path to use these, and

Poem Title: SECT. III.
line: higher numbers still, when he was describing the strength of the Greek

Poem Title: SECT. III.
line: and Trojan armies.

Poem Title: SECT. III.
SECT. III.
line: The highest Homeric number, after those which have been named, is

Poem Title: SECT. III.
line: found in the three thousand horses of Erichthonius. This we must also

Poem Title: SECT. III.
line: consider poetical, because it is so far beyond the ordinary range

Poem Title: SECT. III.
line: of the poems, and in some degree likewise because of the obvious

Poem Title: SECT. III.
line: unlikelihood of his having possessed that particular number of

Poem Title: SECT. III.
line: mares[797].

Poem Title: SECT. III.
SECT. III.
SECT. III.
SECT. III.
line: Only thrice, besides the instances already quoted, does Homer use the

Poem Title: SECT. III.
line: fourth power of numbers; it is in the case of the single thousand. A

Poem Title: SECT. III.
line: thousand measures of wine were sent by Euneos as a present to Agamemnon

Poem Title: SECT. III.
line: and Menelaus. A thousand watch-fires were kindled by the Trojans on the

Poem Title: SECT. III.
line: plain. Iphidamas, having given an hundred oxen in order to obtain his

Poem Title: SECT. III.
line: wife, then promised a thousand goats and sheep out of his countless

Poem Title: SECT. III.
line: herds[798]. In all these three cases, it is more than doubtful whether

Poem Title: SECT. III.
line: the word thousand is not roughly and loosely used as a round number.

Poem Title: SECT. III.
line: The combination of the thousand sheep and goats with the hundred oxen,

Poem Title: SECT. III.
line: immediately awakens the recollection that even the Homeric hecatomb,

Poem Title: SECT. III.
line: though meaning etymologically an hundred oxen, practically meant

Poem Title: SECT. III.
line: nothing of the kind, but only what we should call a lot or batch of

Poem Title: SECT. III.
line: oxen. Again, it is so obviously improbable that the Trojans should

Poem Title: SECT. III.
line: in an hurried bivouac have lighted just a thousand fires, and placed

Poem Title: SECT. III.
line: just fifty men by each, that we may take this passage as plainly

Poem Title: SECT. III.
line: figurative, and as conveying no more than a very rude approximation, of

Poem Title: SECT. III.
line: such a kind as would be inadmissible where the practice of calculation

Poem Title: SECT. III.
line: is familiar. It is then most likely, that in the remaining one of

Poem Title: SECT. III.
line: the three passages, the Poet means only to convey that a large and

Poem Title: SECT. III.
line: liberal present of wine was sent by Euneus, as the consideration for

Poem Title: SECT. III.
line: his being allowed to trade with the army. There is certainly more of

Poem Title: SECT. III.
line: approximation to a definite use of the single thousand, than of the

Poem Title: SECT. III.
line: three, the nine, or the ten: but this difference in definiteness is

Poem Title: SECT. III.
line: in reality a main point in the evidence. Most of all does this become

Poem Title: SECT. III.
line: palpable, when we consider how strange is in itself the omission to

Poem Title: SECT. III.
line: state the numbers of the combatants on either side of this great

Poem Title: SECT. III.
line: struggle: an omission so strange, of what would be to ourselves a fact

Poem Title: SECT. III.
line: of such elementary and primary interest, that we can hardly account for

Poem Title: SECT. III.
line: it otherwise than by the admission, that to the Greeks of the Homeric

Poem Title: SECT. III.

line: The word ἑκατομβὴ, without doubt, affords a striking proof of vagueness

Poem Title: SECT. III.
line: in the ideas of the heroic age with respect to number: and this

Poem Title: SECT. III.
line: vagueness extends, yet apparently in varying degrees, to the adjective

Poem Title: SECT. III.
line: ἑκατομβοῖος. I have elsewhere[801] referred to adjectives of this

Poem Title: SECT. III.
line: formation as indicative of the fact, that for those generations of

Poem Title: SECT. III.
line: mankind oxen may be said to have constituted a measure of value; and

Poem Title: SECT. III.
line: this fact certainly involves an aim at numerical exactitude. It seems,

Poem Title: SECT. III.
line: indeed, on general grounds far from improbable, that the business of

Poem Title: SECT. III.
line: exchange may have been the original guide of our race into the art, and

Poem Title: SECT. III.
line: thus into the science, of arithmetic.

SECT. III.
line: In the description of the Shield of Minerva, which had an hundred

Poem Title: SECT. III.
line: golden drops or tassels, we are told that each of them was ἑκατομβοῖος,

Poem Title: SECT. III.
line: or worth an hundred oxen. This use of the word must be regarded as

Poem Title: SECT. III.
line: strongly charged with figure. Minerva was arming to mingle among men

Poem Title: SECT. III.
line: upon the plain of Troy[802], and it is not likely, therefore, that

Poem Title: SECT. III.
line: the Poet would represent her in dimensions utterly inordinate. He

Poem Title: SECT. III.
line: judiciously reserves this license of exaggeration without bounds for

Poem Title: SECT. III.
line: scenes where he is beyond the sphere of relations properly human, as

Poem Title: SECT. III.
line: for example, the Theomachy and the Under-world. Now we may venture

Poem Title: SECT. III.
line: to take the Homeric value of an ox before Troy at half an ounce of

Poem Title: SECT. III.
line: gold. In the prizes of the wrestling match, where a tripod was worth

Poem Title: SECT. III.
line: twelve oxen, a highly skilled woman (πολλὰ δ’ ἐπίστατο ἔργα) was worth

Poem Title: SECT. III.
line: four[803]. Two ounces of gold would be a low price for such a person in

Poem Title: SECT. III.
line: almost any age. According to this computation, each drop on the Ægis of

Poem Title: SECT. III.
line: Minerva would weigh fifty ounces: the whole would weigh above 300 lbs.

Poem Title: SECT. III.
line: _avoirdupois_, and if we were to assume the purely ornamental fringe

Poem Title: SECT. III.
line: in a work of this kind to weigh one tenth part of the whole, the Ægis

Poem Title: SECT. III.
line: itself would weigh nearly a ton and a half. _Primâ facie_, this is

Poem Title: SECT. III.

Poem Title: SECT. III.

Poem Title: SECT. III.

Poem Title: SECT. III.
line: are elsewhere applied, oblige us to reject the latter solution, and

Poem Title: SECT. III.

Poem Title: SECT. III.

Poem Title: SECT. III.

Poem Title: SECT. III.

Poem Title: SECT. III.
line: that the values of the two suits were precisely as 100:9, or as 11⅑:1.

Poem Title: SECT. III.

Poem Title: SECT. III.

Poem Title: SECT. III.
line: of having no more than a merely indeterminate force.

Poem Title: SECT. III.

line: of the figurative use of number. Had the young prince been ransomed

Poem Title: SECT. III.

Poem Title: SECT. III.

SECT. III.
line: The evidence thus far, I think, tends powerfully to support the

Poem Title: SECT. III.
line: hypothesis, that there is an amount of vagueness in Homer’s general

Poem Title: SECT. III.
line: use of numbers, unless indeed as to very low ones, which cannot be

Poem Title: SECT. III.
line: explained otherwise than as metaphorical or purely poetical: and that

Poem Title: SECT. III.
line: his mind never had before it any of those processes, simple as they are

Poem Title: SECT. III.
line: to all who are familiar with them, of multiplication, subtraction, or

Poem Title: SECT. III.
line: division.

Poem Title: SECT. III.
SECT. III.
line: I admit it to be possible, that his manner of treating number may have

Poem Title: SECT. III.
line: been owing to his determination to be intelligible, and to the state of

Poem Title: SECT. III.
line: the faculties of his hearers, as much as, or even more than, his own.

Poem Title: SECT. III.
line: But to me the supposition of the infant condition even of his faculties

Poem Title: SECT. III.
line: with respect to number, though at first sight startling, approves

Poem Title: SECT. III.
line: itself on reflection as one thoroughly in conformity with analogy and

Poem Title: SECT. III.
line: nature. Indeed the experience of life may convince us that to this

Poem Title: SECT. III.
line: hour we should be mistaken, if we supposed arithmetical conceptions

Poem Title: SECT. III.
line: to be uniform in different minds; that the relations of number are

Poem Title: SECT. III.
line: faintly and imperfectly apprehended, except by either practised or else

Poem Title: SECT. III.
line: peculiarly gifted persons; and that, in short, there is nothing more

Poem Title: SECT. III.
line: mysterious than arithmetic to those who do not understand it. As one

Poem Title: SECT. III.
line: illustration of this opinion, I will cite the difficulty which most

Poem Title: SECT. III.
line: educated persons, when studying history, certainly feel in mastering

Poem Title: SECT. III.
line: its chronology; while to those who are apt at figures it is not only

Poem Title: SECT. III.
line: acquired with ease, but it even serves as the _nexus_ and support of

Poem Title: SECT. III.
line: the whole chain of events.

SECT. III.
line: There were several occasions, upon which it would have been most

Poem Title: SECT. III.
line: natural and appropriate for Homer to use the faculty of multiplication;

Poem Title: SECT. III.
line: yet on no one of these has he used it. He constantly supplies us with

Poem Title: SECT. III.
line: the materials of a sum, but never once performs the process.

line: The first example in the Iliad is supplied by that passage of the

Poem Title: SECT. III.
line: unhappy speech of Agamemnon to the Assembly in the Second Book, which

Poem Title: SECT. III.
line: causes the fever-fit of home-sickness. He compares the strength of

Poem Title: SECT. III.
line: the Greek army with that of the Trojans; and he only effects the

Poem Title: SECT. III.
line: purpose by this feeble but elaborate contrivance. ‘Should the Greeks

Poem Title: SECT. III.
line: and Trojans agree to be numbered respectively, and should the Trojans

Poem Title: SECT. III.
line: properly so called be placed one by one, but the Greeks in tens, and

Poem Title: SECT. III.
line: every Trojan made cupbearer to a Greek ten, many of our tens would be

Poem Title: SECT. III.
line: without a cupbearer[807].’ In the first place, the fact that he calls

Poem Title: SECT. III.
line: this ascertaining of comparative force numbering ἀριθμηθημέναι is

Poem Title: SECT. III.
line: remarkable; for it would not have shown the numbers of either army; nor

Poem Title: SECT. III.
line: even the difference, by which the Greeks exceeded a tenfold ratio to

Poem Title: SECT. III.
line: the Trojans; but simply, by leaving an unexhausted residue, the fact

Poem Title: SECT. III.
line: that they were more, whether by much or by little, than ten times as

Poem Title: SECT. III.
line: many as the besieged. Secondly, it seems plain that, if Homer had known

Poem Title: SECT. III.
line: what was meant by multiplication, he would have used the process in

Poem Title: SECT. III.
line: this instance, in lieu of the elaborate (yet poetical) circumlocution

Poem Title: SECT. III.
line: which he has adopted; and would have said the Greeks were ten times,

Poem Title: SECT. III.
line: or fifteen times, or twenty times, as many as the inhabitants of Troy.

Poem Title: SECT. III.
line: dragon they had seen at Aulis. The phrase χθιζά τε καὶ πρώιζα, which he

Poem Title: SECT. III.
line: employs, may grammatically either belong to the epoch of the gathering

Poem Title: SECT. III.
line: at Aulis, or to the time of the plague, which had carried off a part of

Poem Title: SECT. III.
line: the force a fortnight or three weeks before. In whichever connection of

Poem Title: SECT. III.
line: the two we place it, it affords an instance of extreme indefiniteness

Poem Title: SECT. III.

Poem Title: SECT. III.
line: of number; for on one supposition he must use them to express whole

Poem Title: SECT. III.

Poem Title: SECT. III.

SECT. III.
line: The next case is remarkable. It is that of the Catalogue.

Poem Title: SECT. III.
SECT. III.
line: The resolution, which introduces it, was not a resolution to number the

Poem Title: SECT. III.
line: host; but simply to make a careful division and distribution of the men

Poem Title: SECT. III.
line: under their leaders, with a view to a more effective responsibility,

Poem Title: SECT. III.
line: both of officers and men[808]. But when the Poet comes to enumerate the

Poem Title: SECT. III.
line: divisions, it is evidently a great object with him to make known the

Poem Title: SECT. III.
line: relative forces, and thus the relative prominence and power, of the

Poem Title: SECT. III.
line: different States of Greece. Yet nothing can be more imperfect than the

Poem Title: SECT. III.
line: manner in which the enumerating portion of his task is executed. In the

Poem Title: SECT. III.
line: first place, we trace again the old habit of the loose and figurative

Poem Title: SECT. III.
line: use of numbers. For Homer could hardly mean us to take literally all

Poem Title: SECT. III.
line: the numbers of ships, which he has stated in the Catalogue: since,

Poem Title: SECT. III.
line: in every case where they come up to or exceed twenty, they run in

Poem Title: SECT. III.
line: complete decades without odd numbers; subject to the single exception

Poem Title: SECT. III.
line: of the twenty-two ships of Gouneus. Podalirius and Machaon have thirty,

Poem Title: SECT. III.
line: the Phocians forty, Achilles fifty, Menelaus sixty, Diomed eighty,

Poem Title: SECT. III.
line: Nestor ninety, Agamemnon an hundred: the only full multiple of ten

Poem Title: SECT. III.
line: omitted being the utterly intractable ἑβδομήκοντα. But again, he gives

Poem Title: SECT. III.
line: us no effectual clue to the numbers of the crews. Each of the fifty

Poem Title: SECT. III.
line: ships of the Bœotians had one hundred and twenty men, and each of the

Poem Title: SECT. III.
line: seven ships of Philoctetes had fifty[809]. Thus he supplies us with the

Poem Title: SECT. III.
line: two factors of the sum, which would find the number of men, in each

Poem Title: SECT. III.
line: of these two cases; but in neither case does he perform the sum; and

Poem Title: SECT. III.
line: such is the uniform practice throughout the poems. For the Greek force

Poem Title: SECT. III.
line: generally, he has not even given us the factors. It has indeed been

Poem Title: SECT. III.
line: conjectured, that fifty may have been the smallest ship’s company, and

Poem Title: SECT. III.
line: one hundred and twenty the largest: but this is mere conjecture; and

Poem Title: SECT. III.
line: even if it be well founded, still we do not know whether the generality

Poem Title: SECT. III.
line: of the ships were about the mean, or nearer one or the other of the

Poem Title: SECT. III.
line: extremes. Again, it would appear probable from the Odyssey, that these

Poem Title: SECT. III.
line: numbers, of fifty and one hundred and twenty, are exclusive at least

Poem Title: SECT. III.
line: of pilots and commanders, if not also of the stewards[810] and the

Poem Title: SECT. III.
line: minor officers[811]; for the number mentioned by Alcinous[812] is

Poem Title: SECT. III.
line: fifty-two; and although he says that all were to sit down to row, the

Poem Title: SECT. III.
line: texts when compared cannot but suggest, that the number fifty was an

Poem Title: SECT. III.
line: usual complement of oars, and that the two were the captain and pilot

Poem Title: SECT. III.
line: respectively[813].

Poem Title: SECT. III.

Poem Title: SECT. III.
line: the field[836]. The age of Achilles is, indeed, presumably somewhat

Poem Title: SECT. III.

Poem Title: SECT. III.

Poem Title: SECT. III.

line: than his illustrious father had been at its beginning. Mure has been

Poem Title: SECT. III.

Poem Title: SECT. III.

Poem Title: SECT. III.

Poem Title: SECT. III.
SECT. III.
line: For instance; while we take the three decades of years historically,

Poem Title: SECT. III.
line: we are perplexed by such questions as, How it came about that the

Poem Title: SECT. III.
line: Greeks[839] never had been mustered till nine years had passed.

Poem Title: SECT. III.

Poem Title: SECT. III.
line: in such force[840]; whereas we know that multitudes of the Greek army

Poem Title: SECT. III.
line: had died[841]; and there is no sign that any such communication with

Poem Title: SECT. III.
line: their native country took place during the course of the war, as might

Poem Title: SECT. III.
line: have sufficed to replenish their ranks. Thirdly, why the Trojans had

Poem Title: SECT. III.
line: remained so closely shut within the walls, and yet at the same time

Poem Title: SECT. III.
line: the Greeks had so seldom come near them, that Priam should not have

Poem Title: SECT. III.
line: learnt to know Agamemnon and his compeers by sight during so long a

Poem Title: SECT. III.
line: period; and this although Achilles may probably have been absent, for

Poem Title: SECT. III.
line: considerable intervals, on his predatory expeditions. Fourthly, how it

Poem Title: SECT. III.
line: came about that the great number of allies speaking various tongues,

Poem Title: SECT. III.
line: who had gathered round Priam to assist him, should, like the Greek

Poem Title: SECT. III.
line: army, not have been marshalled at an earlier time.
