line: _Homer’s Perceptions and Use of Colour._

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
SECT. IV.
line: The subject of the Homeric numbers has been discussed at considerable

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: length, on account of its connection with important questions of

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: history. That of colours may, even on its own merits, deserve a

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: careful examination. This inquiry will resemble, however, the former

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: discussion in the appearance of paradox, which the argument may seem

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: to present. Next to the idea of number, there is none perhaps more

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: definite to the modern mind generally, as well as in particular to

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: the English mind, than that of colour. That our own country has some

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: special aptitude in this respect, we may judge from the comparatively

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: advantageous position, which the British painters have always held

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: as colourists among other contemporary schools. Nothing seems more

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: readily understood and retained by very young children among us, than

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: the distinctions between the principal colours. In regard to one point,

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: the case of numbers is here reversed. There the idea becomes indefinite

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: as we ascend in the scale, here it is as we descend. Colour becomes

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: doubtful as it becomes faint, more and more clear as it is accumulated

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: and heightened. But the facility with which we discriminate colour in

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: all its marked forms, is probably the result of traditional aptitude,

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: since we seem to find, as we go far backward in human history, that the

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: faculty is less and less mature.

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
SECT. IV.
line: I am conscious that the subject, which is now before us, in reality

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: deserves a scientific investigation, which I am not capable of

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: affording to it: and also that we are, as yet, far from being able

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: to render the language of the ancients for colour into our own with

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: the confidence, which we can feel in almost every other department of

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: interpretation. My endeavours will be limited, firstly, to a collection

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: of ‘_realien_,’ or facts of the poems, in the case of Colour: and,

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: secondly, to pointing out what appears to be the basis of the ideas and

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: perceptions of Homer respecting it, and the relation of that basis to

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: the ideas of the later Greeks.

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
SECT. IV.
line: Among the signs of the immaturity which I have mentioned, the following

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: are found in the poems of Homer:

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
SECT. IV.
line: I. The paucity of his colours.

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
SECT. IV.
line: II. The use of the same word to denote not only different hues or tints

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: of the same colour, but colours which, according to us, are essentially

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: different.

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
SECT. IV.
line: III. The description of the same object under epithets of colour

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: fundamentally disagreeing one from the other.

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
SECT. IV.
line: IV. The vast predominance of the most crude and elemental forms of

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: colour, black and white, over every other, and the decided tendency to

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: treat other colours as simply intermediate modes between these extremes.

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
SECT. IV.
line: V. The slight use of colour in Homer, as compared with other elements

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: of beauty, for the purpose of poetic effect, and its absence in certain

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: cases where we might confidently expect to find it.

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
SECT. IV.
line: Each of these topics will deserve a distinct notice.

SECT. IV.
line: It at once throws us back on the prior question, what was κύανος? But

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: this question remains almost wholly undetermined[842]; so that we must

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: follow, as well as we can, the Homeric applications of the word itself,

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: together with its adjective and its compounds. These are very numerous.

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: First we have the substantive κύανος introduced in three places: in

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: each of which it evidently belongs to a combination of colours as well

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: as of substances.

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
SECT. IV.
line: [842] See note at the end of the Section.

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
SECT. IV.
line: _a._ Once it is κύανος simply. The interior wall of the hall of

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: Alcinous is covered with sheets of copper[843]; and round the top is a

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: θριγκὸς or fringe of κύανος. Od. vii. 87.

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
SECT. IV.
line: [843] Ibid.

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
SECT. IV.
line: _b._ Twice it is μέλας κύανος. On the breast-plate of Agamemnon there

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: are twenty stripes or layers of tin, twelve of gold, and ten μέλανος

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: κυάνοιο. Il. xi. 24, Also;

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
SECT. IV.
line: _c._ Upon his shield there were ten rounds of copper; and then,

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: apparently on the face of the shield within these, twenty white bosses

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: (ὄμφαλοι λευκοὶ) made of tin, if such be the meaning of κασσίτερος: in

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: the centre of all, there was one boss μέλανος κυάνοιο. Il. xi. 35.

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
SECT. IV.
line: Passing now to κυάνεος, we come next to three passages where it may

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: be questioned whether they describe colour only, or substance only, or

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: both.

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
SECT. IV.
line: _d._ Upon the breastplate of Agamemnon, which has ten layers of black

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: κύανος, there are on either side three κυάνεοι δράκοντες (Il. xi. 26).

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: These are compared to the rainbow, which, as we have already seen, is

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: described elsewhere as πορφυρεή.

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
SECT. IV.
line: _e._ On the silver-plated belt of Agamemnon there is a κυάνεος δράκων.

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
SECT. IV.
SECT. IV.
line: _f._ Around the golden vineyard on the shield of Achilles, with its

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: silver stakes, there is a fence of κασσίτερος and a trench (κάπετος)

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: described as κυανέη. Il. xviii. 564.

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
SECT. IV.
line: The other applications at once appear to have reference to colour only.

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
SECT. IV.
line: _g._ To the eyebrows of Jupiter and Juno. Il. i. 528. xv. 102. xvii.

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
SECT. IV.
SECT. IV.
line: _h._ To a dark cloud of vapour; but not to a storm-cloud. Il. xxiii.

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
SECT. IV.
SECT. IV.
line: _i._ To the hair of Hector, Il. xxii. 402; and to the beard of Ulysses,

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: when he is restored to beauty by Minerva. Od. xvi. 176. With this we

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: may compare the hyacinthine hair of Ulysses in Od. vi. 231.

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
SECT. IV.
line: _j._ To the serried masses of the Greeks: πυκιναὶ κίνυντο φάλαγγες

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: κυάνεαι. Il. iv. 281. Now this epithet must have been derived from

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: their arms, and these would probably be composed in the main of two

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: elements, not easy to combine in a common idea of colour; firstly,

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: copper, which is ruddy; and secondly, the hides of oxen upon the

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: shields and elsewhere. Homer never (except in Il. xiii. 703, and Od.

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: xiii. 32) describes these animals by any epithet of colour. In those

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: two passages they are βόε οἴνοπε. This epithet will be considered

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: presently. In the meantime, we may assume it as probable, that a dark

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: colour would predominate, and that accordingly we should so understand

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: κυάνεαι: but the leaning towards _blue_, which so often characterizes

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: the epithet, thus entirely escapes. The word is also applied to the

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: Trojan host, in Il. xvi. 66.

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
SECT. IV.
line: _k._ Thetis puts on mourning garments for Patroclus, when about to

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: appear to Achilles, Il. xxiv. 93.

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
SECT. IV.
line: κάλυμμ’ ἕλε δῖα θεάων

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: κυάνεον· τοῦ δ’ οὔτι μελάντερον ἔπλετο ἔσθος.

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
SECT. IV.
line: Here Homer is careful to inform us that the κάλυμμα, or hood and

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: mantle, was the blackest garment possible; and, since in Il. iv. 287 we

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: find that he was acquainted with pitch, we need not scruple to assume

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: that here he speaks literally, and either means a real black, which,

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: nevertheless, he also calls κυάνεον, or sees no difference between the

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: genuine black and the colour of κύανος.

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
SECT. IV.
line: _l._ When the wave of Charybdis retires, the shore appears ψάμμῳ

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: κυανέῃ. Now the colour of sea-sand, when it has just been left by the

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: wave, is a dull but also rather a light brown.

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
SECT. IV.
line: We take now the compounds.

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
SECT. IV.
line: 1. κυανοχαίτης is applied

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
SECT. IV.
line: _a._ To Neptune, e. g. Il. xv. 174.

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
SECT. IV.
line: _b._ To a mare, Il. xx. 224.

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
SECT. IV.
line: 2. κυανῶπις is applied to Amphitrite, or the sea, beating on rocks, Od.

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: xii. 60.

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
SECT. IV.
line: 3. κυανόπεζα is used for the foot of a beautiful table (Il. xi. 628).

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: Here possibly substance may be designated rather than colour. Metal at

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: the foot would give steadiness to a table.

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
SECT. IV.
line: 4. We have κυανόπρωρος and κυανοπρώρειος for the prow of a ship.

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: Evidently it is the coloured prow: for otherwise the prow would be of

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: the same hue with the rest of the ship. (Il. xv. 693, _et alibi_.) So

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: the prows of ships are called μιλτοπάρηοι, in Il. ii. 637, and Od. ix.

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: 125. Now μίλτος was red earth or ochre; and yet it seems that Homer

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: uses μιλτοπάρηος as equivalent to κυανόπρωρος. For the first epithet is

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: applied in the Catalogue to the ships led by Ulysses; and the second in

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: Od. x. 127 to the vessel in which he sailed.

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
SECT. IV.
line: The uses of this group of words thus appear to exhibit a degree of

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: indefiniteness, hardly reconcilable with the supposition that Homer

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: possessed accurate ideas of colour. There is no one colour that can

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: cover them all. The hood of Thetis is closely akin to black; the prow

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: of a ship to at least a dull red; the sand is of russet or a lightish

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: brown; the cloud a leaden grey; the hair and eyebrows are of a deep

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: but not a dull colour; the cornice in the hall of Alcinous must have

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: been in relief and contrast as compared with the copper wall, and

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: sufficiently light or clear to strike the eye at a distance, in an

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: interior lighted at night only from the ground. With perhaps this

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: exception, the word ‘dark’ will cover all the uses of κυάνεος: but dark

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: derives its force from a relation to light, and not to colour.

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
SECT. IV.
line: ~_Of φοίνιξ, πόλιος._~

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
SECT. IV.
line: 5. Φοίνιξ in Homer is clearly a word descriptive of colour: but it as

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: clearly partakes of the indefinite character attaching to the other

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: words of the class.

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
SECT. IV.
line: _a._ The blood drawn by Pandarus from Menelaus is compared to the

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: colour φοίνιξ, used for staining ivory. In this simile, the sense leans

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: to red, especially as the hue of ivory is so near to that of flesh

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: (Il. iv. 141). It is mentioned in other places, probably with the same

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: sense, as an ornamental dye.

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
SECT. IV.
line: _b._ In Il. xxiii. 454, we learn that one of the horses of Diomed was

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: φοίνιξ, with a round white mark on his forehead. Whether we render this

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: bay or chestnut, it is materially different from the red colour of

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: blood.

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
SECT. IV.
line: _c._ Φοίνιος is used for blood, Od. xviii. 96.

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
SECT. IV.
line: _d._ As is φοινὸς in Il. xvi. 159.

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
SECT. IV.
line: _e._ And φοινικόεις in Il. xxiii. 716. This word is also applied to a

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: cloak, Il. x. 133.

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
SECT. IV.
line: _f._ A dragon or serpent, borne by an eagle, is φοινήεις, apparently

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: because dappled or streaked with his own blood, Il. xii. 200-6, 218-21.

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
SECT. IV.
line: _g._ Ships are φοινικοπάρηοι, Od. xi. 123, and xxiii. 272: this word is

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: apparently synonymous with μιλτοπάρηοι.

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
SECT. IV.
line: _h._ The serpent is δάφοινος ἐπὶ νῶτα, Il. ii. 308. And we have the

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: δάφοινον δέρμα λέοντος, Il. x. 23.

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
SECT. IV.
line: On the whole, we trace here not less than three senses: that in which

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: φοίνιξ is applied to the horse, which appears to be the equivalent

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: of ξανθὸς, the more prevailing word: next, that of the tawny and

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: dull-coloured lion’s hide: then that of the brighter but yet deep

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: colour of blood, which is freely called πορφύρεος. So that φοίνιξ

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: merely renders other words, and does not at all assist to make up

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: deficiencies in the Homeric vocabulary for the expression of colour.

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
SECT. IV.
line: Considered as an epithet of colour, the word δάφοινος, meaning

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: blood-red, is inappropriate to the dragon or serpent, and further

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: serves to illustrate that vagueness, of which the signs multiply as we

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: proceed.

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
SECT. IV.
line: 6. πόλιος is applied in Homer as follows:

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
SECT. IV.
line: _a._ To human hair in connection with old age, Il. xxii. 74 _et alibi_.

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
SECT. IV.
line: _b._ To the sea, Il. i. 350 _et passim_. It remains to inquire, whether

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: this refers to the sea, or to the foam upon it.

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
SECT. IV.
line: _c._ To iron, Il. ix. 366. xx. 261. Od. xxi. 3, 81. xxiv. 167.

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
SECT. IV.
line: _d._ To the hide of a wolf, which Dolon put on for his nocturnal

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: expedition, Il. x. 334. The meaning of the word here appears to be not

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: ‘gray’ but ‘white.’ It is Homer’s evident intention to exhibit Dolon as

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: a sort of simpleton[844] (x. 316, 17); and accordingly he takes a white

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: covering, which makes him visible to the eye by night, so that Ulysses

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: saw him (φράσατο, 339).

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
SECT. IV.
line: [844] The celebrated Hunter noticed that Homer had made Dolon an

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: only son with five sisters, as a proof of the Poet’s sagacity in

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: observation: having himself found, that youths under such circumstances

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: are generally more or less effeminate. I owe this information to one of

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: the most distinguished living members of the profession, which Hunter

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: himself adorned. It was also a favourite remark, I believe, with Mr.

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: Rogers.

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
SECT. IV.
line: The last, then, of these four uses is _white_. The first clearly

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: inclines to the same idea. The second might bear either of two senses.

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: But iron cannot be brought nearer to white, even if we assume it to

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: be always polished, than a bluish grey; which, in truth, is somewhat

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: distant from white. It will, moreover, be seen, that Homer also

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: describes iron as αἴθων, and as ἰόεις.

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
SECT. IV.
line: ~_The quasi-adjectives of colour._~

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
SECT. IV.
line: I now come to the class of words, in dealing with which it will be

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: shown that they have not in general even the pretensions of those that

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: have preceded to be treated as adjectives of definite colour.

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
SECT. IV.
line: 7. χλωρὸς is used in Homer,

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
SECT. IV.
line: _a._ Chiefly in a metaphorical sense, as directly descriptive of fear.

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
SECT. IV.
line: _b._ For the paleness of the face derived from fear, as in χλωροὶ ὑπαὶ

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: δείους, Il. x. 376 and xv. 4. This use discloses to us the basis of the

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: last-named metaphor.

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
SECT. IV.
line: _c._ For twigs, apparently when fresh-pulled by Eumæus to make a bed

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: for Ulysses, who was an unexpected guest; Od. xvi. 47.

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
SECT. IV.
line: _d._ For honey, Il. xi. 630: where it must mean either pale, or fresh.

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
SECT. IV.
line: _e._ For the olive-wood club of the Cyclops in Od. ix. 320, 379. Here,

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: for the first time, we find the word applied to an object that might

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: perhaps be called green. But still there are two observations to be

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: made. First, even the leaf of the olive is rather grey than green:

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: and this is the bark, not the leaf, which is yet more grey, and yet

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: less green. Secondly, the governing idea is not the greenness, but the

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: newness: for Ulysses says that he heated it in the ashes until it was

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: about to take fire, χλωρός περ ἐών; although freshly cut, and still

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: seething with the sap.

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
SECT. IV.
line: _f._ The derivative χλωρηῒς is applied to the nightingale in Od. xix.

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: 518, as a lover of the woods: and here the idea of greenness seems to

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: be rather less faintly indicated.

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
SECT. IV.
line: Upon the whole, then, χλωρὸς indicates rather the absence than the

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: presence of definite colour, although it is derived from χλοὴ, meaning

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: young herbage. If regarded as an epithet of colour, it involves at

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: once an hopeless contradiction between the colour of honey on the one

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: side, and greenness on the other. Again, the more we assume it to mean

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: green, the more startling it becomes that it could have taken paleness,

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: as is manifestly the case, for its governing idea. Next to paleness,

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: it serves chiefly for freshness, i. e. as opposed to what is stale or

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: withered: a singular combination with the former sense. The idea of

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: green we scarcely find, unless once, connected with this word in the

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: poems of Homer: and yet it is a remarkable fact that there is no other

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: word in the poems that can even be supposed to represent a colour,

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: which, not the rainbow only, but every day nature, presents so largely

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: to the eye.

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
SECT. IV.
line: 8. I take next the word αἰθαλόεις. The Homeric sense of this word seems

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: somewhat to resemble that of κυάνεος; although there is the difference

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: between them, that the derivation here is from αἰθάλη, soot.

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
SECT. IV.
line: This epithet is applied by Homer, in sufficient conformity, as is

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: contended, with the idea of soot,

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
SECT. IV.
line: _a._ To the interior of the palace of Ulysses, Od. xxii. 239, and to

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: that of Priam, Il. ii. 415. In the latter case the word will, as it

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: appears from the context, bear to be construed with reference to the

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: state of a house blackened by a conflagration.

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
SECT. IV.
line: _b._ To the dark ash κόνις αἰθαλόεσσα, which Achilles poured over his

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: head, Il. xviii. 23, and which, in ver. 25, is called μέλαινα τέφρη:

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: this material Laertes also used for the same purpose in Od. xxiv. 315.

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: Yet the propriety of the second of these two applications depends,

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: first, upon the rather hardy supposition, that both Achilles and

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: Laertes had by them, at the moment of their sorrow, the remains of a

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: wood-fire; and, secondly, upon the assumption that the word κόνις may

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: mean fire-ashes as well as dust in general. But we may doubt both of

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: these assumptions; while, if κόνις means ‘dust,’ and αἰθαλόεις ‘sooty,’

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: it becomes plain that this epithet is used, like others, with very

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: great latitude.

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
SECT. IV.
line: 9. It may be admitted that, at a first view, the words ῥοδόεις and

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: ῥοδοδάκτυλος would appear to be in the strictest sense epithets of

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: colour. But it still would seem that they add nothing to Homer’s

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: defective means of expressing it: and not only so, but, in fact, scanty

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: as is their use, it is so little congruous, that we are driven to

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: suppose he must have employed these words in a sense not only elastic,

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: but altogether indeterminate and purely figurative.

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
SECT. IV.
line: Ῥοδοδάκτυλος, or rosy-fingered, has become, through Homer’s example and

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: authority, a classical epithet for the morning. It is, however, more

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: open to criticism than is usually the case with the Homeric epithets.

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: There is nothing strange in personifying Morn, in order to embellish

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: her with an epithet belonging to personal beauty; but redness, applied

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: to the fingers, and not merely to their tips, is more than equivocal in

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: this respect, since that colour is only even admissible in the interior

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: of the hand, which is the part not seen, and therefore presumably the

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: part not intended in ῥοδοδάκτυλος.

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
SECT. IV.
line: There are certain very fugitive tints of the sky, which approach to the

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: hue of the rose: but if Homer had the colour of that flower definitely

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: in his view, it is most singular that he should never use it, either

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: for the human form or otherwise, except on this and one other occasion

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: only.

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
SECT. IV.
line: The nature of that other occasion is yet more strange. Hector’s corpse

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: is anointed, in Il. xxiii. 186, with rosy oil, ῥοδόεντι ἐλαίῳ. It does

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: not appear allowable to follow Damm in rendering this as oil _made

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: from_ roses: for we have no such thing as ἔλαιον in Homer, except from

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: the olive-tree. It therefore applies to the hue of olive oil: and no

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: conceivable use of an epithet could be more conclusive to show an

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: extreme vagueness in the Poet’s ideas of colour, as well as probably in

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: those of his age.

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
SECT. IV.
line: 10. The violet, no less than the rose, has supplied Homer with

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: epithets, which he has used in such a manner as to deprive them of all

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: specific force as vehicles for the expression of a peculiar colour.

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
SECT. IV.
line: There is certainly a great temptation, when we find in Homer the

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: ἰοειδέα πόντον, to give him credit for the full meaning of this very

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: beautiful epithet, which he uses thrice for the sea (Il. ix. 298, Od.

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: v. 55, xi. 106), and never in any other connection. But when we examine

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: his employment of cognate words, it is obvious that he can mean little

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: more by the epithet, than to convey a rather vague idea of darkness.

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
SECT. IV.
line: For he uses ἰόεις as an epithet for iron (Il. xxiii. 850): and

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: ἰοδνεφὴς, first for the wool (Od. iv. 135) with which Helen is

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: spinning. Here we might be tempted to presume a purple dye. Yet it

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: would be a somewhat strained supposition: for what title have we to say

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: that dyeing was in use among the Greeks of the Homeric age? Do we hear

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: of any dye except that of the φοίνιξ, a name which tends to indicate

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: a foreign character? And does not the introduction of the Mæonian

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: or Carian woman in the simile of Il. iv. 141, to stain the ivory--a

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: most simple example of the art, or scarcely an example at all--afford

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: a strong presumption, that the art was foreign to Greece? Such is

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: apparently the true inference: but, if it be the true one, then we at

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: once lose the specific force of purple for all the mantles, carpets,

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: and the like, in the poems; and we are only entitled to presume them to

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: have been woven of a dark wool.

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
SECT. IV.
line: This construction is supported by the second and only other passage,

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: in which Homer has used the word ἰοδνεφής. For here (Od. ix. 426) he

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: speaks of the living sheep of Polyphemus as

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
SECT. IV.
line: καλοί τε μεγάλοι τε, ἰοδνεφὲς εἶρος ἔχοντες.

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
SECT. IV.
line: This passage appears evidently to apply to what we term black sheep,

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: which are more strictly of a dark brown. So viewed, it affords another

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: most striking token of the indeterminateness of Homeric colours, that

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: the name of the violet can be employed with such a signification. And

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: it also seems to carry forward the proof that the πορφύρεαι χλαῖναι,

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: the ῥήγεα, and all other woven objects with that epithet annexed, were

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: in reality either black or brown.

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
SECT. IV.
line: 11. Homer employs the word οἴνοψ with evident relation to colour; but

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: it is for two objects only, viz.

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
SECT. IV.
line: _a._ For oxen, in Il. xiii. 703, and Od. xiii. 32.

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
SECT. IV.
line: _b._ For the sea, without reference to any peculiar state of it, in

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: Il. i. 350, _et alibi_.

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
SECT. IV.
line: There is no small difficulty in combining these two uses by reference

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: to the idea of a common colour. The sea is blue, grey, or green. Oxen

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: are black, bay, or brown. I do not refer to their lighter colours,

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: which are excluded by the nature of the epithet. It is remarkable that,

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: among colours properly so called, Homer has none whatever, derived from

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: the name of an object, that are light, unless it be in the case of

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: the rose. The violet, the unknown κύανος, the φοίνιξ, the αἰθαλὴ, the

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: ἁλιπόρφυρος, the πορφύρη, whatever else they may be, are all dark. And

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: to this class οἴνοψ evidently belongs.

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
SECT. IV.
line: Wine is mentioned by Homer in nearly one hundred and forty places:

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: in the majority of them it has an epithet: but only ten times is it

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: described by an epithet of colour. Of these two are used for it,

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: ἐρυθρὸς and μέλας; so that he plainly conceived of it as dark, but

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: probably without a determinate hue. He more frequently calls it αἴθοψ:

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: but this word, which fluctuates between the ideas of flame and smoke,

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: either means tawny, or else refers to light, and not to colour, and

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: bears the sense of sparkling.

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
SECT. IV.
line: Thus then οἴνοψ, like so many other words that we have gone through,

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: vaguely indicates a dark hue, but cannot be referred to any one of the

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: known principal colours.

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
SECT. IV.
line: 12. The word μιλτοπάρηος has already been disposed of in connection

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: with κυάνεος and φοίνιξ.

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
SECT. IV.
line: 13. αἴθων is applied in Homer

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
SECT. IV.
line: _a._ to horses, as in Il. ii. 839; viii. 185.

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
SECT. IV.
line: _b._ to iron, as in Od. i. 184.

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
SECT. IV.
line: _c._ to a lion, as in Il. x. 23.

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
SECT. IV.
line: _d._ to copper utensils, as in Il. ix. 123; xxiv. 233.

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
SECT. IV.
line: _e._ to a bull, Il. xvi. 488; and to oxen, Od. xviii. 371.

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
SECT. IV.
line: _f._ to an eagle, Il. xv. 690.

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
SECT. IV.
line: With this word we may take its compound αἴθοψ. It is used

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
SECT. IV.
line: _a._ for wine, as we have seen.

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
SECT. IV.
line: _b._ for copper, Il. iv. 495 _et alibi_.

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
SECT. IV.
line: _c._ for smoke, Od. x. 152.

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
SECT. IV.
line: We have also the Αἰθίοπες, men of the tawny or swarthy countenance,

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: beneath the Southern sun.

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
SECT. IV.
line: In what manner are we to find a common thread upon which to hang the

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: colours of iron, copper, horses, lions, bulls, eagles, wine, swarthy

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: men, and smoke? We must here again adopt the vague word ‘dark,’ a word

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: of light and not of colour, for the purpose. But as the idea of αἴθω

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: includes flame struggling with smoke, so there may be a flash of light

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: upon the dark object. Ψολόεις, sooty or smutty, belongs to the same

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: group with αἰθαλόεις and αἴθων, and need not, therefore, be separately

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: discussed.

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
SECT. IV.
line: All the remainder of the words noted for examination are to be dealt

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: with in two groups, each referable to a single idea: the first that of

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: motion, and the second that of light.

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
SECT. IV.
line: 14, 15. Among adjectives of motion, which have sometimes been

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: improperly treated as adjectives of colour, are ἄργος and αἴολος.

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: The former acquires an affinity to _white_, because it may signify

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: an object which, from being rapidly moved, assumes in the light the

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: appearance of whiteness[845], and along with it may be placed its

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: derivatives ἀργεννὸς, ἀργεστὴς, ἀργὴς, ἀργινόεις, ἀργιόδους, ἀργίπους,

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: and ἀργικέραυνος. The latter, as in αἴολος ὄφις, αἴολος ἵππος,

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: κορυθαίολος, πόδας αἴολος, seems to mean whatever from the same cause

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: appears to shift its hues.

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
SECT. IV.
line: [845] See Achæis, or Ethnology, p. 383.

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
SECT. IV.
line: 16. Of those adjectives of light in Homer, which have also been taken

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: for adjectives of colour, the most important is γλαυκός. Its uses,

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: however, are only as follows:

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
SECT. IV.
line: _a._ γλαυκὴ θάλασσα, Il. xvi. 34.

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
SECT. IV.
line: _b._ Γλαυκῶπις, the standing epithet, and even a proper name, of

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: Minerva, Il. viii. 406.

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
SECT. IV.
line: _c._ γλαυκιόων; applied to the eye of a lion, when, reaching the height

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: of his wrath, he makes his rush at the hunters, Il. xx. 172.

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
SECT. IV.
line: The last of these passages seems effectually to fix the sense of the

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: term. The word γλαυκιόων describes a progression. The lion does not

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: enhance the colour of his eye as he waxes angry. If, for example,

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: γλαυκὸς can be taken as blue, it certainly does not become more blue:

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: on the contrary, rage, when kindling fire in the eye, rather subdues

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: its peculiar tint by flooding it with a vivid light. So the word

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: seems clearly to refer to the brightening flash of the eye under the

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: influence of passion. Of light and its movement, as also of sound,

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: and of beautiful form, Homer’s conceptions are even more distinct

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: and lively, than those of colour are, if not dull, yet at least

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: indeterminate.

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
SECT. IV.
line: Γλαυκὸς is derived from γλαύσσω; and has for its root λάω, to see. The

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: meaning of bright or flashing will suit the sea, as well as the epithet

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: blue. And it suits Minerva far better. ‘Blue-eyed’ would be for her but

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: a tame epithet. The luminous eye, on the contrary, entirely accords

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: with her character, and belongs to a marked trait of those primitive

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: traditions, which she appears to represent[846].

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
SECT. IV.
line: [846] See Olympus, sect. ii. p. 53. Welcker (_Griechische Götterlehre_,

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: vi. 63, p. 300) treats the name Ἀθήνη as immediately akin to αἰθὴρ and

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: the idea of light.

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
SECT. IV.
line: 17. Χάροπος is applied to the lion in Od. xi. 611; and it is the

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: proper name of the father of Nireus in the Catalogue, while his mother

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: is Ἀγλαΐη. From this latter use we see that χάροπος is not in Homer

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: an epithet of colour; since he never describes the face by means of

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: colour. Its etymology refers us to gladsomeness; and this is much more

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: connected, in the Poet’s mind, with light than with colour.

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
SECT. IV.
line: 18, 19. Besides these we have

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
SECT. IV.
line: σιγαλόεις, glossy, like σίαλος, or fat; and μαρμάρεος, applied

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
SECT. IV.
line: _a._ to a web, Il. iii. 126.

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
SECT. IV.
line: _b._ to the Ægis, Il. xvii. 594.

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
SECT. IV.
line: _c._ to the sea, Il. xiv. 273.

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
SECT. IV.
line: _d._ to the rim of the Shield, Il. xviii. 480.

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
SECT. IV.
line: We have also the μαρμαρυγαὶ ποδῶν (Od. viii. 265), or twinkling of the

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: feet in the dance: and the verb μαρμαίρω is applied to the eyes of

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: Venus (Il. iii. 397), to arms (Il. xii. 195 _et alibi_), and to the

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: golden palace of Neptune (Il. xiii. 22). The marble, from which the

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: words are derived, was white: but that signification would not suit any

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: of the uses of the words, except the web of Helen. The sense, that will

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: suit them, is one derived from the idea of light, that of glittering or

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: sparkling.

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
SECT. IV.
line: Lastly: ἠεροειδὴς (Il. v. 770; Od. xiii. 103) is so evidently an

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: atmospheric epithet only, that it requires no detailed discussion. It

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: is worthy of note, as it indicates the idea of atmospheric transparency.

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
SECT. IV.
line: ~_Conflict of colours in the same object._~

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
SECT. IV.
line: III. We might have attained to some nearly similar results, by taking

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: the names of substantives in Homer, and considering the differences in

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: the epithets of colour by which he describes them.

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
SECT. IV.
line: Thus, for example, iron is violet, grey, and αἴθων or tawny. There is

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: a certain opposition between the first and second: a very marked one

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: between the second and third. When considered as names of colour, they

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: cannot be reconciled, but they may perhaps be made in some degree to

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: harmonize by introducing the element of light. Iron is dark or tawny if

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: in the shade: while under light it may appear grey.

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
SECT. IV.
line: Again, the dragon, or serpent, which is δάφοινος in Il. ii. 308, is

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: also κυάνεος in Il. xi. 26; and is compared to the rainbow, which is

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: πορφυρέη in Il. xvii. Δάφοινος, being applied to the lion’s hide in

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: Il. x. 23, is essentially of a dull colour, but the rainbow is as

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: essentially bright. Here, again, the only mode of harmonizing is by

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: the supposition that Homer really regulates the use of those epithets

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: according to light; and thus the same object may be dull and bright in

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: different positions.

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
SECT. IV.
line: Again, κέραυνος is in composition white (ἀργικέραυνος): but it is also

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: ψολοεὶς, smutty. In truth it is neither: but its near connection both

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: with light and with darkness will admit of its being referred to either.

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
SECT. IV.
line: ~_Great predominance of white and black._~

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
SECT. IV.
line: IV. I have next to notice the vast predominance in Homer of the two

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: simple opposites, white and black, which may be called, perhaps, the

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: elemental forms of colour: white being the compound of the seven

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: prismatic colours in their natural proportions, and black the absence,

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: or simple negative, of them all.

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
SECT. IV.
line: The adjective μέλας, or ‘black,’ is used, in its different degrees,

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: cases, and numbers, about one hundred and seventy times. Besides this,

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: we have the verb μελαίνω, and several compounds from the adjective. It

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: also forms a very frequent element in proper names.

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
SECT. IV.
line: The word λευκὸς, or ‘white,’ is used nearly sixty times: its compound

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: λευκώλενος forty more, but almost all of these as the stock-epithet

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: of Juno, which should not be taken into the account. We have also

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: λευκαίνω, λεύκασπις, and some proper names. But this by no means

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: exhausts Homer’s means of expressing whiteness. For that purpose he

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: also uses μαρμάρεος, σιγαλόεις, perhaps πόλιος, and an extensive group

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: of words having ἀργὸς for its centre. In all, whiteness, or something

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: intended for it, may perhaps be thus expressed one hundred times or

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: more.

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
SECT. IV.
line: Now assuming for the moment that adjectives of colour, in the prismatic

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: sense of the word, are found in Homer, still it is remarkable how

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: rarely they are found, in comparison with whiteness and blackness.

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
SECT. IV.
line: For example: except as a proper name, and as the stock-epithet of

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: Menelaus, ξανθὸς is, I think, hardly found ten times in Homer.

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: Ἰόεις, and its cognate words, come but six times: ῥοδόεις is an ἅπαξ

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: λεγόμενον: μίλτος is only introduced in its compound twice; yet it

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: is probably the best _red_ in Homer: ἐρυθρὸς and ἐρυθαίνω come but

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: thirteen times: πορφύρεος and the kindred words are found in all

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: twenty-three times; but it has, I think, been shown that this word was

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: wanting, with Homer, in the ingredient of specific colour, and only

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: implied what was dark, whether brown, crimson, purple, or even black.

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
SECT. IV.
line: ~_Omissions to specify colour._~

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
SECT. IV.
line: V. It remains to complete this circle of evidence, by adducing cases

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: where Homer’s omission to name colour, or to describe by means of it,

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: is deserving of remark.

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
SECT. IV.
line: 1. Homer’s similes are so rich in the use of all sensible imagery,

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: that we might have expected to find colour a frequent and prominent

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: ingredient in them. But it is not so. They turn chiefly, I think, upon

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: the following ideas:

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
SECT. IV.
line: 1. Motion.

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: 2. Force.

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: 3. Form.

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: 4. Sound.

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: 5. Symmetry.

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: 6. Number.

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: 7. Light and Darkness.

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: 8. Very rarely, upon Colour.

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
SECT. IV.
line: In the greater part of them colour is not even mentioned. I have seen

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: the similes of the poems reckoned at two hundred: and I have found it

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: difficult to note more than three which turn upon colour, even when it

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: is vaguely conceived.

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
SECT. IV.
line: The first is the blood of Menelaus, compared to a crimson dye, on the

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: cheek-piece of a horse, Il. iv. 141.

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
SECT. IV.
line: The second, the meditations of Nestor, likened to the darkening of the

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: sea before a storm, Il. xiv. 16-22.

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
SECT. IV.
line: Thirdly, the cloud in which Minerva is wrapped is compared to the

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: rainbow, Il. xvii. 547-52.

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
SECT. IV.
line: Of these the second is very indefinite: the idea of the first, as we

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: have seen, was inaccurately and loosely conceived: and the third is one

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: of the most striking proofs of the want of a close discrimination of

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: colours in Homer.

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
SECT. IV.
line: Yet here again we may find life and beauty in the passage, if only

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: we construe it of a cloud illuminated by the rays falling on it.

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: Indeed, generally the element of light brings us back to Homer’s usual

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: definiteness, when his use of colour makes him obscure.

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
SECT. IV.
line: 2. Again, in the numerous and very exact epithets by which the Poet has

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: described the form and appearance of different countries, we scarcely

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: find any epithet of colour. Out of about sixty of these epithets in the

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: Greek Catalogue, there are but three that refer to colour, and these

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: all mention whiteness only (ἀργινόεις, Il. ii. 647, 656, and λευκός,

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: ibid. 735).

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
SECT. IV.
line: ~_In the case of the horse._~

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
SECT. IV.
line: 3. It is most singular that, though Homer so loved the horse that he

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: is never weary of using him with his whole heart for the purposes of

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: poetry, yet in all his animated and beautiful descriptions of this

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: animal, colour should be so little prominent. It is said, indeed, that

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: Homer tells us the horses of Eumelus corresponded in colour (ὅτριχες

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: Il. ii. 765); but what the colour was we know not; and the question may

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: also be raised, whether the epithet employed does not more properly

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: indicate similarity in the fineness of their coat. Perhaps the only

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: cases, where colour is distinctly assigned to horses, are the following

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: two:

Poem Title: SECT. IV.

Poem Title: SECT. IV.

Poem Title: SECT. IV.

Poem Title: SECT. IV.

Poem Title: SECT. IV.

Poem Title: SECT. IV.

Poem Title: SECT. IV.

SECT. IV.
line: 4. It is not, however, the case of the horse alone, on which an

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: argument may be founded. Homer abounds with notices of other animals,

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: both domesticated and wild. We have oxen, dogs, goats, hogs, and sheep.

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: None of his stock epithets for them are drawn from colour; and we have

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: seen that by his wine-coloured oxen, and his violet-coloured sheep, he,

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: in all likelihood, means no more than dark or tawny. His epithets for

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: wild animals are of the same character when they occur, and similarly

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: depend on the scale of degrees between light and darkness, not upon

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: colour. Once he mentions a white goose (Od. xv. 161); but it is borne

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: on high in the talons of an eagle, and the object evidently is to

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: create a clear visual image.

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
SECT. IV.
line: 5. I would not lay overmuch stress on the fact, that Homer never refers

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: to colour in connection with the human frame, unless as regards the

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: hair, which is either ξανθὸς or κυάνεος: expressions which, as we

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: shall see, are apparent exceptions, and not real ones. The olive hue

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: of the Mediterranean latitudes makes colour a less prominent element

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: in human beauty for a Greek climate, than it is for ours. Still its

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: almost entire exclusion is an element in the case. One instance that

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: I have noticed, which introduces it, adds to the general mass of

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: testimony. When Minerva (Od. xvi. 175) restores the beauty of Ulysses,

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: the expression is ἂψ δὲ μελαγχροιὴς γένετο. Now this certainly does not

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: mean that his flesh became black again. It can only signify that he

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: resumed the olive tint, which was associated with personal vigour and

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: beauty. So that even the μέλας of Homer means dark, and is indefinite:

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: as might indeed be shown by many other instances.

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
SECT. IV.
line: 6. Lastly, it seems to deserve remark, that there is not one single

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: epithet of Iris taken from colour. She is once, and only once,

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: χρυσόπτερος (Il. viii. 398); but this is in virtue of her office, and

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: has no relation to the rainbow; as, indeed, gold with Homer always

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: belongs to light rather than to colour. All her other epithets, without

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: exception, are taken from motion only. She is swift (ὠκέα and τάχεια),

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: swift of foot (πόδας ὠκέα), swift as the wind (ποδήνεμος), storm-footed

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: (ἀελλόπους[848]), but from colour she derives no part whatever of her

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: Homeric costume. Now though the chain of traditions which identified

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: Iris with the rainbow was broken[849], yet the traces of it were not

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: wholly lost. For Homer treated the rainbow, physically, as a prophet

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: of storm (Il. xvii. 548): and again, we find that she was still

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: tempest-footed. This epithet can only be derived from her original

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: relation to the rainbow. It is therefore highly instructive, that none

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: of her traits of colour should have been preserved.

SECT. IV.
line: Lastly, let us take the case of the sky, or the heavens. Here Homer

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: had before him the most perfect example of blue. Yet he never once so

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: describes the sky. His οὐρανὸς is starry (Il. i. 317), or broad (Il.

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: iii. 364), or great (Il. i. 497), or iron (Od. xv. 328), or copper (Od.

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: iii. 2. Il. xvii. 425); but it is never blue. This is an important

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: piece of negative testimony.

Poem Title: SECT. IV.

SECT. IV.
line: I submit that they warrant the two following propositions:

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
SECT. IV.
line: 1. That Homer’s perceptions of the prismatic colours, or colours of the

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: rainbow, which depend on the decomposition of light by refraction, and

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: _a fortiori_ of their compounds, were, as a general rule, vague and

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: indeterminate.

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
SECT. IV.
line: 2. That we must therefore seek another basis for his system of colour.

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
SECT. IV.
line: But a few words may be permitted on the cause which has led to his

Poem Title: SECT. IV.

Poem Title: SECT. IV.

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
SECT. IV.
line: Are we to suppose a defect in his organization, or in that of his

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: countrymen?

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
SECT. IV.

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: use of colour as one conceived in the spirit which, with even the most

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: perfect knowledge, would properly belong to his art?

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
SECT. IV.
line: The mere tradition of Homer’s blindness is hardly relevant. The

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: presumption of it drawn from the poems, because they make Demodocus

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: blind, is inappreciably minute. The testimony of the Hymn to Apollo is

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: ancient[850]; but, as his blindness (if he really was blind) allowed

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: of the most vivid conceptions of light, it will not account for

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: defectiveness in his conceptions of colour. The vigorous apprehension

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: and accurate description of sensible objects in the poems demonstrate,

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: that we cannot seek in this hypothesis for an explanation of what may

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: be either singular, crude, or irregular.

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: properly called a defect in his organization; when we bear in mind

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: his intense feeling for form, and when we observe his effective and

Poem Title: SECT. IV.

SECT. IV.
line: Our answer to the third question must also, I think, be in the

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: negative. It is true, indeed, that much of merely literal discrepancy

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: as to colour might be understood to appertain to the license of poetry.

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: There is high poetical effect in what may be called straining epithets

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: of colour. But it seems essential to that effect,

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
SECT. IV.
line: (1.) That the straining should be the exception, and not the rule.

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
SECT. IV.
line: (2.) That there should be a fixed standard of the colour itself, so

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: that the departures from it may be measured. Otherwise the result is

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: not license, but confusion. Shakespeare with high effect says[851],

Poem Title: SECT. IV.

line: [851] Macbeth ii. 3.

SECT. IV.
line: Here lay Duncan,

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: His silver skin laced with his golden blood.

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
SECT. IV.
line: Here the idea is not that silver is of the same colour as skin, nor

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: gold as blood; but that the relation of colour between silver and gold

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: may be compared with that between skin and blood: the skin throws the

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: blood into relief, as a ground of silver would throw out a projection

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: of gold. In license of this kind we can always trace both a rule and an

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: aim. The rule is relaxed only for the particular occasion. The effect

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: produced is that of tenderness, dignity, and purity. Had Shakespeare

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: been describing the horrible carnage of a battlefield, he probably

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: would have spoken of black or foul gore instead of using a brightening

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: figure.

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
SECT. IV.
line: Now this purpose is not traceable in Homer’s use of certain words, if

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: we are required to treat them as adjectives of colour. There is no

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: Poet, whose _rationale_ is commonly more accessible; but these cases,

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: upon such a principle, do not admit of a _rationale_ at all.

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
SECT. IV.
line: Take for instance his use of the rainbow. It is (1) πορφυρέη, and (2)

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: like a δράκων, which is κυάνεος. Of these, the first may be construed

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: dark with a hue of crimson; the second, dark with a hue of deep blue or

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: indigo. Surely we have here, viewing it as a whole, a most inadequate

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: treatment of the colours of the rainbow. Shakespeare indeed says[852],

Poem Title: SECT. IV.

line: [852] Troilus and Cressida, i. 3, _sub_ fin.

line: His crest, that prouder than blue Iris bends;

Poem Title: SECT. IV.

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
SECT. IV.
line: [853] Tempest, iv. 1. The rainbow is mentioned as of many colours, in

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: Merry Wives of Windsor, iv. 5, Winter’s Tale, iv. 3, and King John, iv.

line: And with each end of thy blue bow dost crown

Poem Title: SECT. IV.

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
SECT. IV.
line: But (1) blue differs from πορφύρεος, which is essentially dark, and

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: is not blue. (2) Blue, taken largely, represents three of the seven

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: prismatic colours: i. e. indigo and purple along with itself. (3) In

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: the last quoted passage, Iris is also called ‘many-coloured messenger,’

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: and with ‘saffron wings.’ How different an effect do these words

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: give, as they form a whole, from that of the simile in Il. xvii. In

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: what manner then are we to understand Homer? I answer, in the way

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: of metaphor; and with reference to light and dark, not to prismatic

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: colour. The δράκοντες on the buckler and belt are dark and terrible:

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: so is the storm of which Iris is the type, and it is in viewing the

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: rainbow as a type of what is awful, that we are to find the reason of

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: Homer’s simply treating it as dark, and not as a series and system of

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: colours. Perhaps we ought not to overlook the possibility that Homer

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: may also mean to compare the shifting hues of the serpent with the

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: varied appearance of the rainbow.

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
SECT. IV.
line: Again, let us take his use of μελαγχροίης. Now the question is, did

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: Homer mean by this simply to express darkness, that is to say was

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: _dark_ his idea of μέλας, or did he, with the specific idea of black

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: in his mind, use the term which denoted it poetically for the olive

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: complexion of Ulysses? Surely the former: for the latter use of it

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: would have been bad. It would have been straining the figure in the

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: wrong direction. For blackness would be a fitting trope only where the

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: object was to describe something awful or repulsive.

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
SECT. IV.
line: But beauty of form in Homer always leans to light hues and not to dark

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: ones, whence the Greeks are ξανθοὶ, and the Trojan Hector, though

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: beautiful, is κυάνεος only. Therefore it was not Homer’s object to give

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: an enhanced idea of darkness in the tints of Ulysses. And yet, if μέλας

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: for him meant specifically black, then μελαγχροίης was the height of

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: exaggeration in the wrong sense. But if by μέλας he only understood

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: dark, that was a fair description of the olive tint, as compared with

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: the withered and shrivelled skin of old age.

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
SECT. IV.
line: We have other proofs from the poems that Homer conceived of μέλας as

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: dark, and not specifically as black. The former idea accords best with

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: his calling earth μέλας, when it is fresh behind the plough (Il. xviii.

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: 548): and his calling blood μέλας, not stagnant gore, but blood fresh

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: as it comes spurting from the wound (Il. i. 303),

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
SECT. IV.
line: αἶψά τοι αἷμα κελαινὸν ἐρωήσει περὶ δουρί·

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
SECT. IV.
line: and again, the fresh blood of Venus herself: μελαίνετο δὲ χρόα καλόν

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: (Il. v. 354). It would be bad poetry to call the blood of Venus

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: _black_, for the same reasons which make it good poetry in Shakespeare

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: to call the blood of Duncan golden. So the μέλας πόντος of Il. xxiv. 79

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: is evidently no more than dark; though in vii. 64 we may properly say

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: the sea blackens.

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
SECT. IV.
line: So again with wine-coloured oxen, smutty thunder-bolts, violet-coloured

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: sheep, and many more, it is surely conclusive against taking them for

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: descriptions of prismatic colours or their compounds, that they would

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: be bad descriptions in their several kinds.

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
SECT. IV.
line: ~_Homer’s means of training in colour._~

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
SECT. IV.
line: We must then seek for the basis of Homer’s system with respect to

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: colour in something outside our own. And it may prepare us the more

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: readily to acknowledge such a basis elsewhere, if we bear in mind,

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: that many of the great elements and sources of colour for us presented

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: themselves differently to him. The olive hue of the skin kept down the

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: play of white and red. The hair tended much more uniformly, than with

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: us, to darkness. The sense of colour was less exercised by the culture

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: of flowers. The sun sooner changed the spring-greens of the earth into

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: brown. Glass, one of our instruments of instruction, did not exist. The

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: rainbow would much more rarely meet the view. The art of painting was

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: wholly, and that of dyeing was almost, unknown; and we may estimate

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: the importance of this element of the case by recollecting how much,

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: with the advance of chemistry, the taste of this country in colour has

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: improved within the last twenty years. The artificial colours, with

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: which the human eye was conversant, were chiefly the ill-defined, and

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: anything but full-bodied, tints of metals. The materials, therefore,

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: for a system of colour did not offer themselves to Homer’s vision as

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: they do to ours. Particular colours were indeed exhibited in rare

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: beauty, as the blue of the sea and of the sky. Yet these colours were,

line: I conclude, then, that the organ of colour and its impressions were but

Poem Title: SECT. IV.

Poem Title: SECT. IV.

Poem Title: SECT. IV.

Poem Title: SECT. IV.

SECT. IV.
line: As a general proposition, then, I should say that the Homeric colours

line: are really the modes and forms of light[855], and of its opposite or

Poem Title: SECT. IV.

Poem Title: SECT. IV.

Poem Title: SECT. IV.

Poem Title: SECT. IV.

SECT. IV.
line: Under the application of this principle, I believe that all, or nearly

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: all, the Homeric words will fall into their places: and that we shall

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: find that the Poet used them, from his own standing-ground, with great

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: vigour and effect. We can now see why λευκὸς and μέλας with their

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: kindred words have such an immense predominance: though white and black

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: are the limiting ratios of colour, rather than colour itself.

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
SECT. IV.
line: Of the transparent and opaque, or _chiaroscuro_, we cannot expect to

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: hear from Homer: yet, as has been observed, a rudiment of it may be

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: contained in the highly poetical ἠεροειδὲς of the cave or sea; and

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: again in the δνοφερὴ νὺξ (Od. xiii. 269), since νέφος is the basis of

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: the epithet.

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
SECT. IV.
line: When we speak of colour proper, we speak of an effect which is produced

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: by the decomposition of light, and which, so long as the eye can

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: discharge its function, is complete, whatever the quantity, or the

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: incidence, of light upon the object said to have colour may happen to

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: be.

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
SECT. IV.
line: When we speak of light, shade, and darkness, we refer to the quantity

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: of light, not decomposed, which falls upon that object, and to the mode

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: of its incidence.

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
SECT. IV.
line: Of light, shadow, and darkness thus regarded, Homer had lively and

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: most poetical conceptions. This description of objects by light and its

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: absence tax his materials to the uttermost. His iron-grey, his ruddy,

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: his starry heaven, are so many modes of light. His wine-coloured oxen

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: and sea, his violet sheep, his things tawny, purple, sooty, and the

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: rest, give us in fact a rich vocabulary of words for describing what

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: is dark so far as it has colour, but what also varies between dull and

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: bright, according to the quantity of light playing upon it. Here (for

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: example) is the link between his αἴθοψ κάπνος and his αἴθοψ οἶνος.

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
SECT. IV.
line: As these words all follow in the train, so to speak, of μέλας, even so

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: λευκὸς is attended by its own family, all falling under the meaning of

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: the English adjective _light_. On the one hand χλωρὸς and πόλιος; on

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: the other μαρμάρεος, ἀργὸς, and σιγαλόεις, all mean _light_; but the

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: first two are dull, and represent the twilight of colour, or debateable

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: ground between it and its negative, while the last three are bright and

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: glistering.

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
SECT. IV.
line: Nothing can be more poetical than Homer’s ideas of dark and light. It

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: was a redundancy of life in these ideas, that made him associate light

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: with motion; as in those fine lines (Il. ii. 437),

Poem Title: SECT. IV.

line: ὣς τῶν ἐρχομένων ἀπὸ χαλκοῦ θεσπεσίοιο

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: αἴγλη παμφανόωσα δι’ αἰθέρος οὐρανὸν ἷκεν.

Poem Title: SECT. IV.

Poem Title: SECT. IV.

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: of death, black pains (Il. ii. 859, 834. xvi. 350. iv. 117).

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
SECT. IV.
line: Naturalists tell us, that there exist kinds of creatures respecting

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: which it is known, that their organs are sensitive to light and

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: darkness, but with no perception whatever either of colour or of

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: form[856]. So far as respects form, Homer perceived keenly such forms

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: as were beautiful: but of mere geometrical form he may have had very

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: indistinct ideas, if we are to judge from his epithets for the form of

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: a shield. The parallel is nearer in the case of colour; for even his

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: perceptions were as yet undigested; as if they were novel, not aided by

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: tradition, acquired very much by himself, and fixed as yet neither by

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: custom nor nomenclature.

SECT. IV.
line: From the remains which have reached us of the colours of the ancients,

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: it has been found practicable to treat of them in precise detail[857].

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: But, in examining the question from the works of Homer, we must bear

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: in mind, first, their very early date, and, secondly, the likelihood

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: that heroic Greece may probably have been far behind some countries of

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: the east in the use and in the idea of colour, which has always had a

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: privileged home there.

line: ~_Colour in the later Greek language._~

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
SECT. IV.
line: The tendency, however, to a mixture of the two questions of light and

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: colour appears to be traceable more or less in the popular language,

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: and likewise in the philosophy, of the later Greeks.

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
SECT. IV.
line: In the classical period, the hues of the eye were divided, as μέλας the

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: darkest, χάροπος the intermediate, and γλαυκὸς the lightest.

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
SECT. IV.
line: The word πράσινος, leek-green, appears to be quite adequate to the

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: expression of the colour. It is used by Aristotle; but I do not know

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: that it is found in the poets or writers of the best age. For the

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: classical Greek the idea of greenness is expressed by χλωρὸς, as

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: far as it is expressed at all. Now this word seems inadequate on two

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: grounds. First, its predominant idea is that of ‘fresh’ or ‘recent;’

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: which is but accidentally, and not invariably, the property of those

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: objects in nature that are green.

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
SECT. IV.
line: When we find the word χλωρὸς applied alike to objects of a green

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: colour, and to others that have no colour, (or else not in respect of

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: their colour,) but yet which are fresh or newly sprung, we are led to

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: conclude that it was for freshness, and not for greenness, that the

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: word was generally used. This idea is confirmed by two circumstances.

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: First, that when χλωρὸς does signify colour, as in the case of

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: paleness, (where it cannot mean what is fresh,) it signifies the most

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: indefinite and feeble colour, little more indeed than a negative.

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
SECT. IV.
line: The meaning of χλωρὸν δεός is probably ashy-pale fear. In the green of

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: the olive we see the point of connection between this use of the term

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: on the one hand, and natural verdure on the other. So that the image of

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: the colour green, to the Greeks, was neither lively and bright on the

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: one hand, nor was it strong and deep on the other.

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
SECT. IV.
line: The second circumstance is this: that the word χλωρὸς is applied by the

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: later Greeks to objects that have a colour, but a colour which is _not_

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: green: and this by authors who had the full use of sight. Thus, in

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: Euripides, (Hecuba 124,) we have αἵματι χλωρῷ for blood freshly shed.

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: It seems plain that, when the epithet could be thus used, colour could

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: only be very carelessly and faintly conceived in the minds either of

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: those who used the expression, or of those to whom it was addressed.

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
SECT. IV.
line: I shall not open the general subject of the treatment of colour by the

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: later Greeks, or by the Latin poets. But that it continued to be both

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: faint and indefinite down to a very late period, and in a degree which

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: would now be deemed very surprising, we may judge both from the general

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: tenour of the Æneid, and from the remarkable verse of Albinovanus, an

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: Augustan poet, which applied the epithet ‘purpureus’ to snow;

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
SECT. IV.
line: Brachia purpureâ candidiora nive.

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
SECT. IV.
line: Neither do I enter into the question, whether the shadows of white

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: may afford any ground for this epithet: because an answer, drawn from

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: the secrets as it were of science or art, could not avail for the

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: interpretation of the works of a poet, who must describe for the common

Poem Title: SECT. IV.

SECT. IV.
line: The treatise Περὶ χρωμάτων, popularly ascribed to Aristotle, would

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: appear to belong to some other author. It, however, in conformity with

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: Greek ideas[860], bases the system of colour not, as we do, upon the

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: prismatic decomposition of light, but upon the four elements; of which

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: it declares air, water, and even earth when dry, to be white, fire

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: to be ξανθὸς or yellow; from the mixtures of these arise all other

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: colours, and σκότος, or black, is the absence of light.

SECT. IV.
line: Dr. Prantl, a recent editor of this Treatise, has, in a learned Essay

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: of his own, gathered together the systems of the various Greek writers

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: upon colour; and especially that of Aristotle, from the testimony

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: afforded by his _Meteorologica_ and other works. It exhibits a curious

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: combination of the aim at scientific exactness, with the want of the

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: physical knowledge which is, in such matters, its necessary basis. Its

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: leading ideas appear to be as follows.

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
SECT. IV.
line: If we pass by the mere metaphysical portion of the subject, the basis

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: of colour is laid theoretically in transparency and motion. With the

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: idea of whiteness are associated dryness and heat; and with blackness

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: their counterparts, wet and cold[861]. The air is white, fire the

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: highest form of white; water is black[862], earth the highest negation

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: of colour, and blackest of all. All other colours are treated as

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: intermediate between white and black[863]. An analogy prevails between

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: the intervals of the principal colours, and those of sound, taste

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: (χυμὸς), and other sensible objects. There are seven colours[864]:

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: namely,

SECT. IV.
line: This condition of the philosophy of colour, so many centuries after

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: Homer, and in the mind of such a man as Aristotle, may assist in

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: explaining to us the undeveloped state of Homer’s perceptions in this

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: particular department.

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
SECT. IV.
line: There appears to be a remarkable contrast between such undigested

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: ideas, and the solidity, truth, and firmness of the remains of colour

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: that have come down to us from the ancients. The explanation, I

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: suppose, is, that those, who had to make practical use of colour, did

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: not wait for the construction of a philosophy, but added to their

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: apparatus from time to time all substances which, having come within

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: their knowledge, were found to produce results satisfactory and

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: improving to the eye. And even so Homer, though his organ was little

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: trained in the discrimination of colours, and though he founded himself

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: mainly upon mere modifications of light apart from its decomposition,

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: yet has made very bold and effective use of these limited materials.

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: His figures in no case jar, while they never fail to strike. Nor are

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: we to suppose that we see in this department an exception to that

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: comparative profusion of power which marked his endowments in general,

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: and that he bore, in the particular point, a crippled nature; but

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: rather we are to learn that the perceptions so easy and familiar to

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: us are the results of a slow traditionary growth in knowledge and in

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: the training of the human organ, which commenced long before we took

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: our place in the succession of mankind. We exemplify, even in this

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: apparently simple matter, the old proverbial saying: ‘The dwarf sees

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: further than the giant, for he is lifted on the giant’s shoulders.’

Poem Title: SECT. IV.

Poem Title: SECT. IV.

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
