line: metal, or of its application to unmanufactured iron, or of a new

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: denomination for iron when thus heated and cooled. On the contrary,

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: in this passage the metal when fully hardened is still declared to be

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: σίδηρος: and we have nowhere in Homer any trace of a relation between

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: κύανος and σίδηρος, except the merely negative one, that neither of

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: them is cast into the furnace for making the Shield of Achilles.

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
SECT. IV.
line: [868] Friedreich, Realien, § 21. p. 86.

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
SECT. IV.
SECT. IV.
SECT. IV.
line: Again, the hardness of iron was such as apparently met all their

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: wishes, and almost of itself constituted a difficulty. Hence it is

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: used along with stones as a symbol of hardness; ἐπεὶ οὔ σφι λίθος

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: χρὼς ἠὲ σίδηρος[870]. Again, we do not find it worked up with other

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: metals; for example, on the buckler or shield of Agamemnon. As we

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: have seen, it is not used by Vulcan in making the shield of Achilles.

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: The god casts into the fire gold and silver, copper and tin; lead

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: being apparently excluded as too soft, and iron as too hard for

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: working in masses with the other metals. But the idea of hardness

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: is never associated with κύανος; and, if it had been hard like

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: steel, certainly it would not have been a suitable material for the

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: intricate forms of dragons.

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
SECT. IV.
SECT. IV.
SECT. IV.
line: Again, the adjective κυάνεος means in colour what is blue and what

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: is deep; and by no means corresponds with the ordinary colour of

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: steel. All this, besides the strength of the negative evidence, seems

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: inconsistent with the idea that κύανος can have been steel.

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
SECT. IV.
line: The Compiler of the Index to Eustathius makes κύανος (_in voc._)

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: simply a dark metal. But Millin argues that κύανος without an epithet

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: is tin, and that with the epithet μέλας it is lead. He observes that

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: Pliny[871] appears to call tin by the name of _plumbum_ simply, and

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: lead by the name of _plumbum nigrum_: so that the double use of

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: κύανος and κασσίτερος for tin would be like that of _plumbum_ and

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: _stannum_ for the same metal in Latin. This idea treats the substance

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: as taking its name from the colour: and is so far sustained by the

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: use of the German _blei_, which I presume is the same word as _blau_,

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: for lead. But it would be singular that Homer should thus have double

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: names for two metals, which of all classes of objects have perhaps

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: been most commonly designated by single ones. And this hypothesis

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: is not in accordance with the evident meaning of κυάνεος in Homer;

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: since the word indicates a dark and deep hue very far from that of

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: tin, which Homer describes as white. The after use of κύανος is

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: equally adverse to the interpretation suggested.

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
SECT. IV.
SECT. IV.
SECT. IV.
line: The most probable interpretation for this difficult word appears

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: to be that which is also in accordance with its subsequent use and

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: description as a colour. From Linton’s ‘Ancient and Modern Colours,’

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: (p. 21,) it appears that there was a κύανος αὐτοφυὴς, which was a

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: _native_ blue carbonate of copper: and that, according to the express

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: testimony of Dioscorides, this was obtained by the ancients from

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: the copper-mines: κύανος δὲ γεννᾶται μὲν ἐν Κύπρῳ ἐκ τῶν χαλκουργῶν

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: μετάλλων, v. 106. This interpretation would account for our finding

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: κύανος in Homer: for the rarity of its use: for the dark colour and

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: the affinity to πορφύρεος. Such a substance would make a good relief

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: for the cornice in the palace of Alcinous, against the copper-plated

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: walls: and would stand well in the rest of the passages where it

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: appears to be placed in relief with other metals, Il. xviii. 564,

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: xi. 39, and even on the buckler of Agamemnon, xi. 24. For on this

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: buckler, though the serpents, called κυάνεοι, are evidently placed

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: in contrast with the οἶμοι, and though among the οἶμοι there are ten

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: of κύανος, yet, as they are combined with twelve of gold and twenty

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: of tin, the general effect would be one such as we need not suppose

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: Homer to have rejected. This blue carbonate is still found among

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: other copper-ores, but less in our deep mines, than in the shallow

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: ones worked by the ancients. I understand from a gentleman versed

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: in metallurgy, that in its purest form it is crystalline, rarely

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: massive or earthy, of a deep azure, brittle, easily powdered, and

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: thus readily converted to use as a pigment.

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
SECT. IV.
line: I should therefore suppose that the κύανος is not a metal: that the

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: οἶμοι on the buckler mean lines or bands coloured in pigment: and

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: that the boss on the shield is probably a nodule of the substance

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: in its native state. We can thus understand why κύανος is not used

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: either with the gold, silver, χαλκὸς, and tin, in the forge of

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: Vulcan, or with the gold, silver, iron, and χαλκὸς of the chariot

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: of Juno[872]. We can also understand why, though κύανος is not used

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: in the forge, yet the trench round the vineyard on the shield of

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: Achilles is κυανεή[873]. This interpretation is also in conformity

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: with the Homeric employment of the adjective κυάνεος.

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
SECT. IV.
SECT. IV.
SECT. IV.
SECT. IV.
SECT. IV.
line: I understand that there is, in the _Museo Borbonico_ at Naples, a

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: spoon or ladle, with a boss on the end of the handle, which is formed

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: of this native blue carbonate of copper bored through for the purpose.

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
SECT. IV.
line: Of the four significations given to χαλκὸς in Homer (copper, brass,

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: bronze, and iron[874]), I adhere to the first. It cannot be iron,

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: (1) because it is never mentioned as hard in the same way with it,

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: (2) because it is so much more common, (3) because these metals are

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: expressly distinguished one from the other, as in Il. v. 723.

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
SECT. IV.
line: [874] Eustath. Il. i. p. 93.

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
SECT. IV.
line: Neither can the χαλκὸς of Homer be bronze. Not, however, from

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: absolute want of hardness: for I learn from competent authority that

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: very good cutting instruments (not, of course, equal to steel) may be

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: made in a bronze composed of 87½ parts copper, and 12½ parts tin. But

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: for the following reasons:

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
SECT. IV.
line: 1. Homer always speaks of it as a pure metal along with other pure

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: metals, even where Vulcan casts it into the furnace to be wrought;

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: Il. xviii. 474.

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
SECT. IV.
line: 2. Again, because, although we must not argue too confidently from

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: Homer’s epithets of colour, yet in this case we may lay considerable

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: stress not only on his χαλκὸς ἐρυθρὸς (since the ἐρυθρὸς of Homer

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: leans to brightness), but upon the ἤνοψ and νώροψ, which mean bright

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: and gleaming. These epithets of light would not apply to bronze: nor

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: would Homer plate with bronze the walls of the palace of Alcinous.

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: Neither does it appear likely that he would give us a heaven of

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: bronze among the imposing imagery of battle, Il. xvii. 424.

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
SECT. IV.
line: 3. It does not appear that Homer knew anything at all of the fusion

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: or alloying of metals.

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
SECT. IV.
line: We have, then, to conclude that χαλκὸς was copper, hardened by some

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: method; as some think by the agency of water: or else, and more

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: probably, according to a very simple process, by cooling slowly in

Poem Title: SECT. IV.
line: the air. (See Millin, Minéralogie Homérique, pp. 126-32.)

line: SECT. V.[875]

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
SECT. V.[875]
line: [875] The substance of this and the two following Sections formed two

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: Articles in the Quarterly Review, Nos. 201 and 203, for January and

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: July respectively, 1857. They are reprinted with the obliging approval

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: of Mr. Murray.

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
SECT. V.[875]
line: _Homer and some of his Successors in Epic Poetry: in particular, Virgil

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: and Tasso._

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
SECT. V.[875]
line: ~_Milton and Dante in relation to Homer._~

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
SECT. V.[875]
line: The great Epic poets of the world are members of a brotherhood still

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: extremely limited, and, as far as appears, not likely to be enlarged.

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: It may indeed well be disputed, with respect to some of the existing

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: claimants, whether they are or are not entitled to stand upon the

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: Golden Book. There will also be differences of opinion as to the

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: precedence among those, whose right to appear there is universally

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: confessed. Pretensions are sometimes advanced under the influence of

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: temporary or national partialities, which the silent action of the

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: civilized mind of the world after a time effectually puts down. Among

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: these there could be none more obviously untenable, than that set up on

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: behalf of Milton in the celebrated Epigram of Dryden, which seemed to

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: place him at the head of the poets of the world, and made him combine

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: all the great qualities of Homer and of Virgil. Somewhat similar ideas

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: were broached by Cowper in his Table Talk. The lines, as they are less

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: familiarly remembered, may be quoted here:

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
SECT. V.[875]
line: Ages elapsed ere Homer’s lamp appeared,

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: And ages ere the Mantuan swan was heard;

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: To carry Nature lengths unknown before,

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: To give a Milton birth, asked ages more.

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
SECT. V.[875]
line: But this great master is also subject to undue depreciation, as well

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: as flattered by extravagant worship. I myself have been assured in a

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: company composed of Professors of a German University, who were ardent

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: admirers of Shakespeare, that within the sphere of their knowledge

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: Milton was only regarded as of equal rank with Klopstock. It is not,

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: I trust, either national vanity or religious prejudice, nor is it

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: the mere wonder inspired by the wide range of his attainments and

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: performances, which makes England claim that he should be numbered in

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: the first class of epic poets; in that class of which Homer is the

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: head, distinguished before all competitors by a clear and even a vast

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: superiority.

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
SECT. V.[875]
line: It would be difficult to institute any satisfactory comparison between

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: Milton and Homer; so different, so wanting in points of contact, are

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: the characters partly of the men, and even much more of their works.

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: Perhaps the greatest and the most pervading merit of the Iliad is, its

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: fidelity and vividness as a mirror of man and of the visible sphere

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: in which he lived, with its infinitely varied imagery both actual and

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: ideal. But that which most excites our admiration in Milton is the

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: elasticity and force of genius, by which he has travelled beyond the

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: human sphere, and bodied forth to us new worlds in the unknown, peopled

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: with inhabitants who must be so immeasurably different from our own

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: race. Homer’s task was one, which admitted of and received what we may

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: call a perfect accomplishment; Milton’s was an undertaking beyond the

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: strength of man, incapable of anything more than faint adumbration,

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: and one of which, the more elevated the spectator’s point of view, the

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: more keenly he must find certain defects glare upon him. The poems of

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: Milton give us reason to think that his conceptions of character were

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: masculine and powerful; but the subject did not admit of their being

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: effectually tested. For his nearest approaches to perfection in his

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: art, we must look beyond his epics.

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
SECT. V.[875]
line: A comparison between Milton and Dante would be somewhat more

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: practicable, but it would not accord with the composition of the group,

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: which I shall here attempt to present, and which has Homer for its

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: centre. On the other hand, Dante might, far better than Milton, be

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: compared with Homer; for while he is in the Purgatorio and Paradiso

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: far more heavenly than Milton, he is also throughout the _Divina

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: Commedia_ truly and profoundly human. He is incessantly conversant with

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: the nature and the life of man; and though for the most part he draws

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: us, as Flaxman has drawn him, in outline only, yet by the strength and

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: depth of his touch he has produced figures, for example, Francesca and

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: Ugolino, that have as largely become the common property of mankind,

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: if not as Achilles and Ulysses, yet as Lear and Hamlet. Still the

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: theological basis, and the extra-terrene theatre, of Dante’s poem

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: remove him to a great distance from Homer, from whom he seems to have

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: derived little, and with whom we may therefore feel assured he could

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: have been but little acquainted.

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
SECT. V.[875]
line: The poets, whom it is most natural to compare with Homer, are those

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: who have supplied us in the greatest abundance with points of contact

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: between their own orbits and his, and who at the same time are such

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: manifest children of genius as to entitle them to the honour of being

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: worsted in such a conflict. These conditions I presume to be most

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: clearly fulfilled by Virgil and Tasso; and we may begin with the elder

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: of the pair.

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
SECT. V.[875]
line: Perhaps Chapman has gone too far when he says ‘Virgil hath nothing of

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: his own, but only elocution; his invention, matter, and form, being

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: all Homer’s[876].’ Yet no small part of this sweeping proposition can

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: undoubtedly be made good.

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
SECT. V.[875]
line: [876] Commentary on Il. ii.

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
SECT. V.[875]
line: With an extraordinary amount of admitted imitation and of obvious

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: similarity on the surface, the Æneid stands, as to almost every

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: fundamental particular, in the strongest contrast with the Iliad. As

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: to metre, figures, names, places, persons and times, the two works,

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: where they do not actually concur, stand in as near relations one to

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: another, as seem to be attainable without absolute identity of subject;

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: yet it may be doubted whether any two great poems can be named, which

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: are so profoundly discordant upon almost every point that touches

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: their interior spirit; upon everything that relates to the truth of

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: our nature, to the laws of thought and action, and to veracity in the

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: management of the higher subjects, such as history, morality, polity,

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: and religion.

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
SECT. V.[875]
line: ~_Contrast between form and spirit in the Æneid._~

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
SECT. V.[875]
line: The immense powers of Virgil as a poet had been demonstrated before he

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: wrote the Æneid. He had shown their full splendour in the Georgics;

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: though the ἦθος, or (so to speak) the heart, even of that great

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: work was touched with paralysis by his Epicurean and self-centring

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: philosophy. The Æneid does not bear a fainter impression of his genius.

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: The wonderfully sustained beauty and majesty of its verse, the imposing

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: splendour of its most elaborate delineations, the power of the author

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: in unfolding, when he strives to do it, the resources of passion, and

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: even perhaps the skill which he has shown in the general construction

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: of his plot, cannot be too highly praised. But while its general nature

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: as an epic (for the epic poem is preeminently ethical) brought its

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: defects into fuller view, the particular object he proposed to himself

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: was fatal to the attainment of the very highest excellence. While

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: Homer sang for national glory, the poem of Virgil is toned throughout

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: to a spirit of courtierlike adulation. No muse, however vigorous, can

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: maintain an upright gait under so base a burden.

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
SECT. V.[875]
line: ~_Catalogue in the Iliad and in the Æneid._~

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
SECT. V.[875]
line: And yet, in regard to its external form, the Æneid is perhaps, as a

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: whole, the most majestic poem that the European mind has in any age

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: produced. We often hear of the lofty march of the Iliad; but though

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: its versification is always appropriate and therefore never mean,

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: it only rises into stateliness, or into a high-pitched sublimity,

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: when Homer has occasion to brace his energies for an effort. He is

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: invariably true to his own conception of the bard[877], as one who

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: should win and delight the soul of the hearer; and so, when he has

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: strung himself, like a bow, for some great passage of his action,

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: ‘has brought the string to the breast, the iron to the wood,’ and

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: has hit his mark, straightway he unbends himself again. Thus he

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: ushers in with true grandeur the marshalling of the Greek army in the

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: Second Book, partly by the invocation of the Muses, and partly by an

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: assemblage of no less than six consecutive similes, which describe

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: respectively the flash of the Greek arms, the resounding tramp, the

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: swarming numbers, the settling down of the ranks as they form the

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: line, the busy marshalling by the commanders, the majesty of Agamemnon

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: preeminent among them[878]. Having done this, he sets himself about

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: the Catalogue, with no contempt indeed of poetical embellishment by

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: epithets, and with an occasional relief by short legends, but still

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: in the main as a matter of business, historical, geographical, and

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: topographical. And thus he proceeds, with perfect tranquillity, for

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: near three hundred lines, until his work is done. We then find that

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: he has given us, together with a most minute account of the forces,

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: a living map of the territories occupied by the Greek races of the

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: age. But Virgil, in his imitation of the Homeric Catalogue (upon

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: which there will be further occasion to comment hereafter, with

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: reference to other matters), has pursued a course quite different.

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: Waiving Homer’s gorgeous introduction, which pours from a single

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: point a broad stream of splendour over the whole, Virgil with vast,

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: and indeed rather painful, effort, carries us through his long-drawn

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: list at a laboriously-sustained elevation. To vary the wearisome

line: It is perhaps hardly possible to exhaust the topics of censure which

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: may be justly used against the Æneas of Virgil. His moral deficiencies

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: are not (so to speak) hidden amidst the accomplishments of a manly

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: intellect, nor his intellectual mediocrity redeemed by any fresh and

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: genuine virtues. He is not, to our knowledge, a statesman; nay more,

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: he is not a warrior; for we feel that his battles and feats of war are

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: the poet’s, and not his: and when he appears in arms we are tempted

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: to ask, ‘Son of Venus, what business have you here?’ The violent

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: exaggerations, by which Virgil attempts to vamp up his hero’s martial

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: character, only produce the ψυχρὸν of Longinus; a cold reaction,

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: approaching to a shudder, through the reader’s mind. As, for instance,

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: when in the Shades below, the poet represents the Greek chieftains[882]

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: as trembling and flying at the sight of him, the nobleness of the

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: verses cannot excuse either the tasteless solecism of the thought,

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: or the profanation offered to the memory of Homer in the person of

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: his heroes, who indeed often made Æneas tremble, but never trembled

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: at him themselves. But Virgil goes further yet, when he makes Diomed

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: assert[883] that, having been engaged in single combat with Æneas, he

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: knows by experience how terrible a warrior he will prove; and that, had

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: there been two more such men, Troy would have conquered Greece, and

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: not Greece Troy. Now, Æneas never in the Iliad even once executes a

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: real feat of war; and as to the single combat between the two chiefs,

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: Diomed first knocked him down with a stone[884], and then, after he had

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: been carried off and apparently set to rights by his mother, he was

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: thrice saved from the deadly charge of the same warrior by the single

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: intervention of Apollo, who by divine force arrested the attack. In

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: passing, it may be observed that, since Virgil could, with impunity, as

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: it appears, so far as his popularity was concerned, thus mutilate and

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: falsify the author from whose wealth he so largely borrowed, either the

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: knowledge of Greek literature in its head and father, Homer, must have

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: been very low among even the educated Romans, or else their standard of

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: taste must have been seriously debased before they could accept such

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: compliments.

line: Nor can we draw an apology for the defects of this primary character

line: in Virgil from the Æneas of Homer. The Dardanian Prince is indeed

line: figure. He is placed very high in station and authority, and, as we

line: have seen[886], he may probably have been, by the dignity of lineal

line: in the second, as well as Hector in both. Still, if there is in the

line: Turnus? The whole of that sketch is as good and true as we can desire;

line: and the noble speech in particular, in which he rebukes the trim

line: have been spoken by the Achilles of Homer. In vigorous reasoning, in

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]

line: presents a combination not easily to be matched; and it is, as a whole,

line: ~_The false position of Virgil._~

SECT. V.[875]
line: The failure in the Æneas of Virgil cannot be compared with the case of

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: any modern romance, such as the Waverley or Old Mortality of Scott,

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: where the hero may be an insipid person. All the greater modern

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: inventors have been compelled to lay their foundations in the palpable

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: breadth of some historic event: it was the prouder distinction of the

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: Homeric epic, that it had a living centre; it hung upon a man; there

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: was enough of vital power in Homer for this end: his Achilles and his

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: Ulysses were each an Atlas, that sustained the world in which they

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: also moved. Virgil made his poem an Æneid, instead of following the

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: example of the Cyclic poets; he thus pledged himself to his readers,

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: that Æneas should be its centre, its pole, its inward light and life.

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: But he did not keep his word: he had drawn the bow of Homer without

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: Homer’s force. He marks perhaps the final transition from the old epic

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: of the first class to the new. After him we have the epics of fact, the

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: Pharsalia, the Thebaid, and so forth. But Æneas stands before us with

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: the pretensions of Achilles and Ulysses; and the failure is great in

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: proportion to the gigantic scale of the attempt. When, in the Italian

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: romance, the character of the ideal man, as shown in Orlando, again

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: became the basis of new epic poems, we again find in the protagonist

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: great weakness indeed, as compared with Achilles and Ulysses; but

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: strength and success as compared with the Æneas of Virgil.

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
SECT. V.[875]
line: Upon the whole we are thrown back on the supposition that this crying

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: vice of the Æneid, the feebleness and untruth of the character of

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: Æneas, was due to the false position of Virgil, who was obliged to

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: discharge his functions as a poet in subjection to his dominant

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: obligations and liabilities as a courtly parasite of Augustus. As

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: the entire poem, so the character of its hero, was, before all other

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: things, an instrument for glorifying the Emperor of Rome. It at once

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: followed, that in all respects must that character be such as to avoid

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: suggesting a comparison disadvantageous to the person whose dignity,

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: for political ends, had already been elevated even into the unseen

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: world; nay, whose forestalled divinity was to be kept in a relation

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: of absolute and broad superiority to the image of his human ancestor.

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: Æneas is himself addressed in the action of the Æneid, as

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]

SECT. V.[875]
line: In order to arrive at the disastrous effects of this mental servitude,

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: take, first, the measure of the cold and unheroic character of

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: Augustus; then estimate the degree of relative superiority, which it

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: was essential to Virgil’s position that he should preserve for him

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: throughout; and thus we may come to some practical conception of the

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: straitness of the space within which Virgil had to develop his Æneas,

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: or, in other words, to run his match against Homer. All the faults, and

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: all the faultiness, of his poem may be really owing, in a degree none

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: can say how great, to this original falseness of position.

SECT. V.[875]
line: On account of the personal principle on which the ancient epic was

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: constructed, failure in the character of the hero must almost of

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: necessity have entailed failure in the poem. Most of all would this

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: follow in a case where, as in the Æneid, the hero is never out of view,

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: and where the action does not, as in the Iliad, travel away from his

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: person, in order then to enhance the splendour and effectiveness of his

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: reappearance. Thus the falseness of Virgil’s position was not confined

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: to an individual character, but extended to his entire work. Living,

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: too, in an age less natural and more critical than that of Homer, he

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: provided against criticism, so far as regarded its merely technical

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: functions, more, and he studied nature less. He had to construct his

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: epic for a court, and a corrupt court, not for mankind at large; it

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: followed, that he could not take his stand upon those deep and broad

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: foundations in human nature itself, which gave Homer a position of

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: universal command. Hence as a general rule he does not sing from the

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: heart, nor to the heart. His touches of genuine nature are rare. Such

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: of them as occur have been carefully noted and applauded, for he is

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: always studious to set them off by choice and melodious diction. For my

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]

line: mother labouring with her maidens at night, which he owes to Homer[889]:

line: With rare exceptions, the reader of Virgil finds himself utterly at a

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: loss to see at any point the soul of the poet reflected in his work. We

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: cannot tell, amidst the splendid phantasmagoria, where is his heart,

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: where lie his sympathies. In Homer a genial spirit, breathed from the

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: Poet himself, is translucent through the whole; in the Æneid we look in

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: vain almost for a single ray of it. Again, Virgil lived at a time when

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: the prevailing religion had lost whatever elements of real influence

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: that of Homer’s era either possessed in its own right, or inherited

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: from pristine tradition. It was undermined at once by philosophy and

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: by licentiousness; and it subsisted only as a machinery, a machinery,

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: too, already terribly discredited, for civil ends. Thus he lost one

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: great element of truth and nature, as well as of sublimity and pathos.

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: The extinction of liberty utterly deprived him of another. Homer saw

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: before him both a religion and a polity young, fresh, and vigorous; for

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: Virgil both were practically dead: and whatever this world has of true

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: greatness is so closely dependent upon them, that it was not his fault

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: if his poem felt and bears cogent witness to the loss. Even the sphere

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: of personal morality was not open to him; for what principle of truth

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: or righteousness could he worthily have glorified, without passing

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: severe condemnation on some capital act of the man, whom it was his

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: chief obligation to exalt?

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
SECT. V.[875]
line: And once more. Homer sang to his own people of the glorious deeds of

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: their sires, to whom they were united by fond recollection, and by

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: near historic and local ties. This was at once a stimulus and a check;

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: it cheered his labour, and at the same time it absolutely required

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: him to study moral harmony and consistency. Virgil sang to Romans of

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: the deeds of those who were not Romans, and whom only a most hollow

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: fiction connected with his hearers, through the dim vista of a thousand

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: years, and under circumstances which made the pretence to historical

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: continuity little better than ridiculous. Or rather, he sang thus, not

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: to Romans, but to their Emperor; he had to bear in mind, not the great

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: fountains of emotion in the human heart, but his town-house on the

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: Esquiline, and his country-house on the road from Naples to Pozzuoli.

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: In dealing with Greeks, with Trojans, with Carthaginians, he again lost

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: Homer’s double advantage: he had nothing to give a healthy stimulus

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: to his imagination, and nothing to bring him or to keep him to the

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: standard of truth and nature. And here, perhaps, we hit upon some clue

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: to the superior character and attractions of Turnus. The Poet was now

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: for once upon true national ground: he was an Italian minstrel, singing

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: to Italians, whether truly or mythically is of less consequence, about

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: an Italian hero. Thus he had something like the proper materials to

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: work with; and the result is one worthy of his noble powers, though

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: it has the strange consequence of setting all the best sympathies of

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: his readers, and of implying that his own were already set, in direct

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: opposition to the ostensible purpose of his poem.

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
SECT. V.[875]
line: It appears, however, as if this great and splendid Poet, being

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: thrown out of his true bearings in regard to all the deeper sources

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: of interest on which an epic writer must depend, such as religion,

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: patriotism, and liberty, became consequently reckless, alike in major

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: and in minor matters, as to all the inner harmonies of his work, and

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: contented himself with the most unwearied and fastidious labours in its

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: outward elaboration, where he could give scope to his extraordinary

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: powers of versification and of diction without fear of stumbling upon

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: anything unfit for the artificial atmosphere of the Roman court. The

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: consequence is, that a vein of untruthfulness runs throughout the whole

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: Æneid, as strong and as remarkable as is the genuineness of thought and

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: feeling in the Homeric poems. Homer walks in the open day, Virgil by

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: lamplight. Homer gives us figures that breathe and move, Virgil usually

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: treats us to waxwork. Homer has the full force and play of the drama,

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: Virgil is essentially operatic. From Virgil back to Homer is a greater

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: distance, than from Homer back to life.

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
SECT. V.[875]
line: ~_Homer is misapprehended through Virgil._~

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
SECT. V.[875]
line: But more. Virgil is at once the copyist of Homer, and, for the

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: generality of educated men, his interpreter[891]. In all modern Europe

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: taken together, Virgil has had ten who read him, and ten who remember

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: him, for one that Homer could show. Taking this in conjunction with the

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: great extent of the ground they occupy in common, we may find reason to

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: think that the traditional and public idea of Homer’s works, throughout

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: the entire sphere of the Western civilization, has been formed, to a

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: much greater degree than could at first be supposed, by the Virgilian

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: copies from him. This is only to say, in other words, that it has been

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: sadly impaired, not to say seriously falsified; for there is scarcely

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: a point of vital moment, in which Virgil follows Homer faithfully, or

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: represents him either fairly or completely. Now this traditional idea

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: is not only the stock idea that governs the indifferent public, but

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: it is likewise the idea with which the individual student starts, and

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: which governs him until he has reached such a point in his progress as

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: to discover the necessity, and be conscious moreover of the strength,

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: to throw it off. This, however, is a point that, from the nature of

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: human life and its pursuits, very few students indeed can reach at

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: all. Elsewhere we shall see, with what evil and untrue effect Virgil

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: has handled some of the Homeric characters. It is the same in every

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: minor trait; and it seems strange that so great a Poet should not have

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: had enough of reverence for another Poet, greater still and enshrined

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: in almost the worship of all ages, to have restrained him from such

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: constant and wanton, as well as wilful, mutilations of the Homeric

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: tradition. It would, however, appear that Virgil’s miscarriages are not

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: all due to carelessness, in the common sense of it. In many instances,

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: unless so far as they can be referred to the necessities that press

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: upon a courtier, it would seem as if they must be ascribable to torpor

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: in the faculties, or defect in the habit of mind, by which Homer should

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: have been appreciated. Nay, sometimes he appears to have been moved

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: simply by metrical convenience to alter the traditions of Homer. Let us

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: take first a minor instance to test this assertion.

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
SECT. V.[875]
line: [891] In Dibdin’s ‘Editions of the Greek and Latin Classics,’ we find

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: nineteen editions of Virgil between 1469 and 1478. The _Princeps_

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: of Homer was only printed in 1488. Panzer, according to Dibdin,

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: enumerates ninety editions of Virgil in the 15th century (ii. 540.).

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: Mr. Hallam says (Lit. Eur., i. 420.), ‘Ariosto has been _after Homer_

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: the favourite poet of Europe.’ I presume this distinguished writer does

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: not mean to imply that Homer has been more read than any other poet.

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: Can his words mean that Homer has been more approved? It is worth while

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: to ask the question: for the judgments of Mr. Hallam are like those of

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: Minos, and reach into the future.

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
SECT. V.[875]
line: Nothing can be more marked than the prominence of the Scamander as

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: compared with the Simois in Homer. The Simois is named by him only six

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: times, and none of the passages show it to have been a considerable

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: stream. In the Twenty-first Book[892], Scamander invites Simois to join

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: him in pouring forth the flood which was to bear away Achilles, but

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: his ‘brother’ neither replies, nor takes part in the action. It would

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: appear, indeed, from geographical considerations, which belong to the

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: topography of the Troad, that in the summer Simois was probably dry.

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: This entirely accords with the passage in which this river supplies

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: ἀμβροσίη[893], a figure, as may be presumed, of grass, for the horses

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: of Juno. At any rate, that passage is at variance with the idea of the

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: river as a tearing torrent. Again, Homer mentions[894] that many heroes

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: fell, he does not say in, but about, the stream: above all, he does not

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: say they fell into its waters, but in the dust of it, or near it:

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
SECT. V.[875]
line: [892] Il. xxi. 307, et seqq.

line: καὶ Σιμόεις, ὅθι πολλὰ βοάγρια καὶ τρυφάλειαι

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: κάππεσον ἐν κονίῃσι.

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
SECT. V.[875]
line: Again, Scamander is personified as the god Xanthus, and plays a great

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: part in the action: Simois is not personified at all. Scamander is

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: δῖος, διοτρεφὴς and much besides: Simois has no epithets. Simoeisius is

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: the son of Anthemion, a person of secondary account; but Scamandrius is

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: the name given by Hector to his boy. Simois, for all we know, may have

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: been either a dry bed, or little better than a rivulet; but armed men

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: are thrown into Scamander, and whirled by him to the sea. Lastly, the

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: plain where the Greek army was reviewed is λειμὼν Σκαμάνδριος, πέδιον

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: Σκαμάνδριον. Now a right conception of these rivers is not altogether

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: an insignificant affair, but is material to the clearness of our ideas

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: upon the military action of the poem. What then has Virgil done with

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: them? He has simply reversed the Homeric representation. Xanthus is

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: with him the unmarked river, Simois is the mighty torrent. Witness

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: these passages:

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
SECT. V.[875]
line: Mitto ea, quæ muris bellando exhausta sub altis,

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: Quos Simois premat ille viros. (Æn. xi. 256.)

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
SECT. V.[875]
line: Again:

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
SECT. V.[875]
line: Victor apud rapidum Simoenta sub Ilio alto. (Æn. v. 261.)

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
SECT. V.[875]
line: And most of all, the passage which he has directly carried off from

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: Homer, and corrupted it on his way (Æn. i. 104):

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
SECT. V.[875]
line: Ubi tot Simois correpta sub undis

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: Scuta virûm galeasque et fortia corpora volvit.

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
SECT. V.[875]
line: And why all this? Plainly, I apprehend, because, while Scamander was

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: a word disqualified from entering into the Latin hexameter, Xanthus

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: also was somewhat less convenient than Simois for the march of his

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: resounding verse. Now this is a sample in small things of what Virgil

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: has done in nearly all things, both small and great.

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
SECT. V.[875]
line: ~_Νεκυΐα of Homer and Virgil._~

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
SECT. V.[875]
line: There are instances in which Virgil is popularly thought to profit

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: by the comparison with Homer, and where, notwithstanding, a full

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: consideration may lead to a reversal of the sentence. The νεκυΐα of

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: the Eleventh Odyssey, for example, is thought inferior to that of the

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: Sixth Æneid. To bring them fairly together, we should perhaps put out

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: of view the philosophical and prophetical part of the latter[895]; but

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: whether we do it or not is little material in the comparison. In either

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: way, the _Inferno_ of Virgil is, upon the whole, a stage procession of

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: stately and gorgeous figures; but it has no consistent or veracious

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: relation to any idea of the future or unseen state actually operative

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: among mankind. Yet there existed such an idea, at least in the times

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: of which Virgil was treating, if not at the period when he lived. It

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: was surely a subject of the deepest interest, and of the most solemn

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: pathos. What we are as men here depends very much on our conception

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: of what we are hereafter to be. There is nothing more touching in all

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: the history of the race of Adam, than its blind and painful feeling

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: after a future still invisible. There is no witness to the comparative

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: degradation of a race or age, so sure as its having ceased to yearn

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: towards any thing beyond the grave. Homer has shown us in the Eleventh

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: Odyssey[896], that, together with his keen sense of the present and

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: visible, he felt the full force of this mysterious drawing towards the

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: unseen. He is plainly as much in earnest here, as in any part of the

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: poems. Virgil, on the other hand, succeeds in investing his hell with

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: almost unequalled pomp, approximating at times to splendour. Homer

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: attempts nothing of the kind; but he produces a perfect and profound

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: impression of those regions, according to the idea in his own mind:

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: they are shadowy, gloomy, cold, above all, and in one word, dismal.

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: Virgil contrives to leave the reader convinced that _he_ is a very

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: great artist: Homer lets all such matters take care of themselves.

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: But while Virgil creates no impression at all on the mind as to the

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: World of Shades, no image of the timid, vague, and dim belief that

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: was entertained respecting it, Homer has set it all before us with a

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: truthfulness never equalled or approached. And yet Virgil abounds in

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: details and measurements which Homer avoids. Tartarus is twice as deep

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: as the distance from earth to sky[897], and the Hydra has fifty mouths.

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: Yet the details of the one give no impression of reality, while the

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: utter local vagueness and dreaminess of the other is far more definite

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: in its effect, because it is made to minister to the appropriate

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: ideas of sadness, sympathy, and awe. As to particular passages, the

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: appearance of Dido is full of grandeur; but her silence, the basis of

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: it, is borrowed from that of Ajax; while in the Odyssey the striding of

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: Achilles in silence over the meadow of asphodel, when he swells with

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: exultation upon hearing that his son excelled in council and in war, is

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: perhaps one of the most sublime pieces of human representation, which

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: Homer himself ever has produced.

SECT. V.[875]
line: Let us now give an instance of Virgil’s utter indifference to historic

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: truth and consistency. It is the more remarkable, because as he was

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: pretending to derive the Julian family from the stock of Æneas, there

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: would apparently have been some advantage in adhering strictly to the

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: Homeric distinctions as to races on both sides in the Trojan war. But

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: this appears to be entirely beneath his attention. For instance, he

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: calls the Homeric Greeks Pelasgi[898]. It may be said he was guided by

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: the Italian traditions, which connected the Greek and Pelasgian names

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: as early colonists of that country. But first, some regard should be

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: paid to Homer in matters which concern Troy; and it is rather violent

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: to call the Greeks Pelasgi, when the only Pelasgi named in the war by

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: the Poet are placed on the side of their enemies. Secondly, as it was

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: his purpose throughout to depress the Greeks, why should he thus thrust

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: them into view as one with an Italian race? Above all, why do this

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: in a case, where Homer had himself supplied a link between Italy and

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: Troy? Again, Virgil calls the Greek camp _Dorica_ castra[899]. But the

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: Dorians at the period of the Trojan war were utterly insignificant, and

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: are never once named by Homer in connection with the contest. Again,

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: Virgil calls Diomed, and the city of Arpi founded by him, Ætolian, and

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: makes him complain that he was not allowed to go back to Calydon[900],

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: simply because his father Tydeus, as a son of Œneus, had been of

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: Ætolian extraction; though he commanded the Argives, and had nothing

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: whatever to do with the Ætolians of Homer. Again, following a late and

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: purposeless tradition, he calls Ulysses Æolides[901], though Homer

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: has given the descent of Ulysses[902] without in any manner attaching

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: it to the line of the Æolids, a collection of families whose descent,

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: on account probably of their historical importance, he is more than

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: ordinarily careful to mark.

line: Homer. In the Twentieth Iliad, the genealogy of the reigning families

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: of Troy and of Dardania is given with great precision. The distinction

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: between Trojans and Dardanians is preserved through the Iliad, though

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: the Trojan name is sometimes, but rarely, used to include the whole

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: indigenous army, and sometimes it even signifies the entire force,

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: including the allies, which opposed the Greek army. We might here,

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: however, suppose that it would have been in the interest of Virgil’s

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: aim to maintain, or even sharpen, the distinction between the Dardanian

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: line, which was at most but indirectly worsted by the Greeks, and the

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: line of Ilus, which fatally both sinned and suffered in the conflict of

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: the _Troica_. But, on the contrary, he is still less discriminating in

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: the use of names here, than he has been for the Greeks. The companions

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: of Æneas are sometimes Teucri, Trojani, or Trojugenæ--sometimes

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: Æneadæ, sometimes Dardanidæ. In the first of these names he entirely

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: contravenes Homer, who produces a Teucer eminent among the Greeks,

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: but nowhere connects the name with Troy, while Virgil makes a Cretan

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: Teucer[903] the founder of the Trojan race. I grant that he here

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: founds himself upon what may be called a separate tradition, though

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: it is vague and slender, of a Teucrian race in Troas. In the two last

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: appellations, without any authority, he wholly alters the effect of

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: the Greek patronymic, and changes the mere family-name into a national

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: appellation. Then again they appear as the Pergamea gens[904]. But

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: Pergamus in Homer was simply the citadel of Troy, and is a correlative

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: to πύργος[905]: the English might almost as well be called the people

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: of the Tower. Not content yet, he will also have the Trojans to be

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: Phryges:

line: though in Homer the Phrygians are a people both ethnologically and

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: himself. He is called Rhæteius heros[908]; but if Virgil chose thus

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: to designate his hero by reference to a single point of the Trojan

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: territory, it should have been one with which he was locally connected,

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: whereas the dominions of his family were not near the promontory

line: of the branch of Ilus, while Æneas belonged to that of Assaracus; and

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: was moreover perjured, while the line of Assaracus was marked with no

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]

line: but Dardanus founded Dardania, while Ilium did not exist until the time

line: of his great grandson Ilus. And here Virgil seems wholly to forget that

line: he had himself made Teucer the head of the race[911]. In describing the

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]

line: Nondum Ilium et arces

SECT. V.[875]
SECT. V.[875]
line: Here he not only rejects Homer, who places Dardanus and the original

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: settlement among the mountains, but likewise represents what is in

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: itself improbable, since eminences, and not bottoms, were commonly

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: sought by the first colonists with a view to security. Choosing to

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: depart from Homer, he does not even agree with Apollodorus[913].

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: Lastly, he is not less neglectful of the actual topography; for he

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: implies that Ilium is among the hills, while it was, according to

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: Homer’s express words and according to universal opinion, on the plain

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: as opposed to the hills. Again we have from Virgil the allusion--

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
SECT. V.[875]
line: [913] Apollod. III. xii. 1.

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
SECT. V.[875]
line: quibus obstitit Ilium, et ingens

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: Gloria Dardaniæ[914].

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
SECT. V.[875]
SECT. V.[875]
SECT. V.[875]
line: Here is another case of metre against history, and in all such

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: cases history must go (as is said) to the wall. _Ilium_ would not

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: satisfactorily admit the genitive case; there could therefore be no

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: glory of Ilium, and on this account Virgil liberally assigns vast

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: renown to Dardania, which was a place of no renown whatever. But he is

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: quite as ready, it must be admitted, to contradict himself as he is to

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: contradict Homer. In Æn. ii. 540, he gives it to be understood that the

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: city of Troy alone was the kingdom of Priam, and that the Greek camp

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: was beyond it, for he makes Priam say of his return from the camp,

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
SECT. V.[875]
line: meque in mea regna remisit.

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
SECT. V.[875]
line: But a very little further on he calls Priam (v. 556),

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
SECT. V.[875]
line: tot quondam populis regnisque superbum

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: Regnatorem Asiæ.

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
SECT. V.[875]
line: Each account is alike inaccurate: Priam had more than a city, but his

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: dominions were confined to a mere nook of Asia Minor. And again, before

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: quitting this part of the subject, let us observe how, in the case of

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: Anchises, he departs from Homer, even where it would have served the

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: purpose of his story to follow him closely. The Anchises of Homer is

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: an ἄναξ ἀνδρῶν; he does not appear at Troy among the δημογέροντες of

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: the city, or of Priam’s court, which would have made him a secondary

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: figure; he resides at Dardania as an independent sovereign, and it

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: seems not unlikely that in lineal dignity, at least, he was even before

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: Priam. But the Anchises of Virgil is resident in Troy[915]; and is

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: therefore, of course, to be taken for a subject of Priam. Here the

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: alteration very much lowers the rank of Æneas, and so far, therefore,

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: of Augustus.

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
SECT. V.[875]
SECT. V.[875]
SECT. V.[875]
line: The effect of all this is, without any real gain either moral or

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: poetical, entirely to bewilder the mind of the reader of the Æneid, in

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: regard to a subject of real interest both historical and ethnological,

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: with respect to which Homer has left on record a most careful and

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: clear representation. It must indeed be admitted, that the intervening

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: poets had set many examples of similar license; indeed they had made

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: irregularity a rule; but they had no such powerful reasons as Virgil

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: had for imitating, in some points at least, the precision of Homer, and

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: besides, he has perhaps exceeded them all in the multitude and variety

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: of his departures from it. On the other hand, some allowance, I admit,

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: should be made for the less flexible character of the Latin tongue,

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: which might have made the peculiar accuracy of Homer a real difficulty

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: to Virgil.

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
SECT. V.[875]
line: I have thus minutely traced out this course of inconsistency and

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: contradiction in particular instances, because they are highly

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: illustrative of the character of Virgil’s work, if not of his mind.

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: After the political and courtly idea of the poem, he seems to have

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: abandoned all solicitude except for its form and sound, and to have

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: been totally indifferent as to presenting any veracious, or if that

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: word imply too much credulity, any self-consistent pattern, of manners,

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: places, events, or characters.

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
SECT. V.[875]
line: Virgil must, materially at least, have saturated himself with the Iliad

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: before he planned the Æneid, for his borrowing is alike incessant

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: and diversified; and this it is which renders it so singular that he

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: should at once have exposed himself to the double charge of servilely

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: imitating and of gratuitously disfiguring his original.

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
SECT. V.[875]
line: If we look to the action of the Twelfth Book of the Æneid, it is all

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: made up from Homer cut in pieces and recast. It begins with the idea of

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: the single combat, borrowed from the Third and Seventh Iliads. Then

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: come the pact and the breach of it by Juturna, under Juno’s influence,

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: which are borrowed from the treachery of Pandarus, prompted by Minerva,

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: under the same instigation. Next, the flight of Turnus before Æneas is

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: borrowed from that of Hector before Achilles. After this, Turnus is

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: disabled by a divine agency, like Patroclus before Hector; a downfall

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: brought about in the one case, as in the other, without peril and

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: without honour, so that here we have a copy even of one among the

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: few points where the Iliad was little worthy to be imitated. Lastly,

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: the thought of Pallas in the mind of Æneas (more highly wrought,

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: however, and very effective), plays the part of the recollection of

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: Patroclus[916] in the mind of Achilles.

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
SECT. V.[875]
SECT. V.[875]
SECT. V.[875]
line: ~_Unfaithful imitations of detail._~

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
SECT. V.[875]
line: Both here and elsewhere, the imitations in detail are too numerous to

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: be noted. Some of them even descend to a character which, independently

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: of their minuteness, approaches the ludicrous. The very dung, in which

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: the Oilean Ajax loses his footing[917], in the Twenty-third Iliad,

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: is reproduced in the Fifth Æneid, that Nisus may flounder in it. But

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: even here we may note two characteristic differences. Homer trips up a

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: personage, whom he has no particular occasion to set off favourably.

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: Virgil chooses for the object of derision Nisus, on whom, in the

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: beautiful episode which soon after follows, he is about to concentrate

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: all the tenderest sympathies of his hearers. And again, Homer makes

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: Ajax slip where, as he says, the oxen had just been slain over

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: Patroclus: Virgil has no such probable cause to allege for the presence

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: of the obnoxious material[918], but says _cæsis forte juvencis_. Now

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: the Trojans had in fact left the tomb of Anchises, and had gone to a

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: chosen spot to celebrate the foot-races[919]; so that even his gore and

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: ordure are quite out of place.

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]

SECT. V.[875]
SECT. V.[875]
line: So again, of all the _formulæ_ in Homer, it is not very clear why

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: Virgil should have chosen to recall the rather commonplace line

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
SECT. V.[875]
line: αὐτὰρ ἐπεὶ πόσιος καὶ ἐδήτυος ἐξ ἔρον ἕντο

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
SECT. V.[875]
line: in his own more ambitious and resounding verse,

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
SECT. V.[875]
line: Postquam exemta fames, et amor compressus edendi[920];

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
SECT. V.[875]
SECT. V.[875]
SECT. V.[875]
line: but it is still more singular that, instead of saying that hunger and

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: thirst were satisfied, he should leave out thirst altogether, and fill

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: up his hexameter by mentioning hunger twice over.

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
SECT. V.[875]
line: Still it seems not a little strange, notwithstanding the power of the

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: disabling causes which have been enumerated, that, with so vast an

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: amount of material imitation, Virgil should not have acquired, even by

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: accident or by sheer force of use, some traits of nearer resemblance in

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: feeling, and in ethical handling, to his great original.

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
SECT. V.[875]
line: His maltreatment of the Homeric characters is most conspicuous,

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: perhaps, in the instance of Helen. This case, indeed, deserves a

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: separate consideration of the causes which have reduced a beautiful,

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: touching, and remarkably original portrait to a gross and most common

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: caricature. But Ulysses, as the prince of policy, had perhaps a better

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: claim to be comprehended by a Roman at the court of Augustus. Yet

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: the Ulysses of Virgil simply represents the naked ideas of hardness,

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: cunning, and cruelty. He is never named but to be abused; and, though

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: the mention of him is not very frequent, it is easy to construct from

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: the poem a pretty large catalogue of vituperative epithets, unmitigated

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: by any single one of an opposite character. He is _durus_, _dirus_,

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: _sævus_, _pellax_, _fandi fictor_, _artifex_, _inventor scelerum_, and

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: _scelerum hortator_. Even physical circumstances, however, and those

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: too of the broadest notoriety, Virgil entirely overlooks. Nothing can

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: be more at variance with the effeminate character of the Homeric Paris,

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: his impotence in fight, and his distinction limited to the bow, which

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: was then the coward’s weapon, than to represent him as possessed of

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: vast physical force. Yet even on this Virgil has ventured. In the games

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: of the Fifth Book, when Æneas invites candidates for the pugilistic

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: encounter, the huge Dares immediately presents himself, and he is

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: described as the only person who could box with Paris[921]!

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
