SECT. V.[875]
line: Solus qui Paridem solitus contendere contra.

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
SECT. V.[875]
line: Heyne urges by way of apology the authority of Hyginus, who was no

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: more than the contemporary of Virgil himself; and presumes that

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: Virgil followed authorities now lost: a sorry defence, because the

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: representation is inconsistent not merely with the facts, but with the

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: essential idea of the Paris of Homer, and therefore proves that Virgil

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: did not try or care to understand the character, or to be faithful to

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: his master.

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
SECT. V.[875]
line: ~_Maltreatment of Mythology and Ethics._~

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
SECT. V.[875]
line: But it is time to give some instances, which show an utter disregard of

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: either mythological or moral consistency.

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
SECT. V.[875]
line: In the Eighth Æneid, Æneas and Anchises are much troubled in mind; and

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: so it appears they must have continued,

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
SECT. V.[875]
line: Nî signum cœlo Cytherea dedisset aperto;

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: Namque improviso vibratus ab æthere fulgor

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: Cum sonitu venit[922].

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
SECT. V.[875]
SECT. V.[875]
SECT. V.[875]
line: This idea of a _Cytherea tonans_ is as incongruous as it is novel.

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: To preserve the characteristic attributes of the several deities of

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: the Pagan mythology contributes to beauty, and was therefore at least

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: an obligation imposed by the poetic art; but Virgil is not content

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: with simply departing from it by taking the management of thunder

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: and lightning out of the hands of Jupiter and the highest deities;

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: he cannot be satisfied without giving it to Venus. With her Homeric

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: character, and with any consistent conception of her attributes, it is

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: utterly irreconcilable.

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
SECT. V.[875]
line: But again, in the Second Æneid, Virgil makes Venus address to her son

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: the following majestic lines, when he was about to slay Helen amidst

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: the conflagration of Troy:

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
SECT. V.[875]
line: Non tibi Tyndaridis facies invisa Lacænæ

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: Culpatusve Paris: Divûm inclementia, Divûm

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: Has evertit opes, sternitque a culmine Trojam[923].

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
SECT. V.[875]
SECT. V.[875]
SECT. V.[875]
line: In which he plainly imitates the words of Priam,

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
SECT. V.[875]
line: οὔτι μοι αἰτίη ἐσσὶ, θεοί νύ μοι αἴτιοί εἰσιν,

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: οἵ μοι ἐφώρμησαν πόλεμον πολύδακρυν Ἀχαιῶν[924].

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
SECT. V.[875]
SECT. V.[875]
SECT. V.[875]
line: Now, even with reference to the acquittal of Helen, the cases are

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: quite dissimilar. What Homer puts into the mouth of Priam, Virgil

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: stamps with the authority of a deity: what Priam says of the Homeric

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: Helen, who had been carried off by Paris, and whose general character

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: was very far from depraved, the Venus of Virgil says of a hardened

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: traitress as well as adulteress. Again, what Priam says relative to

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: himself, ‘_I_ do not blame thee,’ seems in the Æneid to resemble the

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: unlimited enunciation of an abstract proposition. But, above all, let

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: us notice how lamentably Virgil has mauled the sentiment by introducing

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: Paris into the passage, of whose moral guilt, if there be such a thing

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: as moral guilt upon earth, there could be no doubt, and whom Homer,

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: with true poetic justice, has taken care to punish by making him the

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: object of the general reprobation and hatred of his countrymen[925].

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: In acquitting such an offender, and throwing the charge of his crimes

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: upon the Immortals, by the mouth, too, of one belonging to their

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: number, Virgil has given into the worst form of fatalism, that namely

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: which annihilates all moral sanctions and ideas as applicable to human

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: conduct.

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
SECT. V.[875]
line: [925] Il. iii. 453, and elsewhere.

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
SECT. V.[875]
line: And this he has done with no plea whatever which might have been

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: drawn, _valeat quantum_, from the exigencies of his poem. Paris was

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: not before the eye of Æneas: Venus was not dissuading her son from

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: taking vengeance upon Paris; he is forced into our sight; the allusion

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: is as irrelevant with reference to the purpose of the passage, as it

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: is blameworthy in an ethical point of view; and in all probability the

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: mention of him is introduced for no other reason than that it supplied

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: Virgil with a hemistich to fill up a gap in an extremely fine passage,

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: and to secure its prosodial equilibrium, to which the balance of moral

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: sanctions is sacrificed without remorse.

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
SECT. V.[875]
line: As it is with the management of his gods, so with his conception

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: of human nature; Virgil seems to have lost the sight of its higher

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: prerogatives, and especially of the great and noble truth, that it

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: is susceptible of divine influences without the loss of its free

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: agency. The poems of Homer, notwithstanding their copious theurgy, are

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: throughout eminently and entirely human. Their human agency is adorned

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: and elevated (as well as unhappily lowered and darkened), it is even

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: modified and controlled, but never inwardly mutilated, curtailed or

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: superseded, by the interference of the Immortals. But, in regard to his

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: relations with the deities, Æneas is a mere puppet; and the gallant

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: spirit of Turnus on his last battlefield is, as it were, put down

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: within him by main force from heaven.

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]

line: ~_Æneas and Dido in the Shades._~

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: saying, ‘he could not help it, the gods compelled him; and really he

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: never thought she would take it so much to heart.’

line: Though Virgil is esteemed a woman-hater, he has availed himself of

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: the use of female characters to a degree only exceeded, so far as I

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: portraits of king Henry the Eighth of England. Of mortals we have,

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: besides the mute Lavinia, and minor or transitory personages, Dido,

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: Juturna, Amata, Camilla. All these play very marked parts in the poem;

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: which the whole range of the poem affords, to the original power and

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: genius of its author. Yet even in these, his signal successes, it is

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: curious to notice the dissimilarity between Virgil and Homer. Homer,

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: too, has been eminently successful in his women. His greater studies of

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: force of all the less conspicuous delineations: Hecuba, Briseis, the

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: incomparable Nausicaa, the faithful Euryclea, the pert and heartless

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: Melantho. But how different are the works of the two poets! In all

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: Virgil’s women (as on the other hand his men are apt to be effeminate)

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: there is a tinge of the masculine. Many a woman would stab herself for

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: love like Dido; but none, not even in France, with her pomp, apparatus,

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: and self-consciousness. Their fates, too, are all of a violent

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: character. Amata, as well as Dido, commits suicide; Camilla is slain;

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: Juturna is immortal indeed, but is dismissed from earth with what for

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: her comes nearest to an image of death; with defeat, mortification,

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: shame. But on the contrary, the feminineness of Homer’s women has never

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: been surpassed. In Hecuba alone, at one single point in the story,

line: there is an apparent exception; yet it is no great violence done to

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: nature, if we find in her after Hector’s death the wild ferocity of

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: a moment into the temper of a cannibal. Elsewhere beyond doubt, even

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: in Melantho, the feminine character is not wholly obliterated, but is

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: left at the point where in actual life licentiousness and vanity might

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: leave it. In Helen, Andromache, Nausicaa, it reaches a perfection which

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: has never been surpassed, unless by Shakespeare, in human song. There

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]

line: intercommunion of spirit between the poet and those to whom he sang,

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: was not in him a sordid quest of popularity; it was only an expression

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: the basis of a great effort to be the organ of the general heart of

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: mankind. All this we may discern in his notices, informal as they are,

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: of the profession of the minstrel:

line: And again, in the offices of guardianship which they exercised; for

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]

line: bard of his palace the care of Clytemnestra; and his advice, with her

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: bard in the living description of Homer; such he was represented in

line: the Poet himself, never thrust into view, but ever understood, ever

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: bard, as exhibited in Virgil, is what may be termed professional: the

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: fire and power of genius may be in him, but they must work only under

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: conventional forms, and for ends prescribed according to the spirit of

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: that lower and narrower utility which is, not logically perhaps, but

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: yet very effectively, denominated utilitarianism. A remarkably high

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: form of exterior art, with a radical inattention to substance, both

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: of facts and laws, has been the result in the case of Virgil. And it

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: is rather significant, that this great Poet has nowhere placed upon

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: his canvass the figure of the bard amidst the abodes of man; as if the

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: very type had perished from the earth in those degenerate days, and

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: the memory of him could not be recalled. An effete and corrupted age

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: could no longer conceive a mind like the mind of Homer; an Æolian harp

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: so finely strung, that it answers to the faintest movement of the air

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: by a proportionate vibration: with every stronger current its music

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: rises, along an almost immeasurable scale, which begins with the lowest

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: and softest whisper, and ends in the full swell of the organ.

line: ~_Change in the idea of the Poet’s office._~

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
SECT. V.[875]
line: By a false association of ideas, we have come to place accuracy and

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: genius in antagonism to one another. It is Homer who may best undeceive

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: us: except indeed that most complete solution which the mind gladly

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: perceives when, ascending to the Author of all being, it finds in Him

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: alone the source and the perfection, alike of Order and of Light; alike

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: of the most minute, and of the most gigantic operations. But among men

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: Homer best exemplifies this union. It is not indeed the precision of

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: dry facts, terminating upon itself: it is the precision of sympathies,

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: of sympathies with nature and with man, to which the minute and

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: scrupulous adjustments of Homer are to be referred; and this precision

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: is probably due by no means to conscious effort, but to the spontaneous

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: operations of the soul. In this view his far-famed, but not even yet

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: fully fathomed, accuracy is no deduction from his greatness, but is in

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: truth a proof of the near approach to perfection in the organization

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: of his faculties. The later poets have too often torn asunder, what in

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: him was harmoniously combined. They have conferred upon their art a

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: deadly gift, in claiming first an exemption _ad libitum_ from the laws,

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: not only of dry fact, but of Truth in its higher sense, of harmony and

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: self-consistency, and of all, except a merely external beauty, which

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: was meant to be the vehicle and not the substitute for all those great

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: and discarded qualities. In this work of laceration, Virgil has borne

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: no secondary share.

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
SECT. V.[875]
line: Upon the whole, though it is doubtless natural that Virgil should

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: be compared with Homer, the mind is astonished at finding that he

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: should so often even have gained a preference. We may account for his

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: being chosen as Dante’s guide, by their being countrymen, and by the

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: almost universal ignorance of Greek when Dante wrote. It is far more

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: staggering to find Saint Augustine emphatically call him[952] _Poeta

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: magnus omniumque præclarissimus atque optimus_; for he was no stranger

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: to Greek influences, inasmuch as the philosophy of Plato had a very

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: high place in his estimation[953]. Nor can this be readily accounted

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: for, except by the advantage which Virgil had through writing in the

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: Latin tongue, and by the very great decay of poetical tastes and

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: perceptions.

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
SECT. V.[875]
line: [952] De Civ. Dei, i. 3.

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
SECT. V.[875]
line: [953] Ibid. viii. 4-11.

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
SECT. V.[875]
line: Still let us not do wrong to the memory of him, who thrilled with an

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: immeasurable love, as he bore the sacred vessels of the Muses; and who

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: has received so unequivocally the seal of that approbation of mankind,

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: prolonged through ages, which comes near to an infallible award. It is

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: but fair to admit, that we must not measure the relative rank of Homer

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: and Virgil simply by the comparative merits of their epic works. Homer

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: lived in the genial and joyous youth of a poetic nation and a poetic

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: religion, and amid the influences of the soul of freedom: Virgil among

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: a people always matter-of-fact rather than poetical, in an age and a

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: court where the heart and its emotions were chilled, where liberty

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: was dead, where religion was a mockery, and the whole higher material

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: of his art had passed from freshness into the sear and yellow leaf.

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: Whether Virgil, if he had lived the life of Homer in Homer’s country

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: and Homer’s time, could have composed the Iliad and the Odyssey, may be

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: more than doubtful; but it is indisputably clear that Homer could not

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: have produced them, if it had been his misfortune to live at the date

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: and in the sphere of Virgil.

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
SECT. V.[875]
line: I pass on now to make some attempt at comparison between the work of

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: Tasso and the Iliad of Homer. But although the relation between the

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: subjects appears to recommend the choice of Tasso for this purpose

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: rather than any other Italian poet, I have to confess, that as far as

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: the qualities of the men are concerned, both Bojardo and Ariosto are in

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: my estimation more Homeric than Tasso; as being nearer to nature in its

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: truest sense, as not conveying the same impression of perpetual effort

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: and elaboration, as exempt from the temptation to the conceits so

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: unhappily frequent in the _Gerusalemme_, and generally as working with

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: a freer and broader touch, and exhibiting a more vigorous and elastic

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: movement.

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
SECT. V.[875]
line: ~_The War of Troy and the Crusades._~

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
SECT. V.[875]
line: There is, however, a striking resemblance between the relation in

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: which the Trojan war stood to Greece, and that of the Crusades to

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: Western Europe. The political unity and collective existence of Greece

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: was greatly due to the first, that of Christendom to the second.

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: The combination of races and of chiefs, the arduous character and

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: extraordinary prolongation of the effort, the chivalry displayed, the

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: disorganizing effects upon the countries which supplied the invading

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: army, the representation in each of Europe against Asia, of Western

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: mankind meeting Eastern mankind in arms, and the proof of superior

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: prowess in the former, establish many broad and deep analogies between

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: the subjects of these poems. In both struggles, too, the object

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: purported to be the recovery of that which the East had unrighteously

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: acquired: and into both what is called sentiment far more largely

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: entered, than is common in the history of the wars which have laid

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: desolate our earth.

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
SECT. V.[875]
line: ~_Exaggeration as used by Homer and by Tasso._~

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
SECT. V.[875]
line: As Godfrey is Tasso’s version of Agamemnon, so the Rinaldo of Tasso

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: occupies a place in the Jerusalem, similar to that of Achilles in the

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: Iliad. Now the whole character of Achilles, mental and corporeal, which

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: ranks at least among the most wonderful of all the works of Homer, is

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: colossal and vast, but is not unduly exaggerated. Although the son of

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: Peleus evidently was of great bodily size, yet Homer never calls him by

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: the epithets μέγας and πελώριος, but reserves them for Ajax, because

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: they suggest a predominance of the animal over the incorporeal element,

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: which, in the case of Achilles, the Poet utterly eschews. The character

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: of Rinaldo as a warrior (and in no other respect does he present any

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: salient point) is, as will be shown, exaggerated unduly, but yet does

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: not leave the impression of the vast or colossal, because the excess

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: beyond common nature is not in harmony with the rest of the delineation.

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
SECT. V.[875]
line: Thus the strength of Achilles is the very highest; none can use his

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: spear. But Rinaldo, in the assault of the Tower, does the work of a

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: battering-ram. He takes up and carries a beam, of which we are told,

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
SECT. V.[875]
line: Nè così alte mai, nè così grosse

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: Spiega l’ antenne sue ligura nave[954].

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
SECT. V.[875]
line: [954] Gerus. xix. 36.

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
SECT. V.[875]
line: With this he breaks the bars, and beats down the gates; and the stanza

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: proceeds:

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
SECT. V.[875]
line: Non l’ ariète di far più si vanti,

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: Non la bombarda, fulmine di morte[955].

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
SECT. V.[875]
SECT. V.[875]
SECT. V.[875]
line: No such excess of muscular power as this is ascribed to Achilles;

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: and yet a much more lively impression of grandeur in his martial

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: character is left upon the mind of the reader; the fact being that mere

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: exaggeration freezes, while the adjusted representation of greatness

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: warms.

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
SECT. V.[875]
line: The largest size assigned by Homer to any even of his mythological

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: personages who are in relations with man, and this only in the Shades

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: below, is in the case of Otus and Ephialtes. At nine years old, when

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: they were put to death, they were nine cubits broad, nine fathoms

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: (fifty-four feet) high[956]. These were they, who piled the mountains

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: up to heaven. They are among the few figures absolutely gigantic,

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: which appear in Homer; but they hover only in the distance through the

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: mists of the Under-world, and in describing even them he has adhered

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: strictly to the limits of what may be termed the gigantesque. Further

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: on, he describes Tityus as reaching over nine acres; but he nowhere

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: presents any such person to us in active motion, or in any relation

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: with man on earth. In Il. xxi. however, occurs a passage which it is

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: more easy to impugn; for Mars, who had marched about among the Trojans

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: and the Greeks in battle without driving either friends or foes from

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: their propriety by his bulk, and had fought with Diomed in the plain

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: of Troy on terms favourable to that hero, when overthrown by Minerva

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: in the battle of the gods, covers seven acres (407). Although Homer

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: has skilfully avoided localizing the conflict, this may be thought to

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: wear the aspect of a poetical incongruity; because in the Mars of the

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: Theomachy we cannot wholly forget the Mars of the plain. As a general

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: rule, however, Homer does not employ vast size, except in cases where

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: it can suggest no comparison with objects of ordinary dimensions, and

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: where, accordingly, it in no way jars with our customary standard.

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
SECT. V.[875]
SECT. V.[875]
SECT. V.[875]
line: But if there be incongruity in the dimensions of the prostrate Mars of

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: Homer, what shall we say to Tasso, who, carefully setting out in detail

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: that his infernal assembly is held within the four walls of the palace

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: of Pluto, describes the sub-terranean monarch, when he sits in actual

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: council, as exceeding in mass, and that immeasurably, any mountain

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: whatever?

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
SECT. V.[875]
line: Nè tanto scoglio in mar, nè rupe alpestra,

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: Nè pur Calpe s’ innalza, o ’l magno Atlante,

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: Ch’ anzi lui non paresse un picciol colle[957].

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
SECT. V.[875]
line: [957] Gerus. iv. 6.

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
SECT. V.[875]
line: Thus, where Homer is in excess, Tasso multiplies upon him by a

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: thousandfold. This is not grandeur, but extravagance; nor is it

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: vastness, but indistinctness, of which an impression is left upon the

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: mind. The passage is followed by a description of the countenance and

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: gorge of Pluto, which all readers must remember, but which all readers

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: must likewise wish they could forget. In general it is curious to

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: compare the very sparing use which Homer has made of mere bulk as a

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: poetical engine, with the boundless redundance of it, not only even to

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: nausea in such writers as Fortiguerra, who vulgarize everything they

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: touch, but even in a patriarch of Italian romance like Bojardo.

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
SECT. V.[875]
line: It would not, however, repay the trouble to be entailed by the perusal,

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: were I to draw out in detail a comparison between the diction, taste,

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: figures, and all other incidents of poetic handling, in Tasso, and

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: those of Homer. It is better to direct attention to what more easily

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: admits of being brought into juxtaposition--that is, the general

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: structure and movement of the poems, and the manner in which the

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: greater laws of the poetic art are applied to the respective subjects.

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
SECT. V.[875]
line: Mr. Hallam adopts an opinion of Voltaire, that in the choice of his

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: subject Tasso has been superior to Homer; and adds, that ‘in the

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: variety of occurrences, in the change of scenes and images, and of

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: the trains of sentiment connected with them in the reader’s mind, we

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: cannot place the Iliad on a level with the Jerusalem;’ that, by unity

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: of subject and place, the poem of Tasso has a coherence and singleness

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: not to be found in the Æneid; and that, while we expect the victory of

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: the Christians, ‘we acknowledge the probability and adequacy of the

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: events that delay it[958].’

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
SECT. V.[875]
line: [958] Hallam’s Literature of Europe, ii. 268.

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
SECT. V.[875]
line: Of the Italians themselves, some place the work of Tasso at the very

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: head of all Epic compositions: others maintain, that it was surpassed

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: by the Orlando Furioso. Tiraboschi, while declining to weigh the poems

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: against each other generally, yet compares the poets, and gives the

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: higher place to Ariosto[959]. Neither the agitated, struggling, and

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: dependent life of Tasso, nor the character of the time in which he

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: lived, were favourable to the attainment of the very summit of poetic

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: excellence. The freshness of the morning of Christian civilization in

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: Italy had worn away. The romantic poetry, which seemed so congenial

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: to that country, and which had attained to such high perfection, had

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: now run its course: it was rather an effort against nature, than a

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: movement in the line of it, when Tasso wrought upon a subject which

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: required him to bridle his country’s freer Muse, and train her to

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: historic grandeur and severity. He has left us the undoubted work of a

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: great mind, adorned with abundant and, in some respects, extraordinary

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: beauties; yet many would own themselves not to have experienced from

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: the Jerusalem that peculiar sort of satisfaction, which any work of

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: simple tenour, if nearly approaching perfection in its kind, even

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: though that kind be somewhat below the epic, never fails to impart to

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: the mass of its readers.

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]

line: [959] Lett. Ital., vol. vii.

SECT. V.[875]
line: Granting it to be true, that the Siege of Jerusalem is a nobler subject

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: than the Wrath of Achilles, together with all that it includes of the

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: siege of Troy, yet neither is the Siege of Jerusalem, with the high

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: elements it comprehends, really the staple of the subject matter of

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: Tasso, nor is the Siege of Troy the real subject of the poem of Homer.

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: Tasso had evidently studied with attention the Iliad as well as the

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
