line: but a great deal more, as far as I have seen, from the former than the

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: latter. In which selection, doubtless, he chose well. The copy of a

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: copy is pretty sure to be a vulgar work. Without noticing at present

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: anything except what governs the main action, it may be observed, that

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: the Wrath of Achilles is reproduced in the Offence, given and taken, of

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: Rinaldo: and the relation of the one to Godfrey is evidently suggested

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: by that of the other to Agamemnon.

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
SECT. V.[875]
line: ~_Achilles the subject of the Iliad._~

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
SECT. V.[875]
line: It is needful here to return to a topic, which I have already more

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: lightly touched. We may reckon it among the chief distinctions of

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: Homer, that he has been able to make of the individual man the broad

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: basis of the most heroical among epic songs. The weak thread of the

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: Æneid is really sustained by something that lies behind the figure of

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: Æneas, namely, by its hanging on the splendid fortunes of Rome; the

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: Odyssey is toned more nearly to the colour of a domestic painting; but

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: in the Iliad, the man Achilles is the power whose action propels, and

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: whose inaction stops, the world-wide conflict before Troy. The Poet has

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: accomplished this great feat by dint of powers, that have given to the

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: character of his hero on the one hand dimensions absolutely colossal,

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: and, on the other, the finest lines that miniature itself could require.

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
SECT. V.[875]
line: For efforts of such a range as this, after-poets had not the necessary

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: strength. They had not such command over the high-born material, of

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: which man is formed, as to make their mode of treating it in one single

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: figure the main stake, on which the fortune of their entire works was

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: to depend. Men like Tasso sought and found a basis, less elevated

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: indeed and splendid, but equally solid, and far more accessible, in the

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: great events of history, or in the multitude of associations, alike

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: noble and familiar, which belonged to them. These, which with Homer

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: had been organically, and not mechanically alone, grouped about the

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: one great Humanity of his poem, now became the central stem of the

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: epic; and the properly and strictly personal element, which had been

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: primary, became no more than accessory. But events are made for man,

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: and not man for events; and we can scarcely doubt that the transition

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: from the older epic, which gathered all its interests around the human

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: soul as a centre, to the newer, which exhibits the human soul itself

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: in a subordinate relation to external history or fortune, has been a

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: transition downwards. It may be said, that Achilles is not the subject

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: of the Iliad, in the same sense as Ulysses of the Odyssey. It is at

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: any rate true that the action of the Odyssey is more directly related

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: to the hero, than that of the Iliad. And so precise is the working

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: of Homer’s intellect in all that appertains to poetical consistency,

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: that a distinction of shade, just proportioned to this difference, is

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: perhaps perceptible in the very _exordia_ of the two poems, μῆνιν ἄειδε

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: Θεὰ, and ἄνδρα μοι ἔννεπε, Μοῦσα, πολύτροπον. The one seems to propose

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: the Wrath of the Man: the other the Man himself. But substantially

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: the proposition is questionable: Achilles is in effect, as truly as

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: Ulysses, the life and strength, the chief glory and beauty, of his own

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: poem.

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
SECT. V.[875]
line: It might perhaps be doubted, whether even the Liberation of Jerusalem

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: was a finer subject for Christendom, than the siege of Troy for the

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: Greek race. For it is a mistake to suppose that because the Redemption

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: of mankind infinitely transcends all other transactions, the poetry

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: which is composed about it will therefore be excellent in proportion.

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: But at any rate this is not the question. Homer’s subject is, indeed,

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: the Titanic passion of Achilles, and to this subject every Book of the

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: Iliad, some of them positively and some negatively, but every one of

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: them effectively, contributes; but is the Liberation of Jerusalem the

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: true subject of the poem of Tasso?

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
SECT. V.[875]
line: ~_Subject of the Gerusalemme more doubtful._~

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
SECT. V.[875]
line: The three first Cantos, with the ninth, the eleventh, and the

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: nineteenth, are the only ones, which are in strictness occupied with

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: the proper theme of the Jerusalem. The fifth, fifteenth, and sixteenth,

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: and large portions at the least of the other eleven, are taken from

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: the Siege, and are given to the truancy, or erratic and separate

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: adventures, of those who ought to have carried it on; mainly of the two

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: principal Christian warriors, Rinaldo and Tancredi. In short, near a

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: moiety of the work is occupied, not with the Liberation of Jerusalem at

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: all, but with the events which draw away the champions pledged to it,

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: upon errands of a character the most incongruous with the grand design.

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
SECT. V.[875]
line: Will it be answered, that in the same manner Achilles disappears

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: from the eye of the spectator during one moiety of the Iliad? The

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: apparent parallel is wholly false. For the subject of the Iliad is

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: the passion of Achilles; and the whole movement of the poem in his

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: absence bears directly upon the enhancement and elevation of that

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: subject. It exhibits to us the successive efforts of the Greeks, and

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: of their most redoubted chieftains, one by one, to make up for the

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: seclusion of Achilles from the fighting host. It was impossible for

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: Homer more effectually to magnify his hero, than by recounting fully

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: these exploits and their failure. In showing the perils and calamities

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: brought about by his absence, they deeply impress us with the grandeur

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: and efficacy of his presence, and prepare us for the reappearance of

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: something more than man: of something which, but for a most skilful

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: preparatory mechanism, we should probably have repelled as an unnatural

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: exaggeration. But the love-born vagaries of the warriors of Tasso are

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: mere impediments to the conquest of Jerusalem, and have no effect

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: whatever in enhancing the poetical greatness of the achievement which

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: was to crown the work, while they seriously deduct from the power and

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: effectiveness, already in the case of Rinaldo but moderate, of the

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: characters assigned to the warriors themselves.

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
SECT. V.[875]
line: It may therefore be true, as Mr. Hallam has said, that the events

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: in Tasso spring naturally one from another; but so may a series of

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: successive turnings off the line of a road we have been travelling,

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: when taken singly, produce no serious, and even no sensible, deviation;

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: yet their effect, when taken together, may be wholly to change our

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: direction, and prevent us from making any way at all towards our point.

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: Without doubt, each incident of an epic poem ought to follow naturally

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: in the train of that which directly precedes it; but it is far more

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: important that it should bear a legitimate relation to the central

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: design, and should magnify, not detract from, the grandeur of that on

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: which the whole fabric principally depends.

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
SECT. V.[875]
line: But there are surely many other objections to the mode, which Tasso

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: has adopted, of impeding and retarding the accomplishment of his main

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: action. Considering the nature of his theme, and the solemnity of the

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: sanctions under which the Crusades were undertaken, although we have

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: no right to ask that passion and infirmity should be banished from the

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: camp, yet the wholesale entanglement of the very first warriors in

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: love affairs, their rushing in a mass, with few exceptions besides

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: greyheads of the camp, upon the track of Armida, their compelling

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: Godfrey to allow the interests of this treacherous beauty to interrupt

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: the august purpose of their undertaking, and then the very large

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: proportion of the poem occupied in unravelling the web thus tangled,

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: form, to my view at least, a bad poetical mixture of the intrusive with

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: the Christian elements of the design.

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
SECT. V.[875]
line: Nor let it here be said, that even so our great Achilles stays the

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: progress of the Greeks towards triumph for the love of a weak woman.

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: We need not dwell on such distinctions as that Briseis was a noble and

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: worthy, but Armida an unworthy object of attachment; that Achilles was

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: but one, while Tasso touches all, who by age were capable, with the

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: same phrensy. It is not even this worthy attachment alone, that acts

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: upon Achilles: that is not the main stress of the tempest which so

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: rends the strong heaving oak when he cries,

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
SECT. V.[875]
line: ἀλλά μοι οἰδάνεται κραδίη χόλῳ, ὁππότ’ ἐκείνων

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: μνήσομαι, ὥς μ’ ἀσύφηλον ἐν Ἀργείοισιν ἔρεξεν

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: Ἀτρείδης, ὡσεί τιν’ ἀτίμητον μετανάστην[960].

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
SECT. V.[875]
SECT. V.[875]
SECT. V.[875]
line: In Achilles, baffled love is surmounted by the image of agonizing

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: pride, pierced through and through; and high over this again towers

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: his hatred of the meanness of Agamemnon, and his sense of Justice,

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: stung to the very inmost quick. Even supposing the question to be open,

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: whether Homer has mixed his ingredients in due or in undue proportions,

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: at all events there is no essential conflict among them. But such a

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: conflict becomes visible and glaring, when a scope is assigned to the

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: impulses and sway of personal passion upon an army devoted to God and

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: to the highest aim, such as it is quite impossible to exemplify, nay to

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: suppose, in any army that has ever been banded together for any even of

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: the meaner ends of earthly policy.

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
SECT. V.[875]
line: Again, although Tasso’s poem is eminently Christian in its general

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: intention, who does not feel that, instead of gathering our main

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: sympathies and interest by means of his accessory circumstances round

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: his principal subject, he has too effectually severed them from it,

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: and has left it so bare and naked, that his liberation of Jerusalem

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: is after all very like a common capture and sack; very like what,

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: _mutatis mutandis_, the capture of it by the Saracens must have been?

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: We leave him with our minds full of Tancredi and Clorinda, of Rinaldo

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: and Armida, of Gildippe and Odoardo; but the associations, which these

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: names suggest, connect themselves with any subject, rather than with

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: the liberation of the Holy Sepulchre; and the respected Godfrey, with

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: his plans, has, at most points of the poem, little more share in our

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: thoughts than the Jupiter of the Iliad, as he feasts remotely grand on

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: Olympus, or sits on Ida for the convenience of a nearer view.

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
SECT. V.[875]
line: ~_Relative places of Rinaldo and Tancredi._~

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
SECT. V.[875]
line: Besides these objections of irrelevant interpolation, incongruous

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: mixture, and divided interests, it may be observed that the relative

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: prominence of the heroes of Tasso is not clearly pronounced. No one

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: can doubt as to the question, who is the first, and by far the first,

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: figure of the Iliad. Achilles ever haunts us, either in recollection

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: or by sight; at any rate, he stands among and above his brother

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: chieftains, as Saul out-topped by head and shoulders the people of

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: Israel. But it is not easy to say who is the hero or protagonist of

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: the Jerusalem. Although the interest which he attracts is inferior,

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: yet the virtues, intellect, and moral force of Godfrey stand high

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: and clear beyond those of all the other more prominent personages:

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: he bears himself so meekly in his high office, and yet so perfectly

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: and so exclusively exhibits the political spirit, that by mere moral

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: and official greatness he stands, in any general view of the poem, an

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: inconvenient neighbour and a dangerous rival to the two other figures,

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: for one of whom the title of hero must have been designed. Taking,

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: next, the yet more serious question between Tancredi and Rinaldo, which

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: of this pair is intended to command the chief interest? Apparently,

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: in Tasso’s intention, it is Rinaldo; because without him the main

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: action stops, with him it proceeds. And yet the poet has assigned to

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: Tancredi the deadly single combat with, and the triumph so powerfully

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: described over, Argante, the only really great and terrible champion on

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: the Mahometan side. How would the Iliad stand, if Diomed had killed

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: Hector, and had left to Achilles only Æneas or Sarpedon?

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
SECT. V.[875]
line: Tasso here seems himself to have felt an incongruity, and to have

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: sought to compensate Rinaldo in quantity for the (comparatively)

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: deficient quality of his conquests. In the final assault he slays a

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: multitude of the enemy like sheep[961]; when, as the poet says, in a

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: manner surely far beneath his theme, the taste of victory had excited

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: in him the appetite of carnage[962].

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
SECT. V.[875]
line: [961] Gerus. xx. 55.

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
SECT. V.[875]
SECT. V.[875]
SECT. V.[875]
line: Nor is it only in the distribution of military glory, that Rinaldo

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: appears to have suffered for the advantage of Tancred. On one occasion

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: indeed, immediately after the death of Gernando, Tasso has degraded

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: Tancred for the advantage of Rinaldo. For the poet makes this warrior

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: plead, that the offence of Rinaldo should be considered according to

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: the quality of him who committed it, and that there can be no such

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: thing as true justice without respect of persons:

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
SECT. V.[875]
line: Or ti sovvegna

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: Saggio signor, chi sia Rinaldo, e quale;

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: ...       non dee chi regna

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: Nel castigo con tutti esser uguale.

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: Vario è l’ istesso error ne’ gradi vari;

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: E sol l’ egualità giusta è co’ pari[963].

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
SECT. V.[875]
SECT. V.[875]
SECT. V.[875]
line: It was acting on an opinion of this kind, in the case of the Master of

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: Stair after the Massacre of Glencoe, that left uneffaced a deep stain

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: on the memory of William III. and of Scotland. Doubtless there have

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: been periods when, even in Christian countries, such sentiments have

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: been professed as well as practised; but can there have been any period

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: when the utterance of them from the mouth of a knight, who is exhibited

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: to us as a pattern, would not have caused a revulsion in the minds of

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: ordinary hearers or readers?

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
SECT. V.[875]
line: ~_The Woman-characters of Tasso._~

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
SECT. V.[875]
line: The Jerusalem is greatly overstocked with interesting couples; so much

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: so, that at times we almost seem to be reading a Pastoral poem. Taken

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: singly, the details of these love-stories are worked up with infinite

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: art and beauty, and are the most effective and successful portions of

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: the whole Epic; but the aggregate is so much too large, that it chills

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: the general tone, as well as weakens the broader effects. The excess

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: of quantity is, indeed, gross and glaring. Tasso has followed the

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: Christian Romancers in employing largely the idea of the woman-warrior,

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: practically unknown to Homer, introduced with great spirit but no very

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: elevated moral effect in Virgil, carried by Bojardo and Ariosto to its

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: perfection; and, without doubt, a conception far more suitable to the

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: standard of those great poets of fancy, than to the lofty level of the

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: Epic or the higher drama, which deal with the greatest powers and the

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: deepest problems of our nature. Still, as to the manner of employing

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: it, we need not deny that high praise must be accorded to the Clorinda

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: of Tasso. It is indeed easy to criticize the religious incidents of her

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: death, and not easy to understand what business she has after death

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: in a tree of the enchanted wood; or why, when that wood becomes the

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: prey of the carpenters, she is so unceremoniously overlooked in her

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: uncomfortable abode. But as to the main exhibition of the character,

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: she follows Bradamante without degeneracy: pure, upright, chivalrous,

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: thoroughly martial, and yet not grossly masculine. She falls to

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: the lot of Tancred. But besides the Sofronia, the Erminia, and the

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: Gildippe, in the second degree of prominence, there is projected on

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: the picture another person yet more conspicuous than even Clorinda,

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: namely, Armida; so different that they can hardly be compared, and yet

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: inconveniently jarring from the similarity of their relations to the

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: great heroes of the poem. Both, too, are lovely; both figure in the

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: camp. Notwithstanding, however, the profusion of charms, which Tasso

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: has called into existence to set off the person and the powers of

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: Armida, nothing can be more unsatisfactory than her character itself,

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: except its place in the poem, and her particular relation to Rinaldo.

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: When every one else is ravished by her overpowering attractions, he

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: remains insensible: and yet afterwards, with no poetical justification

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: for the change, he becomes desperately enamoured of her. Here we see

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: that feebleness in the conception and exhibition of character, which

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: depresses the flight of Tasso, which excludes him from a place in the

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: class, quite as open to poets as to philosophers, the class of the

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: greatest masters of thought and of human nature.

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
SECT. V.[875]
line: ~_The Armida of Tasso._~

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
SECT. V.[875]
line: We become acquainted with Armida, the beautiful enchantress, first in

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: the guise of a forlorn damsel, who implores succour from the Christian

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: heroes; and this is perhaps the most successful portion of the _rôle_

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: assigned to her. Then she appears as the Circe of her own gardens:

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: then she is a Dido without an Æneas, for the escape of Rinaldo from

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: the disgraceful servitude into which she had inveigled him bears no

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: resemblance to the fond and deep passion of the Carthaginian queen,

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: which grew out of an honourable hospitality afforded to the Trojans in

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: distress. With a disagreeable amount of likeness in detail, the copy

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: still misses the original, and loses all that force and majesty of

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: intense passion to which here, and here alone, Virgil has been enabled

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: to ascend. Then instead of that tragic end of Dido, in which, though

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: with an attitude somewhat theatrical, softness and fierceness are so

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: wonderfully blended, so that she does not forfeit sympathy even in

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: her keenest longings for revenge, Armida has recourse to an expedient

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: which is wholly debased and vulgar. She simply offers herself for

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: sale, promising to be the prize of any warrior of the Egyptian camp,

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: who shall execute her vengeance on Rinaldo for the offence of having

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: escaped out of her toils.

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
SECT. V.[875]
line: Nor have we yet done with the doublings of her tortuous path. She sees

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: Rinaldo pass her in the battle; and, not without infinite doubting,

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: shoots an arrow at him. It is perhaps difficult to define in language

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: what it is, that constitutes the difference between the mental

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: struggles of genuine passion, and mere incongruous vacillation. We see

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: the former in Dido; and one sign of it is a certain progression. Where

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: the law of nature is followed, perpetual fluctuation is not allowed;

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: by degrees, though they may be slow and many, the mind is worked up to

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: a strong resolve, where it abides: its agitation and seeming reflux is

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: but the receding wave of the advancing tide; and when once a strong

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: purpose is full-formed after struggle in a truly powerful nature,

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: whether of man or woman, it must not be changed. Now this is what we

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: miss in Armida. She is ever playing at backwards and forwards. Thrice

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: she draws the bow, thrice she relaxes it: at last she discharges the

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: arrow, but with it a wish that it may miss:

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
SECT. V.[875]
line: Lo stral volò; ma con lo strale un voto

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: Subito uscì, che vada il colpo a voto[964].

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
SECT. V.[875]
line: [964] Gerus. xx. 63.

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
SECT. V.[875]
line: Not unnaturally, this unsatisfactory passage leads us to one of the

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: worst of all the provoking conceits that disfigure from time to time

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: the beautiful pages of this poem:

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
SECT. V.[875]
line: Tanto poteva in lei, benchè perdente,

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: (Or che potria vittorioso?) amore[965].

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
SECT. V.[875]
SECT. V.[875]
SECT. V.[875]
line: Yet, after all this, revenge again gets the upper hand, and her eye

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: follows the arrow with avidity, hoping it may strike. She then repeats

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: the shot again and again, and while doing it is again herself shot in

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: return by love:

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
SECT. V.[875]
line: E mentre ella saetta, Amor lei piaga[966].

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
SECT. V.[875]
SECT. V.[875]
SECT. V.[875]
line: Again the same alternation is reiterated; but her champions fail. She

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: flies. She resumes the part of Dido; apostrophizes her own weapons in a

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: speech of near thirty lines, entreating them to despatch her. Rinaldo

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: then arrests her arm; and yet once more, in stanzas replete with beauty

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: of diction, we have the same unsatisfactory and indecisive mixture of

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: ill-assorted emotions, without the strength either of harmony or of

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: contrast, founded on no natural law, connected by no moral or mental

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: tie, ordered to no end or consummation. However, he vows himself her

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: adorer, and she gives herself up to his disposal:

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
SECT. V.[875]
line: Ecco l’ ancella tua; d’ essa a tuo senno

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: Dispon, gli disse; e le fia legge il cenno[967].

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
SECT. V.[875]
SECT. V.[875]
SECT. V.[875]
line: And so we leave them. But unhappily we cannot, in leaving them, forget

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: that she is a Mahometan and a sorceress; that her frauds have been the

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: great scandal of the army, and the main obstacle to the completion of

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: its design; that she has never throughout the whole poem exhibited a

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: single quality containing in it the elements of just moral attraction;

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: and that this triumph of mere corporeal form, without one solitary

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: note of inward loveliness, is achieved over the greatest of the

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: warriors of Christ, when engaged, under the immediate and special

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: direction of the Almighty, in the recovery of the Holy Sepulchre from

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: infidel dominion. With all these circumstances before us, it must

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: be admitted that a more lame and unsatisfactory contribution to the

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: climax of a great Christian poem could hardly have been contrived.

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: Nor is the impression much amended by the dedication of the eight

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: last stanzas of the work to the completion of the victory by Godfrey.

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: A reader may, on the contrary, well feel perturbed by the sharpness

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: of the transition, and by the air of unconsciousness with which, in

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: gathering up the threads of the action, Tasso has brought into close

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: neighbourhood matters so heterogeneous, that they form a kind of moral

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: chaos. And the observation applies to the close of the poem, which may

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: well have accompanied it throughout its course; that the sympathies of

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: the reader are not evoked and managed with due, or with any, reference

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: to the greatness and nobleness of the objects, but, on the contrary,

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: are allured into the wrong quarter. Homer has carefully contrived, in

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: the case of Paris, that even his extraordinary personal attractions

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: shall do nothing to give him a hold upon our favour, while he has

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: given his warmest sympathies to the beauty of the innocent, though

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: comparatively insignificant, Euphorbus[968]. How tame and flat, on

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: the contrary, has Tasso made the stainless Erminia, whom indeed he

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: altogether forgets before the poem closes; and what efforts of art has

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: he not used to gather admiring interest around the character and fate

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: of the heartless, even when enamoured, Armida. Nay, more, with some

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: brilliant exceptions, especially that noble one of the first view of

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: Jerusalem, how cold and slack, how uninteresting to the reader, is the

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: movement of the main action of the poem, compared with that of the

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: love-stories which invade and engross so inordinate a portion of the

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: ground. We seem to feel that, after all, the Siege of Jerusalem is not

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: the principal business in hand; it is the task which must somehow or

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: other be got through, but it is not the life and pulse, the light and

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: joy of the poem. As the Siege of Troy was the instrument of Homer, to

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: enable him to develop his Achilles, so the much higher subject of the

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: Crusade is the tool of Tasso to enable him to exhibit his workmanship,

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: chiefly in connection with love-stories, upon very inferior persons

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: and performances. The relative values of the setting and the jewel are

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: totally different in the two cases.

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
SECT. V.[875]
SECT. V.[875]
SECT. V.[875]
line: ~_The affront of Gernando._~

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
SECT. V.[875]
line: Besides the first great hindrance to the prosecution of the siege

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: in the seductive power of Armida when she appears in the camp,

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: there is a second, namely, the slaughter of Gernando by Rinaldo,

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: upon a personal affront. It has here been objected to the first,

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: that the effect assigned to it is out of proportion to all example

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: and to all likelihood, though it may be suitable to the passionate

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: susceptibilities of Tasso’s individual mind; and that this

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: disproportion jars peculiarly from the more than usual elevation of the

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: subject. Is the second obstacle more happily conceived?

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
SECT. V.[875]
line: Rinaldo, in the Fifth Canto, unlike his companions, has proved

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: impregnable to the assaults of Armida’s mingled beauty and art:

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
SECT. V.[875]
line: Ma perch’ a lui colpi d’ amor più lenti

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: Non hanno il petto oltra la scorza inciso,

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: Nè molto impaziente è di rivale,

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: Nè la donzella di seguir gli cale[969].

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
SECT. V.[875]
SECT. V.[875]
SECT. V.[875]
line: He rather aspires to succeed to the fallen Dudone in the immediate

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: command of the forces. Yet even with respect to this, his ambition

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: purports to be under the guidance of high principle:

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
SECT. V.[875]
line: I gradi primi

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: Più meritar che conseguir desio[970].

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
SECT. V.[875]
SECT. V.[875]
SECT. V.[875]
line: Presently the Norwegian Prince Gernando, moved by jealousy, insults

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: him; on which Rinaldo there and then gives him the lie, and slays him.

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
SECT. V.[875]
line: It is hardly possible to measure the inferiority of this combination,

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: as respects poetic art and effect, to the scene of the First Book of

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: the Iliad, with which it must naturally be compared: where Achilles

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: is stung, and stung at once in every fibre of his deep, proud, and

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: impassioned nature, by the mingled meanness and tyranny of Agamemnon.

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: The affront in Homer is so contrived that it shall contain all

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: the highest elements of provocation: avarice, tyranny, injustice,

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: ingratitude, on the one side are made to exacerbate the wounds

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: inflicted by public degradation, and by the sudden loss of a beloved

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: object, on the other. But the insult of Gernando to Rinaldo is an

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: every-day insult of the streets: yet an American duellist could not

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: have been more summary in his proceedings, than is the great Christian

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: champion. The brutal provocation instantly breaks down both the piety

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: and the moral firmness of Rinaldo. It is not so with Achilles. In him

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: there is a conscious force of self-command, which absolutely, though

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: not relatively to his passion, is even beyond that of other men; and

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: though unequal, indeed, yet is all but not unequal to controlling that

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: tempestuous flood of wrath. Nothing can be grander than the picture of

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: this his first great mental convulsion. We must quote the lines:

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
SECT. V.[875]
line: ὣς φάτο· Πηλείωνι δ’ ἄχος γένετ’, ἐν δέ οἱ ἦτορ

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: στήθεσσιν λασίοισι διάνδιχα μερμήριξεν,

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: ἢ ὅγε φάσγανον ὀξὺ ἐρυσσάμενος παρὰ μηροῦ

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: τοὺς μὲν ἀναστήσειεν, ὁ δ’ Ἀτρείδην ἐναρίζοι,

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: ἠὲ χόλον παύσειεν, ἐρητύσειέ τε θυμόν[971].

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
SECT. V.[875]
SECT. V.[875]
SECT. V.[875]
line: Then, while the strong current eddies to and fro within him, and while

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: his fingers, playing instinctively on the handle of his sword, cause

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: its blade to be seen, comes the warning vision of Pallas to him, and to

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: him alone. This admonition restores the disturbed balance of his mind;

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: and, his inward wound assuaged with the promise of a future revenge, to

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: be wrought out for him by the self-condemning hands of the inflicters

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: and abettors of the wrong, he moodily foregoes the reckoning of blood.

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
SECT. V.[875]
line: Such is the solid, the Cyclopian structure of the fabric, into which

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: Homer has built his characters. Had the hero of Tasso indeed been

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: endowed with a sublimity of passion beyond or like that of Achilles, we

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: might not have been entitled to call him strictly to account for the

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: slaughter of Gernando. But the truth is, that he is a somewhat jejune

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: and feeble character; and his offence in this instance is not from

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: the excess of the impelling, but from the defect, or rather the utter

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: absence, of the restraining power.

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
SECT. V.[875]
line: Gioberti, in a posthumous work[972], remarks that the heroes of

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: Paganism are more effective than those of Christianity, because the

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: standard by which they are measured is lower, the idea imperfect

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: instead of perfect. There is, I believe, much both of truth and of

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: depth in this observation. It is no more than justice that Tasso should

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: have the benefit of it, which is not inconsiderable.

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
SECT. V.[875]
line: [972] _La Riforma Cattolica_, lately published at Turin, with an

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: excellent preface by Massari.

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
SECT. V.[875]
line: ~_Differing modes of describing personages._~

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
SECT. V.[875]
line: Such, however, as his heroes are, he takes the precaution to describe

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: them in outline at a very early stage indeed of his proceedings,

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: namely, in the stanzas 8-10 of the First Canto. He here places before

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: us Godfrey, Baldwin, Tancred, Boemondo, and Rinaldo; and he resumes

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: from time to time the business of describing them. Bojardo and

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: Ariosto avoid this; but it is probably because they were dealing with

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: characters of well-known type, already familiar to their audience.

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: Homer, who drew so much more powerfully, had more to describe than

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: any of them. And yet it may be said he never describes characters at

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: all, with the very slight exceptions of Nestor, in a few words, and

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: Thersites with somewhat more detail: the latter, it is evident, because

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: he wanted to concentrate contempt and disgust upon his qualities, for

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: exhibiting which in action he could not afford to such a wretch any

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: extended space: the former, perhaps because he has thought it better

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: for effect to abstain from marking him through the poem by distinctive

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: epithets, and could produce a certain roundness of figure, highly

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: suitable to the personage, in this way with more convenience. But, in

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: general, Homer’s characters are described by their actions only, with

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: the aid of choice and characteristic epithets, and here and there of

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: some small but pointed allusion, not from themselves nor from the Poet,

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: but in the speeches of others. Thus he grapples with the full scale of

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: the demands of the dramatic art. Others could not follow him. We must

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: not blame Tasso for a proceeding quite necessary by way of clue to his

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: poem; rather, indeed, we should praise the ingenious manner in which he

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: has effected his purpose, by a survey which the Almighty takes of the

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: Christian camp; a proceeding alike conducive to the religious character

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: of his poem, not always so well cared for, and to the supply of the

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: first necessities of his readers.

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
SECT. V.[875]
line: In the details of his battles, Tasso is a great and skilful describer.

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: Perhaps in this point alone, out of so many, he may be termed superior

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: to Homer. At least we may be disposed to think he has nothing so

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: unsatisfactory under this head as the death of Patroclus. It may

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: be another question how far he is indebted for instruction in this

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: department to his great countrymen, especially Ariosto, and also

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: whether he has anywhere equalled the magnificent account of that

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: terrible contest with Rodomonte, which, in the Furioso, sums up

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: Ruggiero’s triumphs.

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
SECT. V.[875]
line: As nearly all the greater situations and combinations of the

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: Gerusalemme, and its general framework, have been suggested by the

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: ancients, so the minor imitations are too numerous for notice. Many

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: of Tasso’s similes are extremely beautiful and finished; and he has

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: followed Homer in employing them to relieve the narrative of battle;

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: but he has not observed the same judicious parsimony in other parts of

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: his poem; he has apparently not perceived, certainly not followed, the

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: general rules of Homer in the distribution of this ornament, and the

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: result has been that they produce a somewhat cloying effect.

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
SECT. V.[875]
line: Like Virgil, he has been betrayed into imitating Homer in certain

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: cases, where the whole reason of the case was changed: as, for

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: instance, in the Invocation before the Catalogue, and in the wish

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: expressed for multiplied organs of speech. To Homer, a reciting poet,

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: the Catalogue was a great effort of memory, and it therefore justified

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: the special application to the Muse: to Tasso it must have been one of

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: the easier parts of his performance. As respects the second point, what

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: can be more reasonable in the case of an unwritten composition? what

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: less so, when the poet works with pen and ink? Nor is the case much

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: mended by supposing that Tasso had in mind his recitations, unless the

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: recitation had been, not the accident, but the rule, so that the poem

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: would itself, in the ordinary course of thought, be conceived of as

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: associated with the act of reciting.

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
SECT. V.[875]
line: Tasso seems, however, to have fallen into a more serious error in

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: introducing a Second Catalogue into his poem. The first may be defended

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: by the same reasoning, which so amply warrants that of Homer. But what

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: interest could Christendom or Italy feel in the detailed muster-roll of

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: the Egyptian army?

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
SECT. V.[875]
line: ~_The Return of Rinaldo._~

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
SECT. V.[875]
line: If in the Jerusalem the Wrath is beneath the standard of the Iliad,

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: so is the Return. On the side of Rinaldo, indeed, it is most just and

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: right, that he should be extricated from the entanglements of the

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: seductive Armida: but, on the side of Godfrey, there is the same sorry

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: management of all the moral elements of the case. In Homer, Achilles

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: was justly and most deeply offended: on every principle known to the

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: creed of Paganism, or to Greek life and experience, he justly resented

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: the offence: the utmost that can be imputed to him is a decided excess

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: in the indulgence of a thoroughly righteous feeling: and this was

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: terribly expiated by the bloody death of that friend, who was to him

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: as a second self. But the gross offence of Agamemnon is dealt with

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: according to the most righteous rules; and he is compelled by word

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: and gift to appease the man whom he had robbed, insulted, and striven

line: If it has been found possible in the case of Virgil to institute a more

line: minute comparison with Homer, this cannot be attempted in the case

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: of Tasso, for his work hardly admits of juxta-positions in detail.

line: We have already noticed the abundant stock of real analogies between

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: the subject of the Trojan expedition, and that of the Crusades.

line: feigning a centralization of the Christian enterprise, which I fear did

line: and it still remains hard really to compare the poems, far harder the

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: poets. In order to see this clearly, let us ascend a height, and view

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: the scene which lies before us. How vast a deluge of time and of events

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: has swept away the very world in which Homer lived, and the worlds that

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: succeeded his: the place of nativity is changed, the great gulf of time

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: is stretched between, the language is another, the religion new, all

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: the chains of association have been taken to pieces and re-forged, all

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: the old chords of feeling are now mute, and others that give forth a

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: different music are strung in their stead. And there is also, it must

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: be confessed, a great and sharp descent from the stature of Homer, as a

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: creative poet, to that of Tasso. Yet he too is a classic of Italy, and

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: a classic of the world; and if for a moment we feel it a disparagement

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]
line: to his country that she suffers in this one comparison, let her soothe

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]

Poem Title: SECT. V.[875]

line: Like the sun, which furnishes with its light the close courts and

Poem Title: SECTION VI.

Poem Title: SECTION VI.

line: by successive subdivision, there can be no cause for wonder, if some

Poem Title: SECTION VI.

Poem Title: SECTION VI.

Poem Title: SECTION VI.
line: innumerable veins, it is gradually darkened in its flow. The very

Poem Title: SECTION VI.

Poem Title: SECTION VI.
line: That which, as to documents, is a guarantee, because their errors

Poem Title: SECTION VI.

Poem Title: SECTION VI.

Poem Title: SECTION VI.
line: an original, which has escaped from view. And this universality is his

Poem Title: SECTION VI.
line: alone. An Englishman may pardonably think that his great rival in the

Poem Title: SECTION VI.
line: portraiture of character is Shakespeare--a Briton may even go further,

Poem Title: SECTION VI.

Poem Title: SECTION VI.

line: Ravenswood, or Caleb Balderston, or Meg Merrilies, has not yet come,

Poem Title: SECTION VI.

Poem Title: SECTION VI.
line: first class, who appears in the Homeric poems. He has conferred upon

Poem Title: SECTION VI.

Poem Title: SECTION VI.

Poem Title: SECTION VI.

Poem Title: SECTION VI.
SECTION VI.
line: It is not difficult to point out reasons why the characters of Homer

Poem Title: SECTION VI.
line: should have been peculiarly exposed to injury from the lapse of time.

Poem Title: SECTION VI.
line: Most of all from two causes; because they were of such extraordinary

Poem Title: SECTION VI.
line: and refined merit, and because of the form in which they were conveyed.

Poem Title: SECTION VI.
line: Not only did they bear the stamp that the highest genius alone could

Poem Title: SECTION VI.
line: affix, but nothing less than care, sympathy, and manly effort, could

Poem Title: SECTION VI.
line: enable men to comprehend them. For they were not exhibited in the set

Poem Title: SECTION VI.
line: forms of descriptive passages, which might be learnt by rote, but they

Poem Title: SECTION VI.
line: were wrought out in the fine, as well as deep and strong lines of life

Poem Title: SECTION VI.
line: and action; and none of them could be defined in terms, until they had

Poem Title: SECTION VI.
line: first been profoundly felt within. We were to become acquainted with

Poem Title: SECTION VI.
line: them as friends, by living with them through their varied fortunes; not

Poem Title: SECTION VI.
line: as strangers, by some letter of introduction, that sets forth their

Poem Title: SECTION VI.
line: birth, parentage, calling, and qualifications. For earnest and hearty

Poem Title: SECTION VI.
line: attention they provided the richest possible reward; by the careless

Poem Title: SECTION VI.
line: they were to be enjoyed indeed, but scarcely to be apprehended. To

Poem Title: SECTION VI.
line: the eyes of such men there is little or nothing to discriminate, as

Poem Title: SECTION VI.
line: between Agamemnon, Ajax, Diomed, Menelaus, and Patroclus; and if Nestor

Poem Title: SECTION VI.
line: is a good deal older, Ulysses a good deal more cunning, and Achilles

Poem Title: SECTION VI.
line: even more valiant than the rest, a single touch disposes of these

Poem Title: SECTION VI.
line: differences, and enables us to reduce all the eight nearly to a common

Poem Title: SECTION VI.
line: type. A prior examination of particular instances will best prepare

Poem Title: SECTION VI.
line: us for weighing the force of those other causes, besides the weakness

Poem Title: SECTION VI.
line: of human nature, and the excellence of the works in the general sense

Poem Title: SECTION VI.
line: of the words, that contributed to depress and deface the Homeric

Poem Title: SECTION VI.
line: characters.

line: from a first view of the manners and feelings of the age. As far as

line: is everywhere described as the cause of war, it is nowhere spoken of,

Poem Title: SECTION VI.

line: which we might suppose it would have aroused. Of all the Greeks,

Poem Title: SECTION VI.
line: be assigned for this with more or less confidence. A probable one

Poem Title: SECTION VI.
line: is, as we have seen[991], that the act partook of the character of

Poem Title: SECTION VI.

Poem Title: SECTION VI.

Poem Title: SECTION VI.

Poem Title: SECTION VI.

Poem Title: SECTION VI.
line: since the act had taken place. But perhaps the solution of the question

Poem Title: SECTION VI.
line: is to be mainly found in this consideration, common to modern with

Poem Title: SECTION VI.
line: ancient times, that the causes of war are apt to be swallowed up in

Poem Title: SECTION VI.
line: its circumstances. In entering upon the arbitrement of the sword, men

Poem Title: SECTION VI.

Poem Title: SECTION VI.
line: powerful and often ungovernable. When once the armament was on the

Poem Title: SECTION VI.

Poem Title: SECTION VI.

SECTION VI.
line: It is plain, however, that Homer has represented Hector as keenly

Poem Title: SECTION VI.
line: feeling and resenting, not only his brother’s cowardice, but his

Poem Title: SECTION VI.
line: sensuality. Twice does he address him as mad with lust, and as a

Poem Title: SECTION VI.
line: deceiver of women[992]: out of his five speeches addressed to Paris,

Poem Title: SECTION VI.
line: only one is not reproachful; and in the only one which extends beyond

Poem Title: SECTION VI.

Poem Title: SECTION VI.

Poem Title: SECTION VI.
line: that, being a coward, he was also a ravisher[993]. The charge, however,

Poem Title: SECTION VI.
line: also takes a more specific form. We see that Hector was greatly

Poem Title: SECTION VI.
line: delighted, ἐχάρη μέγα when his rebuke[994] had stirred up Paris to

Poem Title: SECTION VI.
line: offer to stake the whole issue on a single combat with Menelaus. But

Poem Title: SECTION VI.
line: it is said, why, when the battle had been lost, did not Hector enforce

Poem Title: SECTION VI.
line: the terms of the bargain? The answer seems to be this. We stand here

Poem Title: SECTION VI.

Poem Title: SECTION VI.

Poem Title: SECTION VI.

Poem Title: SECTION VI.
line: Agamemnon had at the close of the Third Book in due course demanded

Poem Title: SECTION VI.
line: Helen. Jupiter immediately apprehended the consequences; he saw that if

Poem Title: SECTION VI.
line: faith were kept, Achilles would neither be avenged nor glorified; and

Poem Title: SECTION VI.
line: he accordingly invited the assembly on Olympus to determine, whether

Poem Title: SECTION VI.
line: Helen should be rendered back or not. When this had been settled in

Poem Title: SECTION VI.

Poem Title: SECTION VI.

Poem Title: SECTION VI.

Poem Title: SECTION VI.

Poem Title: SECTION VI.

line: He occupies in the Homeric tradition a place altogether peculiar,

Poem Title: SECTION VI.

Poem Title: SECTION VI.

Poem Title: SECTION VI.

Poem Title: SECTION VI.

Poem Title: SECTION VI.

line: Probably a main reason why Hector has become the groundwork of the

Poem Title: SECTION VI.
line: modern Orlando is, that no one of the Homeric heroes exhibits a

Poem Title: SECTION VI.
line: combination of qualities supplying so appropriate a basis for the

Poem Title: SECTION VI.
line: character of a Christian hero; a tone so sensibly approximating to

Poem Title: SECTION VI.
line: that of the gospel. Partly because of those acts of piety towards the

Poem Title: SECTION VI.
line: Immortals, which can hardly receive in the case of Hector any but a

Poem Title: SECTION VI.
line: favourable construction, and which drew down the all but unanimous

Poem Title: SECTION VI.
line: compassion of the Olympian assembly on his remains; but partly also,

Poem Title: SECTION VI.
line: and yet more, in that mild, just, and tender estimate of character,

Poem Title: SECTION VI.
line: which not only secured his constant gentleness of demeanour towards

Poem Title: SECTION VI.
line: Helen, but made him her protector against the acrimony of others, and

Poem Title: SECTION VI.
line: rendered him considerate and kind even to Paris[999], so soon as he saw

Poem Title: SECTION VI.
line: him disposed at length to be personally active in the mortal struggle

Poem Title: SECTION VI.
line: he had brought upon his country. There is, perhaps, no virtue more

Poem Title: SECTION VI.
line: especially Christian, than the temper which thus equitably and gently

Poem Title: SECTION VI.
line: makes allowances for human weakness, particularly if it be weakness by

Poem Title: SECTION VI.
line: the effects of which we ourselves have suffered.

SECTION VI.
line: The employment, however, of Hector for the purposes of Christian poetry

Poem Title: SECTION VI.
line: has certainly had the effect of perverting for us the true Homeric

Poem Title: SECTION VI.
line: tradition. But, in order to understand this, we must throw aside the

Poem Title: SECTION VI.
line: Hector of our proverbs or our plays, travel back to the Iliad, and set

Poem Title: SECTION VI.
line: out anew from the starting-point of its great author. We must there

Poem Title: SECTION VI.
line: be content to take him not as a pure effort of imagination aimed at

Poem Title: SECTION VI.
line: the production of an ideal man, but as a part of the poem of Homer,

Poem Title: SECTION VI.
line: subordinated like every other part of it to its main purpose, as well

Poem Title: SECTION VI.
line: as to the general laws of historical consistency. In modelling the

Poem Title: SECTION VI.
line: several heroes, he made the exigencies of his Hector yield to the

Poem Title: SECTION VI.
line: exigencies of his Achilles, who could have no real competitor. Nor,

Poem Title: SECTION VI.
line: with the fine characteristic sense he has everywhere shown of the

Poem Title: SECTION VI.
line: national differences between Greek and Trojan, could he build up his

Poem Title: SECTION VI.
line: Hector on the same foundations with his Greek heroes, or give him that

Poem Title: SECTION VI.
line: strength and tenacity of tissue which belongs to the European and

Poem Title: SECTION VI.
line: Achæan character. He could not equip him with either the dauntless

Poem Title: SECTION VI.
line: chivalry in battle, or the profound unswerving sagacity in council,

Poem Title: SECTION VI.
line: which were reserved for the kings of his own race, and for those most

Poem Title: SECTION VI.
line: nearly allied to them. He has imparted to the character of the chief

Poem Title: SECTION VI.
line: Trojan hero, no less than to that of the Trojan people at large, a

Poem Title: SECTION VI.
line: decided Asiatic tinge, which modifies their community of colour with

Poem Title: SECTION VI.
line: the properly European races. In such characters, instinct and sentiment

Poem Title: SECTION VI.
line: take oftentimes the place of inquiry and reflection, and impulse

Poem Title: SECTION VI.
line: does the work of conviction: the ideas of right, order, consistency,

Poem Title: SECTION VI.
line: moral dignity and self-respect, are less clearly, less symmetrically,

Poem Title: SECTION VI.
line: conceived. Though in particular cases, such as that of Hector, the

Poem Title: SECTION VI.
line: deficiency may be made up by a liberal and full development of the most

Poem Title: SECTION VI.
line: affectionate emotions, we feel, in comparing it with the Greeks, that

Poem Title: SECTION VI.
line: we are dealing with a more contracted type of manhood: as if morally,

Poem Title: SECTION VI.
line: no less than locally, we had gone back with Homer one full stage

Poem Title: SECTION VI.
line: nearer to the cradle of our race, and had arrested and fixed the human

Poem Title: SECTION VI.
line: character at the very point where it is neither child nor man.

line: perhaps in these very circumstances we may upon consideration find

line: but fresh reason to admire the skill of Homer, and that rarely erring

Poem Title: SECTION VI.
line: instinct which forbade him to forget his whole in running after his

Poem Title: SECTION VI.
line: details.

Poem Title: SECTION VI.
SECTION VI.
line: His first object seems to have been to give the fullest and boldest

Poem Title: SECTION VI.
line: prominence to the colossal shape, moral as well as physical, of

Poem Title: SECTION VI.
line: Achilles, and therefore to tone down whatever could diminish its

Poem Title: SECTION VI.
line: effect. And here the point of danger evidently lay in Agamemnon;

Poem Title: SECTION VI.
line: the chief of the army was too likely to be the chief of the poem.

Poem Title: SECTION VI.
line: Accordingly he has broken the unity of that character, and has

Poem Title: SECTION VI.
line: chequered it with weakness in various forms. But this was not all: he

Poem Title: SECTION VI.
line: had to keep the Greeks before the Trojans, as well as Achilles before

Poem Title: SECTION VI.
line: the Greeks; not only that he might consult his popularity, but that he

Poem Title: SECTION VI.
line: might indulge the genial vein of his poesy, and follow the impulses

Poem Title: SECTION VI.
line: of his patriotism, in maintaining high above all question their

Poem Title: SECTION VI.
line: intellectual and martial superiority. Had this, however, been all,

Poem Title: SECTION VI.
line: his task would have been easy; he would then have had only to depress

Poem Title: SECTION VI.
line: their opponents in all the properties that attract admiration. But if

Poem Title: SECTION VI.
line: he had simply done this, if he had cut off the interest and sympathies

Poem Title: SECTION VI.
line: of his readers from the Trojans by general disparagement, he would have

Poem Title: SECTION VI.
line: deprived Greek valour of its choicest crown. It is a noble necessity of

Poem Title: SECTION VI.
line: war that, even in the interest of countrymen, we cannot do injustice to

Poem Title: SECTION VI.
line: adversaries, without feeling the offence recoil on our own heads.

Poem Title: SECTION VI.
SECTION VI.
line: Thus it was impossible for Homer to make his Trojan hero at once great

Poem Title: SECTION VI.
line: and consistent; and if he has made Hector unequal, it was to avoid

Poem Title: SECTION VI.
line: making him mean. By chequering his martial daring with boastfulness,

Poem Title: SECTION VI.
line: and with occasional weakness of purpose, he has effectually provided

Poem Title: SECTION VI.
line: against any interference, from this quarter, to the prejudice of those

Poem Title: SECTION VI.
line: chieftains whose praises he was to sing in the courts and throngs of

Poem Title: SECTION VI.
line: Greece. Thus he has left the field quite clear for expatiating on their

Poem Title: SECTION VI.
line: military virtues; and if, for sufficient reasons, he has departed from

Poem Title: SECTION VI.
line: his rule in the case of Agamemnon, who receives his compensation in

Poem Title: SECTION VI.
line: superiority of rank and power, all his other Greek characters, bearing

Poem Title: SECTION VI.
line: forward parts in the poem, are constructed in faultless conformity to

Poem Title: SECTION VI.
line: the idea, or modification of an idea, which he had selected for the

Poem Title: SECTION VI.
line: basis of each. There is not a flaw in the picture of Achilles, Diomed,

Poem Title: SECTION VI.
line: Ajax, Nestor, Menelaus, or Ulysses. Not that all these are of a type

Poem Title: SECTION VI.
line: equally elevated, or alike wonderful; but that there is no one thing

Poem Title: SECTION VI.
line: in any of them which does not manifestly conform to its type, and no

Poem Title: SECTION VI.
line: one thing consequently which jars with any other. Having thus given to

Poem Title: SECTION VI.
line: his countrymen a clear and marked ascendancy in what then at least were

Poem Title: SECTION VI.
line: the only great and governing elements of human society, the strong

Poem Title: SECTION VI.
line: mind, and the strong hand, he does his best for the Trojans with what

Poem Title: SECTION VI.
line: remained, that is to say, with the softer affections of domestic life,

Poem Title: SECTION VI.
line: adding only so much of the martial element as was needful to make them

Poem Title: SECTION VI.
line: no discreditable adversaries for his countrymen. Thus, consistently

Poem Title: SECTION VI.
line: with all his poetic objects, he has been enabled to present us, to say

Poem Title: SECTION VI.
line: nothing of the highly respectable character of Hecuba, with the three

Poem Title: SECTION VI.
line: unsurpassed pictures of Priam, of Andromache, and perhaps even most, of

Poem Title: SECTION VI.
line: Hector.

SECTION VI.
line: Was she a vicious woman and a seductress, or was she more nearly a

Poem Title: SECTION VI.
line: victim and a penitent? Do the laws of poetical verisimilitude and

Poem Title: SECTION VI.
line: beauty, as they were understood by Homer, allow us to suppose that he

Poem Title: SECTION VI.
line: intended to represent his countrymen, of whom he has presented to us

Poem Title: SECTION VI.

Poem Title: SECTION VI.
line: forth their blood, and throwing their country into certain confusion,

Poem Title: SECTION VI.

Poem Title: SECTION VI.

Poem Title: SECTION VI.

Poem Title: SECTION VI.

Poem Title: SECTION VI.

Poem Title: SECTION VI.
SECTION VI.
line: The present inquiry has nothing to do with the opinion that Helen

Poem Title: SECTION VI.
line: was, or that she was not, an historical personage. For my own part, I

Poem Title: SECTION VI.
line: know of no reason except discrepancies of mere traditional chronology

Poem Title: SECTION VI.
line: for disbelieving her existence. These seem to arise entirely from

Poem Title: SECTION VI.
line: the practice of putting on a par with Homer tales of very inferior

Poem Title: SECTION VI.
line: authority to his. But even apart from this, considering what, under

Poem Title: SECTION VI.
line: ordinary circumstances, the chronology of pre-historic times is likely

Poem Title: SECTION VI.
line: to be, and how many more chances there are for the preservation of

Poem Title: SECTION VI.
line: great events in outline, than for a careful adjustment of their

Poem Title: SECTION VI.
line: relative times, I cannot but think that difficulties arising from

Poem Title: SECTION VI.
line: other legends as to Helen, and bearing simply upon time, form a very

Poem Title: SECTION VI.
line: insufficient reason for the wholesale rejection of belief in her

Poem Title: SECTION VI.
line: existence. Even if, however, she never existed at all, it still is not

Poem Title: SECTION VI.
line: one whit the less reasonably to be presumed, that Homer in fictions

Poem Title: SECTION VI.
line: concerning her would be governed here and elsewhere by all the laws,

Poem Title: SECTION VI.
line: including the moral laws, of his art.

Poem Title: SECTION VI.
SECTION VI.
line: Neither is it now the question, whether Helen was the model of an

Poem Title: SECTION VI.
line: heroic character. That is probably inconsistent, for the earliest

Poem Title: SECTION VI.
line: times of Greece, with her adulterous relation to Paris and afterwards

Poem Title: SECTION VI.
line: to Deiphobus. But there is a vast space between a faultless and a

Poem Title: SECTION VI.
line: worthless woman. The idea of Helen represented by the later tradition,

Poem Title: SECTION VI.
line: from the Greek tragedians downwards, is strictly the latter idea: and

Poem Title: SECTION VI.
line: this representation has naturally occupied the popular mind, which is

Poem Title: SECTION VI.
line: deprived of the power of access to the remote Homeric picture. Now

Poem Title: SECTION VI.
line: it seems to be plain that, if this representation be substantially

Poem Title: SECTION VI.
line: true, it is a great reproach to the bard of the Iliad as a bard, and

Poem Title: SECTION VI.
line: stamps him as one, who has done his best to poison morality at its

Poem Title: SECTION VI.
line: fountain-head. For there can be no question, that he has made his Helen

Poem Title: SECTION VI.
line: highly attractive, and that he intends her to possess our sympathies.

Poem Title: SECTION VI.
line: Is it then true, or is it false? Let us proceed to examine the evidence.

SECTION VI.
line: The whole Homeric evidence, then, appears to show that, from the

Poem Title: SECTION VI.
line: moment of her removal, neither the usages of society, nor the ideas of

Poem Title: SECTION VI.
line: religion or the moral code, could allow Helen to remain in the single

Poem Title: SECTION VI.
line: state. But it may be said this seems to prove too much on her behalf;

Poem Title: SECTION VI.
line: namely, that both the abduction and the subsequent life were against

Poem Title: SECTION VI.
line: her will. It is, however, entirely in keeping with the testimony of the

Poem Title: SECTION VI.
line: poems, to suppose that her whole offence lay in having permitted at

Poem Title: SECTION VI.
line: the first, perhaps half unconsciously, the attentions of a flatterer,

Poem Title: SECTION VI.
line: who became at once a paramour and a tyrant to his victim. In order to

Poem Title: SECTION VI.
line: comprehend the heroic age, it is indispensable that we should recollect

Poem Title: SECTION VI.
line: that the responsibilities of women were contracted in proportion to her

Poem Title: SECTION VI.
line: strength; and that the heroism of endurance, in which she has since

Poem Title: SECTION VI.
line: excelled, is a Christian product.

Poem Title: SECTION VI.
SECTION VI.
line: That element of weakness and lightness in a character otherwise

Poem Title: SECTION VI.
line: beautiful, which the incident of the Horse betrays, was probably at

Poem Title: SECTION VI.
line: once the source and the measure of her offending in reference to the

Poem Title: SECTION VI.
line: cause of war. It was a mind of relaxed fibre, and vacillated under

Poem Title: SECTION VI.
line: pressure. Less than this we cannot suppose, and there is no occasion

Poem Title: SECTION VI.
line: to suppose more. The respect felt, within certain limits, for women in

Poem Title: SECTION VI.
line: the heroic age, and so powerfully proved by the Odyssey, may perhaps

Poem Title: SECTION VI.
line: be adverse to the supposition that Paris carried her away without

Poem Title: SECTION VI.
line: some degree of previous encouragement. I confine myself to ‘perhaps,’

Poem Title: SECTION VI.
line: because it is nowhere indicated in the poems, and we can at most have

Poem Title: SECTION VI.
line: only a presumption to this effect. On the other hand, it seems certain

Poem Title: SECTION VI.
line: that what she expiated in life-long sadness was, at any rate, no more

Poem Title: SECTION VI.
line: than the first step in the ways of folly, the thoughtless error of

Poem Title: SECTION VI.
line: short-sighted vanity, which the state of manners did not permit her

Poem Title: SECTION VI.
line: subsequently to redeem. Repent she might: but to return was beyond her

Poem Title: SECTION VI.
line: power.

SECTION VI.
line: On the whole, it may be said with confidence that the Helen of the

Poem Title: SECTION VI.
line: Homeric poems has been conceived, by an author himself of peculiar

Poem Title: SECTION VI.
line: delicacy, with great truth of nature, and with no intention to deprive

Poem Title: SECTION VI.
line: her of a share in the sympathies of his hearers; that he has made her

Poem Title: SECTION VI.

Poem Title: SECTION VI.
line: to a capacity of comprehension and of endurance above her age, but yet

Poem Title: SECTION VI.
line: endowed with much tenderness of feeling, with the highest grace and

Poem Title: SECTION VI.
line: refinement, and with a deep and peculiar sense of shame for having

Poem Title: SECTION VI.
line: done wrong. Probably her appreciation of virtue and of honour, though

Poem Title: SECTION VI.

line: The degradation of Helen by the later tradition will be treated of

Poem Title: SECTION VI.

Poem Title: SECTION VI.

Poem Title: SECTION VI.
line: counterpart of Paris[1037].’ Paris and Helen are respectively ‘the

Poem Title: SECTION VI.
line: man of fashion and the woman of pleasure of the heroic age.’ ‘Both

Poem Title: SECTION VI.

Poem Title: SECTION VI.

Poem Title: SECTION VI.

Poem Title: SECTION VI.

Poem Title: SECTION VI.
line: general levity of her habits.’ This petulance, this general levity,

Poem Title: SECTION VI.

Poem Title: SECTION VI.

Poem Title: SECTION VI.

Poem Title: SECTION VI.

Poem Title: SECTION VI.

Poem Title: SECTION VI.

Poem Title: SECTION VI.
SECTION VI.
line: III. The character of Paris is as worthy, as any other in the poems, of

Poem Title: SECTION VI.
line: the powerful hand and just judgment of Homer. It is neither on the one

Poem Title: SECTION VI.
line: hand slightly, nor on the other too elaborately, drawn; the touches are

Poem Title: SECTION VI.
line: just such and so many, as his poetic purpose seemed on the one hand to

Poem Title: SECTION VI.
line: demand, and on the other to admit. Paris is not indeed the gentleman,

Poem Title: SECTION VI.
line: but he is the fine gentleman, and the pattern voluptuary, of the heroic

Poem Title: SECTION VI.
line: ages; and all his successors in these capacities may well be wished joy

Poem Title: SECTION VI.
line: of their illustrious prototype. The redeeming, or at least relieving

Poem Title: SECTION VI.
line: point in his character, is one which would condemn any personage

Poem Title: SECTION VI.
line: of higher intellectual or moral pretensions; it is a total want of

Poem Title: SECTION VI.
line: earnestness, the unbroken sway of levity and of indifference to all

Poem Title: SECTION VI.
line: serious and manly considerations. He completely fulfils the idea of the

Poem Title: SECTION VI.
line: _poco-curante_, except as to the display of his personal beauty, the

Poem Title: SECTION VI.
line: enjoyment of luxury, and the resort to sensuality as the best refuge

Poem Title: SECTION VI.
line: from pain and care. He is not a monster, for he is neither savage nor

Poem Title: SECTION VI.
line: revengeful; but still further is he from being one of Homer’s heroes,

Poem Title: SECTION VI.
line: for he has neither honour, courage, eloquence, thought, nor prudence.

Poem Title: SECTION VI.
line: That he bears the reproaches of Hector without irritation, is due to

Poem Title: SECTION VI.
line: that same moral apathy, and that narrowness of intelligence, which

Poem Title: SECTION VI.
line: makes him insensible to those of his wife. No man can seriously resent

Poem Title: SECTION VI.
line: what he does not really feel. He is wholly destitute even of the

Poem Title: SECTION VI.
line: delicacy and refinement which soften many of the features of vice; and

Poem Title: SECTION VI.
line: the sensuality he shows in the Third Book[1038] partakes largely of the

Poem Title: SECTION VI.
line: brutal character which marks the lusts of Jupiter. No wise, no generous

Poem Title: SECTION VI.
line: word, ever passes from his lips. On one subject only he is determined

Poem Title: SECTION VI.
line: enough; it is, that he will not give up the woman whom he well knows to

Poem Title: SECTION VI.
line: be without attachment to him[1039], and whom he keeps not as the object

Poem Title: SECTION VI.
line: of his affections, but merely as the instrument of his pleasures. One

Poem Title: SECTION VI.
line: solicitude only he cherishes; it is to decorate his person, to exhibit

Poem Title: SECTION VI.
line: his beauty, to brighten with care the arms that he would fain parade,

Poem Title: SECTION VI.
line: but has not the courage to employ against the warriors of Greece.
