SECTION VI.
line: There are other greater achievements in the Iliad, but none finer,

Poem Title: SECTION VI.
line: or more deserving our commendation, than the manner in which Homer

Poem Title: SECTION VI.
line: has handled the difficult character of Paris. It was quite necessary

Poem Title: SECTION VI.
line: to raise him to a certain point of importance; had he been simply

Poem Title: SECTION VI.
line: contemptible, his place in the early stages of the Trojan tale, and

Poem Title: SECTION VI.
line: the prolongation of the War on his account, would have involved a

Poem Title: SECTION VI.
line: too violent departure from the laws of poetical credibility. This

Poem Title: SECTION VI.
line: importance Homer, whether from imagination or from history, has

Poem Title: SECTION VI.
line: supplied; in part by his very high position. Even if I were wrong in

Poem Title: SECTION VI.
line: the opinion that the Poet meant to represent him as the eldest son, or

Poem Title: SECTION VI.
line: the eldest living son, of Priam, it would still at least be plain that

Poem Title: SECTION VI.
line: he is more eminent and conspicuous than any other member of the royal

Poem Title: SECTION VI.
line: house after Hector; while he is so much less worthy than Deiphobus,

Poem Title: SECTION VI.
line: for example, that no one, I think, could doubt that his distinction is

Poem Title: SECTION VI.
line: due to his being senior to that respectable prince and warrior, and

Poem Title: SECTION VI.
line: to the rest of his brothers. Further, the Poet has raised him to the

Poem Title: SECTION VI.
line: very highest elevation in two particulars; one the gift of archery,

Poem Title: SECTION VI.
line: the other the endowment of corporeal grace and beauty. But neither of

Poem Title: SECTION VI.
line: these involves one particle of courage, or of any other virtue; for the

Poem Title: SECTION VI.
line: archer of Homer’s time was not like the British bowman, who stood with

Poem Title: SECTION VI.
line: his comrades in the line, and discharged the function in war which has

Poem Title: SECTION VI.
line: since fallen to musketry; he was a mere sharpshooter, always having the

Poem Title: SECTION VI.
line: most deliberate opportunity of aim at the enemy, and always himself out

Poem Title: SECTION VI.
line: of danger. No archer is ever hit in the Iliad; but Pandarus, so skilled

Poem Title: SECTION VI.
line: in the bow, is slain, and Paris is disgraced, when they respectively

Poem Title: SECTION VI.
line: venture to assume the spear. Again, the Poet has contrived that the

Poem Title: SECTION VI.
line: accomplishments of Paris, though in themselves unsurpassed, shall

Poem Title: SECTION VI.
line: attract towards him no share, great or small, of our regard. This

Poem Title: SECTION VI.
line: prince really does more, than even Hector does, to stay the torrent of

Poem Title: SECTION VI.
line: the Grecian war; for in the Eleventh Book, from behind a pillar, he

Poem Title: SECTION VI.
line: wounds Diomed, who had fought with the Immortals, Eurypylus, who had

Poem Title: SECTION VI.
line: also been one of the nine accepters of Hector’s challenge, and Machaon,

Poem Title: SECTION VI.
line: one of the two surgeons. Thus Homer[1040] has been able to make him

Poem Title: SECTION VI.
line: most useful in battle, most lovely to the eye, and yet alike detestable

Poem Title: SECTION VI.
line: and detested.

Poem Title: SECTION VI.

Poem Title: SECTION VI.

line: Homer, full as he is of the harmonies of nature, differs in this as in

Poem Title: SECTION VI.
line: so many points from most among later writers, that he does not set at

Poem Title: SECTION VI.
line: nought the due proportion between the moral and the intellectual man,

Poem Title: SECTION VI.

Poem Title: SECTION VI.

Poem Title: SECTION VI.

Poem Title: SECTION VI.

Poem Title: SECTION VI.

SECTION VI.
line: The immediate transition, in the Third Book, from the field of battle,

Poem Title: SECTION VI.
line: where he was disgraced, to the bed of luxury, is admirably suited to

Poem Title: SECTION VI.
line: impress upon the mind, by the strong contrast, the real character of

Poem Title: SECTION VI.
line: Paris. Nor let it be thought, that Homer has gratuitously forced upon

Poem Title: SECTION VI.
line: us the scene between him and his reluctant wife. It was just that he

Poem Title: SECTION VI.
line: should mark as a bad man him who had sinned grossly, selfishly, and

Poem Title: SECTION VI.
line: fatally, alike against Greece and his own family and country. This

Poem Title: SECTION VI.
line: impression would not have been consistent and thorough in all its

Poem Title: SECTION VI.
line: parts, if we had been even allowed to suppose that, as a refined,

Poem Title: SECTION VI.
line: affectionate, and tender husband, he made such amends to Helen as the

Poem Title: SECTION VI.
line: case permitted for the wrong done her in his hot and heady youth. Such

Poem Title: SECTION VI.

Poem Title: SECTION VI.
line: been supported by the very feebleness of the character of Paris and

Poem Title: SECTION VI.
line: by his part in the war, had Homer been silent upon the subject. He,

Poem Title: SECTION VI.
line: therefore, though with cautious hand, lifts the veil so far as to show

Poem Title: SECTION VI.
line: us that in our variously compounded nature animal desire can use up

Poem Title: SECTION VI.
line: and absorb the strength which ought to nerve our higher faculties, and

Poem Title: SECTION VI.
line: that, as none are more cruel than the timid, so none are more brutal

Poem Title: SECTION VI.
line: than the effeminate.

SECTION VI.
line: One hold, and one only, Paris seems to retain on human affection in

Poem Title: SECTION VI.
line: any sort or form. The paternal instinct of Priam makes him shudder and

Poem Title: SECTION VI.
line: retire, when he is told that Paris is about to meet Menelaus in single

Poem Title: SECTION VI.
line: combat. This trait would have been of extraordinary and universal

Poem Title: SECTION VI.

Poem Title: SECTION VI.
line: it is a remarkable proof of the debasement of Paris, and of the strong

Poem Title: SECTION VI.
line: sense which Homer gives us of that debasement, that the tender father

Poem Title: SECTION VI.
line: seems in a measure tainted by the very warmth and strength of his love.

SECT. VII.
line: ~_Physical conditions of the Greek Theatre._~

Poem Title: SECT. VII.
SECT. VII.
line: One legitimate mode of measuring the true greatness of Homer is, by

Poem Title: SECT. VII.
line: observing what has become of the materials and instruments he worked

Poem Title: SECT. VII.
line: with, upon their passing into other hands. Acting on this principle,

Poem Title: SECT. VII.
line: let us now pass on to consider the murderous maltreatment, which the

Poem Title: SECT. VII.
line: most remarkable of all the Homeric characters have had to endure in

Poem Title: SECT. VII.
line: the later tradition; partly, as I have already observed, from general,

Poem Title: SECT. VII.
line: and partly from special causes. On the more general influence of this

Poem Title: SECT. VII.
line: kind I have already touched. Among the special causes, we should place

Poem Title: SECT. VII.
line: the declension in the fundamental ideas of morals and of politics

Poem Title: SECT. VII.
line: between the time of Homer and the historic age. With this we may

Poem Title: SECT. VII.
line: reckon one which, though it may appear to be technical, must, in all

Poem Title: SECT. VII.
line: likelihood, have been most important, namely, the physical necessities

Poem Title: SECT. VII.
line: imposed by the fixed conditions of dramatic representation among the

Poem Title: SECT. VII.
line: Greeks[1047]. Their theatres were constructed on a scale, which may be

Poem Title: SECT. VII.
line: called colossal as compared with ours. Both polity and religion entered

Poem Title: SECT. VII.
line: into the institution of the stage. The intense nationality of their

Poem Title: SECT. VII.
line: life required a similar character in their plays, and likewise in the

Poem Title: SECT. VII.
line: places where they were to be represented. Not therefore a particular

Poem Title: SECT. VII.
line: company of auditors, but rather the whole public of the city, where the

Poem Title: SECT. VII.
line: representation took place, was to be accommodated. In consequence, the

Poem Title: SECT. VII.
line: dimensions of the buildings exceeded the usual powers of the human eye

Poem Title: SECT. VII.
line: and ear; so that the figure was heightened by buskins, the countenance

Poem Title: SECT. VII.
line: thrown into bolder and coarser outline by masks, and the voice endowed

Poem Title: SECT. VII.
line: with a great increase of power by acoustic contrivances within the

Poem Title: SECT. VII.
line: masks, as well as aided by the construction of the buildings. All this

Poem Title: SECT. VII.
line: was the more strictly requisite, because the plays were acted in the

Poem Title: SECT. VII.
line: open air.

Poem Title: SECT. VII.
SECT. VII.
line: [1047] Schlegel, Lect. iii. vol. i. p. 81; Donaldson, Greek Theatre,

Poem Title: SECT. VII.

Poem Title: SECT. VII.
SECT. VII.
line: Now this general exaggeration of feature beyond the standard of

Poem Title: SECT. VII.
line: nature had an irresistible tendency to affect the mode in which

Poem Title: SECT. VII.
line: characters were modelled for representation; to cause them to be laid

Poem Title: SECT. VII.
line: out morally as well as physically in strong outline, in masses large

Poem Title: SECT. VII.
line: and comparatively coarse. The fine and careful finishing of Homer

Poem Title: SECT. VII.
line: required that those, who were to recite him, should retain an entire

Poem Title: SECT. VII.
line: and unfettered command over the measure in which the bodily organs were

Poem Title: SECT. VII.
line: to be employed. The τύνη δ’ ὠμοΐιν of Achilles to Patroclus might bear

Poem Title: SECT. VII.
line: to be spoken in a voice of thunder, and would absolutely require the

Poem Title: SECT. VII.
line: bard to use considerable exertion of the lungs; but the scenes of Helen

Poem Title: SECT. VII.
line: with Priam in the Third Book, of Hector with Andromache in the Sixth,

Poem Title: SECT. VII.
line: of Priam with Achilles in the Twenty-fourth, would admit of no such

Poem Title: SECT. VII.
line: treatment; and as these passages could not themselves be rendered, so

Poem Title: SECT. VII.
line: neither could anything bearing a true analogy to Homer be given, unless

Poem Title: SECT. VII.
line: the actor had enjoyed full liberty to contract as well as expand his

Poem Title: SECT. VII.
line: own volume of sound, or unless he had enjoyed both easy access, on any

Poem Title: SECT. VII.
line: terms he pleased, to the ears of his audience, and the full benefit of

Poem Title: SECT. VII.
line: that most important assistance, which the eye renders to the ear by

Poem Title: SECT. VII.
line: observing the play of countenance that accompanies delivery. King Lear,

Poem Title: SECT. VII.
line: King John, or Othello, could not have been represented more truly and

Poem Title: SECT. VII.
line: adequately in a Greek theatre, than the Achilles, or than the Helen,

Poem Title: SECT. VII.
line: of Homer. Those who have ever happened to discuss with a deaf person

Poem Title: SECT. VII.
line: a critical subject, requiring circumspect and tender handling, will

Poem Title: SECT. VII.
line: know how much the necessity for constant tension of the voice restrains

Poem Title: SECT. VII.
line: freedom in the expression of thought, and mars its perfectness. The

Poem Title: SECT. VII.
line: Greek actors lay under a somewhat similar necessity, and to their

Poem Title: SECT. VII.
line: necessities of course the diction of the tragedians was, whether

Poem Title: SECT. VII.
line: consciously or unconsciously, adapted.

Poem Title: SECT. VII.
SECT. VII.
line: Let it, however, be borne in mind, that when we criticize the

Poem Title: SECT. VII.
line: conceptions of the Homeric characters by the later Greek writers,

Poem Title: SECT. VII.
line: it need not be with the supposition that we have eyes to discern in

Poem Title: SECT. VII.
line: Homer what they did not see. Their reproductions must be taken to

Poem Title: SECT. VII.
line: represent not so much the free dictates of the mind and judgment of

Poem Title: SECT. VII.
line: the later poets, as the conditions of representation to which they

Poem Title: SECT. VII.
line: were compelled to conform, and the popular sentiments and opinions

Poem Title: SECT. VII.
line: which, in the character of popular writers, they could not but take

Poem Title: SECT. VII.
line: for their standard. The invention of printing has given a liberty and

Poem Title: SECT. VII.
line: independence to thought, at least in conjunction with poetry and the

Poem Title: SECT. VII.
line: drama, such as it could not possess while the poet, in Athens for

Poem Title: SECT. VII.
line: example, could sing in no other way but one, namely, to the nation

Poem Title: SECT. VII.
line: collected in a mass. The poet of modern times may write for a minority

Poem Title: SECT. VII.
line: of the public, nay, for a mere handful of admirers, which is destined,

Poem Title: SECT. VII.
line: yet only in after-years, to grow like the mustard-seed of the parable.

Poem Title: SECT. VII.
line: But the Athenian dramatist was compelled to be the poet of the majority

Poem Title: SECT. VII.
line: at the moment, and to be carried on the stream of its sympathies,

Poem Title: SECT. VII.
line: however adverse its direction might be to that in which, if at liberty

Poem Title: SECT. VII.
line: to choose, he would himself have moved.

Poem Title: SECT. VII.
SECT. VII.
line: ~_Obliteration of the finer distinctions._~

Poem Title: SECT. VII.
SECT. VII.
line: Accordingly, when we come to survey the literary history of those great

Poem Title: SECT. VII.
line: characters which the Poet gave as a perpetual possession to the world,

Poem Title: SECT. VII.
line: we find, naturally enough, that the flood of the more recent traditions

Poem Title: SECT. VII.
line: has long ago come in upon the Homeric narrative, like the inundation

Poem Title: SECT. VII.
line: brought by Neptune and Apollo over the wall and trench of the Greeks.

Poem Title: SECT. VII.
line: Like every other deluge, in sweeping away the softer materials, which

Poem Title: SECT. VII.
line: give the more refined lines to the picture, it leaves the comparatively

Poem Title: SECT. VII.
line: hard and sharp ones harder and sharper than ever. Thus it is with the

Poem Title: SECT. VII.
line: Homeric characters, transplanted into the later tradition. The broader

Poem Title: SECT. VII.
line: distinctions of his personages one from another have been not only

Poem Title: SECT. VII.
line: retained, but exaggerated: all the finer ones have disappeared. No

Poem Title: SECT. VII.
line: one, deriving his ideas from Homer only, could confound Diomed with

Poem Title: SECT. VII.
line: Ajax, or either with Agamemnon, or any of the three with Menelaus, or

Poem Title: SECT. VII.
line: any of the four with Achilles; but when we come down to the age of

Poem Title: SECT. VII.
line: the tragedians, what remains to mark them, except only for Agamemnon

Poem Title: SECT. VII.
line: his office, and for Achilles his superiority in physical strength? In

Poem Title: SECT. VII.
line: the Homeric poems, the strong and towering intellectual qualities even

Poem Title: SECT. VII.
line: outweigh the great physical and animal forces of his chief hero: by

Poem Title: SECT. VII.
line: the usual predominance in man of what is gross over what is fine, the

Poem Title: SECT. VII.
line: principal and higher parts of his character are afterwards suppressed,

Poem Title: SECT. VII.
line: and it becomes comparatively vulgarized. In the Ulysses of Homer,

Poem Title: SECT. VII.
line: again, the intellectual element predominates in such a manner, that not

Poem Title: SECT. VII.
line: even the most superficial reader can fail to perceive it. He and Helen

Poem Title: SECT. VII.
line: stand out in the Iliad from among others with whom they might have

Poem Title: SECT. VII.
line: been confounded; the first by virtue of his self-mastery and sagacity,

Poem Title: SECT. VII.
line: the second, not only by her beauty and her fall, but by the singularly

Poem Title: SECT. VII.
line: tender and ethereal shading of her character. The later tradition,

Poem Title: SECT. VII.
line: laying rude hands upon the subtler distinctions thus established, has
